content:

title: How to Hit a Flick in Pickleball
summary: Master the flick shot in pickleball to surprise opponents, win more rallies, and boost your pickleball ratings. Learn when, why, and how to hit it a flick like a pro.
content:
If you‚Äôre serious about improving your pickleball game, whether you‚Äôre chasing a higher DUPR rating or just looking to win more rec games, strength training isn‚Äôt optional. It‚Äôs the secret weapon that helps you move faster, hit harder, and play longer without breaking down.

‚Äç

‚Äç

And with DUPR‚Äôs new partnership with GRAVL, you can now get personalized, pickleball-specific workouts that make training as smart as your strategy on the court.

‚Äç

Why Strength Training Matters for Pickleball Players

‚Äç

Pickleball might look low-impact to the casual observer, but competitive players know the truth: it‚Äôs an explosive, quick-change-of-direction sport that demands power, agility, balance, and endurance.

‚Äç

Here‚Äôs how strength training helps:

‚Äç

1. More Power in Your Shots
Stronger legs and core help you hold position and transfer energy into the ball with less effort.

‚Äç

2. Faster Court Coverage
Leg strength and stability training translate to quicker first steps, faster lateral movement, and the ability to recover between points.

‚Äç

3. Injury Prevention
Building muscle strength and improving joint stability reduces strain on knees, shoulders, and elbows, which are three of the most common pickleball injury zones.

‚Äç

4. Better Endurance
Strength work supports cardiovascular fitness and keeps you feeling fresh deep into long rallies and multi-match days.

‚Äç

‚Äç

How GRAVL Fits In

‚Äç

DUPR has teamed up with GRAVL to help players train smarter, not harder. GRAVL creates AI-powered, personalized workout plans that you can use to improve your physique and overall pickleball performance.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Whether you‚Äôre brand new to strength training or already lifting, you can use GRAVL to adjust your plan to match your skill level, fitness goals, and schedule, keeping you accountable along the way.

‚Äç

Here‚Äôs what you get with GRAVL:

‚Äç

Personalized Programs: Every workout is tailored to your needs and updated as you progress.


Coach Support: Message in-app anytime for training or app guidance.


Performance Tracking: See your progress and how it impacts your game.

‚Äç



‚Äç

Exclusive for DUPR Players: Your First Month Free

‚Äç

We‚Äôre giving all DUPR players one month free using the code: DUPR.

‚Äç

And if you have DUPR+, you get 2 months free!

‚Äç

üì≤ Get the GRAVL app and start building the strength, balance, and endurance you need to dominate the court, now and for years to come.

‚Äç

title: World #1 Reveals the Only Return Tip You‚Äôll Ever Need
summary: Learn World #1 Federico Staksrud‚Äôs top tip for returning like a pro: depth over speed to control rallies and boost your pickleball ratings.
content:
You‚Äôve been dinking back and forth, patiently waiting for the perfect ball. Then boom.. you flick it past your opponent before they even know what hit them. That‚Äôs the magic of the flick shot in pickleball.

‚Äç

It‚Äôs fast.

‚Äç
It‚Äôs sneaky.

‚Äç
And when you hit it right, it can completely flip a rally in your favor.

‚Äç

Whether you‚Äôre chasing a higher DUPR rating or just want to add some spice to your game, the flick is one of those ‚Äúmust-have‚Äù shots for competitive and rec play alike.

‚Äç

Let‚Äôs break it down.

‚Äç

What‚Äôs a Flick in Pickleball?

‚Äç

Think of a flick as a surprise attack from right up at the kitchen line. You‚Äôre in a soft dink rally, looking all calm and controlled‚Ä¶ then suddenly, with a quick low-to-high wrist snap, you send the ball speeding past your opponent.

‚Äç

It works because they‚Äôre expecting another soft shot, not a sudden burst of pace. Even better, you can use it to attack balls below net height (something most players won‚Äôt see coming).

‚Äç

Pro Player Bobbi Oshiro Hitting a Backhand Flick Shot

‚Äç

When to Use the Flick Shot

‚Äç

The flick isn‚Äôt something you blast out every other ball. It works best when it‚Äôs unexpected. Here‚Äôs when to pull it out:

‚Äç

You‚Äôre locked in a slow dink rally at the net and want to change gears.


Your opponent is creeping in and getting a little too comfortable.


You see an open space and want to catch them flat-footed.



Pro tip: The more patient you are before you flick, the more likely you are to land the point.

‚Äç

How to Hit a Flick in Pickleball - Tips by Pro Player Bobbi Oshiro

‚Äç

Start in a strong, balanced stance
Stay low, knees bent, paddle out front, feet wide. This keeps you ready for anything, flick or dink.


Use a continental grip
Same grip you‚Äôd use for a backhand; it keeps your shot looking identical to a dink until the last second.


Go low-to-high
Keep your paddle down, elbow up, and lift through the ball. This motion sets up your speed and spin.


Snap the wrist at the last moment
This is the secret sauce. That quick snap is what makes the ball jump off your paddle faster than your opponent expects. Think of the motion as throwing a frisbee.¬†

‚Äç

‚Äç

Common Flick Fails (and How to Avoid Them)

‚Äç

Bad timing: Don‚Äôt flick every ball. Wait for one that‚Äôs attackable and when you‚Äôve got space to hit into.


Too much heat : Yes, it‚Äôs tempting to rip it, but if you overhit, you‚Äôll send it long or straight into the net.


Kitchen foot faults: No volleying stepping into the kitchen. Rules are rules.
Too much follow-through or overextending after the shot: Players tend to follow through too much after hitting the shot. Keep the swing quick and short so you are ready for the counter by your opponents.



‚Äç

Think you know the pickleball rules? Read this article and see if you‚Äôre one of the 90% of players getting these wrong.

‚Äç

Why You Should Add It to Your Game

‚Äç

The flick isn‚Äôt just a ‚Äúcool trick shot.‚Äù It‚Äôs a legit strategy tool that:

‚Äç

Forces errors from your opponents.

Makes you unpredictable in dink rallies.

Helps you take control of a point on your terms.
Takes time away from your opponents by hitting the ball early and out of the air.



So whether you‚Äôre grinding for a higher pickleball rating, chasing your next tournament win, or just looking to dominate those tight net battles, the flick is worth the reps.

‚Äç

Next time you‚Äôre on the court, set up some dink rallies with a buddy and practice sneaking in that flick. Use it sparingly, disguise it well, and watch your opponents start questioning every shot you take.

‚Äç

Want more ways to sharpen your game? Check out Bobbi Oshiro‚Äôs singles drills blog for inspiration.

‚Äç

title: Former Collegiate Champ Upsets Tyson McGuffin on Home Turf at PPA Bristol
summary: David Bieger, a former collegiate pickleball champ from UVA, upsets Tyson McGuffin at PPA Bristol, highlighting DUPR‚Äôs path from college to the pro level.
content:
Improve Your Return: Tips By World #1 Federico Staksrud

‚Äç

In pickleball, the double bounce rule gives returners a built-in advantage. The serving team must let your return bounce, which means you have a perfect opportunity to set the tone for the rally.

‚Äç

Pros have shared serving tips to minimize that edge, but when you are returning, choosing where and how you place the ball can make all the difference. A smart return can put you or your team on offense immediately.

‚Äç

Why Depth Beats Speed

‚Äç

Many players think a hard, low return is best, but that‚Äôs not always the case. Because the serving team must wait for the bounce, your priority should be pushing them back. A deep return:

‚Äç

Gives you more time to get to the kitchen line.


Forces opponents to hit their third shot from farther back.


Reduces their ability to hit sharp angles.



In short: depth over speed.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Staksrud‚Äôs Pro Perspective

‚Äç

Here‚Äôs how World #1 Federico Staksrud approaches his returns:

‚Äç

‚ÄúFor the return, I focus on depth and pace, usually targeting the middle to limit angles and set up my next shot.‚Äù

‚Äç

By aiming deep to the middle, you:

‚Äç

Force opponents into awkward positioning.


Take away the sidelines and angles.


Give your partner time to move forward with you.

‚Äç

How to Hit Deep, Effective Returns

‚Äç

Hitting deep consistently takes more than just swinging harder. Here are a few tips:

‚Äç

Loosen Your Grip:¬† A softer grip helps control depth without overhitting.


Aim Higher Over the Net: More clearance ensures the ball lands deep instead of into the net.


Use Your Legs: Bend and push through the shot for added lift and control.


Target the Middle: Limits angles and forces confusion between opponents.


Follow Your Shot In: Use the extra time you‚Äôve created to get to the kitchen line.


The Takeaway

‚Äç

Depth + smart placement = control of the rally.


By focusing on deep returns to the middle, you limit your opponents‚Äô options and set up your team for success. As former collegiate pickleball player David Bieger.said after beating Tyson McGuffin at the PPA Event, ‚Äúmake them beat you, don‚Äôt give them freebies.‚Äù

‚Äç

Curious how Bieber took down McGuffin? Read this article to find out.

‚Äç

To stay up to date on pickleball tips to improve your game and pickleball ratings, follow @duprpb on Instagram!

title: The Real Story of How Pickleball Started 60 Years Ago
summary: Discover the real story of how pickleball started. Learn how three dads, a handmade paddle, and a simple idea grew into the world‚Äôs fastest-growing sport.
content:
The wait is over. Registration for the 2025 MiLP National Championship is officially open!¬†

‚Äç

Dream Ticket teams can now lock in their spot to battle for a massive $100,000 prize purse. Plus, the first wave of National Leaderboard qualifiers (top players nationwide) will start receiving invitations by mid-August to form their championship teams.

‚Äç

And this year, it‚Äôs bigger than ever. Every skill level from DUPR 12 to DUPR 22, plus all ages from Open to 50+ divisions, will be competing for prize money. Even v3 teams have a chance to grab a piece of the prize pool.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Who Can Register and When?

‚Äç

Here‚Äôs how registration breaks down:

‚Äç

Dream Ticket Earners: Registration opens August 8th (private link provided to winners).


DUPR 22 & DUPR 20 50+ Teams:¬† Registration opens August 8th. Register here.


National Leaderboard Qualifiers: The first wave of invitations goes out around August 20th following leaderboard updates.


v3 Teams: Eligible players can register starting August 20th (for those who have competed in a v3 or v4 MiLP event).


MLP Teams: Can officially register their MiLP teams starting August 8th.

‚Äç



‚Äç

How the National Leaderboard Qualification Works

‚Äç

We use a rolling registration system to give rising talent a shot at Nationals:

‚Äç

Wave 1: Top leaderboard players in August receive invites first.


Wave 2: Top leaderboard players in September receive invites next.


Wave 3:Top leaderboard players in October receive invites next.


Wave 4: Top leaderboard players in November receive the final wave to Nationals.



This system ensures new talent who climb the leaderboard can still secure a spot while registration remains open.

‚Äç

Want to Guarantee Your Team Spot at Nationals? Earn a Dream Ticket!

‚Äç

The easiest way to lock in your place at Nationals is to win your division at one of these events:

‚Äç

State Championships ‚Äì Winners earn a Dream Ticket + points toward the National Leaderboard.


Regional Showdowns ‚Äì Winners earn a Dream Ticket +¬† DOUBLE points towards the National Leaderboard.
‚Äç

‚Äç


‚Äç

Uniform & Costume Contests

‚Äç

Uniform Contest

‚Äç

Earn $1,000 for winning the uniform contest at Nationals, which celebrates professionalism, team cohesion, and adherence to a unified standard, much like what you‚Äôd see from professional sports teams. Judges will evaluate based on uniformity, polish, and overall professional team look.

‚Äç

Costume Contest

‚Äç

Earn $1,000 for winning the costume contest at Nationals. Creativity and personality take center stage. Whether it‚Äôs bold colors, quirky accessories, or full-on themed looks, this is your chance to stand out and show team spirit. Matching pieces are optional, but team creativity is a must.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Everything You Need to Know

‚Äç

For even more details, including FAQs, visit our National Championship Extended FAQ.

‚Äç

Your Shot at $100K Starts Now

‚Äç

Registration is live. The leaderboard is moving. The Dream Ticket events are still in play. This is your moment. Make it count.

‚Äç

title: 2025-26 Collegiate Pickleball Tour Schedule Release
summary: Explore the full 2025-26 Collegiate Pickleball Tour schedule, presented by adidas. See key dates, host locations, new sponsors, scholarship details, and how to qualify for Nationals.
content:
Pickleball may be America‚Äôs fastest-growing sport today, but its beginnings were far more humble, and we‚Äôve got the story straight from someone who witnessed it. In an exclusive interview with DUPR, Ruth Rosenquist, board member of the Global Pickleball Federation and longtime friend of Barney McCallum (one of the sport‚Äôs original creators), shared how it all began.

‚Äç

The sport wasn‚Äôt born in stadiums or clubs, but on a simple driveway in Bainbridge Island, Washington. In 1965, three dads named Joel Pritchard, Bob Bell, and Barney McCallum were trying to do what so many parents did before them:¬† keep their kids entertained. They grabbed some equipment, marked up a court on their driveway, and made up a new game on the spot. What began as a quick backyard activity would eventually become a global phenomenon.

‚Äç

Why Is It Called ‚ÄúPickleball‚Äù?

‚Äç

For decades, the story circulated that the game was named after the Pritchard family dog, ‚ÄúPickles.‚Äù While fun, that story isn‚Äôt quite true. Pickles the dog wasn‚Äôt even born when the game was invented.¬†

‚Äç

"The actual inspiration came from the term ‚Äòpickle boat,‚Äô which is a rowing crew made up of leftover oarsmen from other boats," Ruth explained. "One of the inventors‚Äô wives said the sport was similar, pulling pieces from other games like tennis, badminton, and ping pong, and combining them into something new. And just like that, pickleball was born."

‚Äç

Building the Game, One Paddle at a Time

‚Äç

Barney McCallum, one of the original trio, was a builder at heart. He went into his woodshop and built the first pickleball paddle by hand, helping the sport establish its unique playing style from day one. McCallum even created key features of the game we still use today, like the no-volley zone (the ‚Äúkitchen‚Äù), ensuring rallies stayed fun and accessible for players of all ages.

‚Äç

From Driveway Hobby to National Obsession

‚Äç

For decades, pickleball grew quietly, mostly spread by word-of-mouth among friends and neighbors. Players built their own courts and found whatever paddles they could get their hands on. In the early 1990s, people like Ruth were traveling 30 miles just to find a place to play.

‚Äç

Source: DUPR

‚Äç

By 2013, Ruth was pushing hard to get the sport into the national spotlight. One of her early wins was convincing NBC Nightly News to run its first-ever pickleball story, coining the now-famous label: ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs Fastest Growing Sport.‚Äù

‚Äç

A Moment of Laughter and a Glimpse of the Future

‚Äç

Ruth recalled a conversation with Barney McCallum, who laughed for five minutes straight when she suggested pickleball could one day make money. At the time, it was hard to imagine pickleball being anything more than a niche backyard pastime. But today, it‚Äôs an industry worth hundreds of millions of dollars, with professional tours, major brand sponsorships, and global reach.¬†

‚Äç

A new report from Market.us (April 2025) projects the global pickleball market to reach USD 9.1 billion by 2034, up from USD 2.2 billion in 2024. This reflects a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 15.3% from 2025 to 2034, underscoring the sport‚Äôs accelerating popularity and expanding economic impact worldwide.

‚Äç

60 Years Later: A Global Sport

‚Äç

What started with three dads, some bored kids, and a handmade paddle is now a worldwide movement made up of both amateur and professional players. There are DUPR players in over 160 countries, with pickleball being on track to seek recognition by the International Olympic Committee. Pickleball is breaking barriers, connecting people of all ages, and, as Ruth says, ‚Äúbringing joy to people‚Äôs lives everywhere it goes.‚Äù

‚Äç

This year marks Pickleball‚Äôs 60th anniversary, a milestone worth celebrating, not just for how far it‚Äôs come, but for the spirit in which it started: simple, inclusive, and focused on fun.

‚Äç

Interested in learning more about the sport and how to raise your pickleball ratings? Don‚Äôt miss our blog on the pickleball rules 90% of players get wrong; it might change how you play.

‚Äç

title: Introducing the 2025 Collegiate Tailgate Tour: Pickleball Pros, Music & More
summary: The 2025 Collegiate Tailgate Tour brings pickleball pros, live music, and campus energy to college game days nationwide, featuring exhibition matches, DUPR rating sessions, and exclusive post-game concerts.
content:
The 2025-26 collegiate pickleball season is here, and it‚Äôs bigger than ever. DUPR and the UPA are proud to kick off the fifth year of the Collegiate Pickleball Tour with our biggest announcement yet: Adidas has been named the Presenting Sponsor of the Collegiate Pickleball Tour, marking a major milestone in the sport‚Äôs evolution on campuses across the country.

‚Äç

Keep reading to explore the full 2025-26 season lineup, including key dates, host locations, Adidas‚Äôs involvement as Presenting Sponsor, additional sponsors, and everything you need to get your team ready to compete at the highest level.

‚Äç

Fall Semester Events

‚Äç

Utah Super Regional at The Picklr Kaysville

September 27th-28th

‚Äç

Pennsylvania Super Regional at Dill Dinkers Hatboro

October 11th-12th

‚Äç

North Carolina Super Regional at City of Wilson Pickleball Facility

October 18th-19th

‚Äç

Collegiate World Championship at Brookhaven Country Club

October 31st-November 2nd

‚Äç

Arizona Super Regional at Arizona Athletic Grounds

November 22nd-23rd

Spring Semester Events

‚Äç

Virginia Super Regional at Performance Pickleball RVA

February 14th-15th

‚Äç

February 21st-22nd

‚Äç

California Super Regional at The Hub Silicon Valley

March 7th-8th

‚Äç

Georgia Super Regional at Atlanta National Pickleball Club

March 28th-29th

‚Äç

2026 Collegiate National Championship

TBD

‚Äç

Adidas ‚Äì The Official Sponsor of the Collegiate Pickleball Tour

Our Partnership with adidas brings one of the most iconic brands in the sport to the heart of collegiate pickleball. As presenting sponsor of the tour, adidas will play a central role in elevating the athlete experience across all events. With a focus on performance, innovation, and community, adidas will activate on-site and support players with best-in-class products.¬†¬†

‚Äç

Vulcan ‚Äì¬† The Official Ball of DUPR

This new partnership sets a standard across the sport with Vulcan‚Äôs V-PRO FLIGHT technology regarded as best-in-class, delivering elite performance, durability, and accuracy. The Vulcan V-PRO FLIGHT ball will be used across all Collegiate Pickleball Tour events.¬†

‚Äç

If you are a college club - use this link to purchase Vulcan balls.

‚Äç

Osaka ‚Äì¬† The Official Apparel Sponsor of Collegiate Pickleball

Osaka delivers designs that elevate both a player's game and lifestyle. Globally recognized for its impact in padel and field hockey, the brand entered the pickleball sphere with apparel built for versatility, functionality, and durability, crafted for performance and everyday wear.¬†

‚Äç

Six Zero ‚Äì¬† Official Partner Of Collegiate Pickleball

Six Zero brings elite paddle technology to the nation‚Äôs Collegiate Pickleball Tour. Known for pushing the boundaries of performance and design, Six Zero will provide collegiate athletes with access to high-quality paddles engineered for speed, precision, and control. Their commitment to innovation makes them the perfect partner.

‚Äç

Reign Storm ‚Äì¬† The Official Energy Partner of DUPR and Collegiate Pickleball

Reign Storm offers clean, plant-based energy to players and fans at every stop of the Collegiate Pickleball Tour. Designed to support high-performance lifestyles, Reign Storm is a natural fit for collegiate pickleball‚Äôs fast-paced and competitive environment. With on-site activations, product sampling, and fan engagement throughout the season, Reign Storm is here to fuel the next generation of college athletes, on and off the court.

‚Äç

Scholarship Money

To date, the Collegiate Pickleball Tour has given out over $300,000 at all of our past events, and we look forward to continuing that tradition in the 2025-26 season.

2026 Collegiate National Championship - $42,500+ given out
Collegiate World Championship - $10,000+ given out
Super Regionals - $6,000+ given out at each
Total - $100,000+ given out in the 2025-26 season

‚Äç

Bids

There will be 64 bids given out for the 2026 Collegiate National Championship. A bid allows your school to bring a team to compete for the championship in the 1st Team Bracket at Nationals, as well as bring another team for the 2nd Team Bracket. Only 1 bid per school. If your school does not have a bid, you can still compete in the Challenger Brackets at Nationals and the 3rd Team Bracket. Here are how the bids will be distributed:

Collegiate World Championship - 6 bids for the best USA teams
Super Regionals - 3 bids each (24 bids total)
Campus Regionals - 1 bid each (30 bids total)
Dual Matches - 2 bids awarded to the teams with the most Dual Match wins
Wildcard Bids - 2 bids for teams selected by the CPT committee

‚Äç

Eligibility Changes

Starting in the 2025‚Äì26 season, we‚Äôre adjusting the credit hour requirements for undergraduate players to better reflect the evolving level of competition. Our goal is to ensure student-athletes are maintaining academic commitments while still representing their schools with pride. These credit hours must be taken in the same semester as the collegiate tournament you are playing in. Here are the requirements:

Undergraduate Students - 9 credit hours (¬æ full time)
Graduate Students - 6 credit hours (¬Ω full time)
Graduating Seniors - Below minimums allowed for the final semester

‚Äç

As always, you must be partnered with other players from your same school for Collegiate Pickleball Tour events.

‚Äç

Campus Regionals

Campus Regionals continue to be a critical part of the Collegiate Pickleball Tour, helping new and returning schools compete for a shot at Nationals. In 2024, we hosted 16 Regionals, and in 2025 we hosted 14 - even with a shortened season.

‚Äç

In 2025‚Äì26, we‚Äôre dedicating 30 of the 64 total Nationals bids to Campus Regionals - aiming for 15 Campus Regionals each semester! These tournaments will follow the Collegiate Pickleball Tour Format, creating a clear and unified path to the Collegiate National Championship.

‚Äç

Want to host a Campus Regional? Click here to learn more.

‚Äç

Collegiate Council

We want to make sure that we continue to foster open communication and collaboration with our player base, and so we organize a Collegiate Council that is made up of leaders and players from each region of collegiate pickleball. The Collegiate Council and the Collegiate Pickleball Tour Team will meet regularly to discuss feedback on previous events, the steps that CPT is taking to grow the sport, and your input on what we can do to increase each player‚Äôs experience. If you are interested in lending your experience to help us grow collegiate pickleball, you may apply here for the 2025 fall semester group.

‚Äç

The tour will feature five events across the country, including the Collegiate component at the Pickleball World Championships, and is expected to engage more than 4,000 players from over 125 colleges, with additional high school tie-in events to help grow the game at the grassroots level.¬†

title: How to Lose Weight Playing Pickleball | Tip 6: Reverse Dieting
summary: Hit your weight loss goal playing pickleball? Learn how reverse dieting helps you keep it off, restore your metabolism, and maintain performance on the court.
content:
Pickleball rules and scoring differ from other racket sports like tennis, badminton or padel. Traditionally, points could only be earned by the serving team, making strategy and patience critical. But as the sport grows, rally scoring has gained popularity for its faster pace and simpler structure.

‚Äç

So, what‚Äôs the difference? And how does it affect DUPR ratings? Let‚Äôs break it down.

‚Äç

Traditional Scoring: The Original Pickleball Formula

‚Äç

In traditional pickleball scoring for doubles:

‚Äç

Only the serving team scores points.


The receiving team can win the rally but only earns the right to force the ball to the second server or get the ball back to serve next.


Both players on the serving team get an opportunity to serve before a sideout occurs.


The score is announced with three numbers (e.g., 7-5-1): serving team‚Äôs score, receiving team‚Äôs score, and whether it‚Äôs the first or second server.


Partners rotate sides only if they score a point while serving.



Games are typically played to 11 points, win by 2. To learn more about serving rules in pickleball, check out this blog.¬†

‚Äç

Rally Scoring: Speeding the Game

‚Äç

Rally scoring changes one key rule: a point is awarded on every rally, regardless of who served.

‚Äç

Scoring is simplified to two numbers (e.g., 7-6), making it easier for new players and spectators to follow.


Players stay on their designated sides instead of rotating based on points won.


Matches typically play to 21 points, still win by 2, to balance the faster pace.


How Does Rally Scoring Affect Your DUPR Rating?

‚Äç

DUPR‚Äôs algorithm factors in rally scoring. Because rally scoring matches tend to be tighter, the favorite‚Äôs expected point percentage is slightly lower compared to traditional scoring. DUPR‚Äôs predictions and post-match updates are based on real data from both formats, so whether you play traditional or rally scoring, your DUPR rating remains fair and accurate.

‚Äç

To learn more about DUPR‚Äôs algorithm, check out DUPR‚Äôs How It Works Page.¬†

‚Äç

Bottom Line

‚Äç

Both scoring systems bring unique elements to the game:

‚Äç

Traditional scoring rewards patience, holding serve, and strategic sideouts.


Rally scoring increases pace, simplifies scoring, and speeds up the game.



Which one do you prefer? Either way, DUPR‚Äôs rating system adjusts for both.

title: How to Lose Weight Playing Pickleball | Tip 5: Sleep
summary: Sleep impacts weight loss and pickleball performance more than you think. Get science-backed tips to improve rest, recovery, and fat-burning results.
content:
The Pickleball Player's Science-Based Guide to Sustainable Weight Loss

‚Äç

You‚Äôve put in the work, dialed in your nutrition, built muscle, improved your conditioning, and maybe even hit your weight loss goal while playing the sport you love. But here‚Äôs the truth: losing the weight is only half the battle; keeping it off is the real challenge.

‚Äç

This is where reverse dieting comes in. By gradually increasing calories back to maintenance instead of jumping straight into your old eating habits, you can protect your results, rebuild your metabolism, and avoid regaining the weight you worked so hard to lose.

‚Äç

In this guide, we‚Äôll break down exactly how reverse dieting works, why it‚Äôs so effective, and how to transition from fat loss to long-term maintenance, without sacrificing your pickleball performance or your lifestyle.

‚Äç

Reverse Dieting: Protecting Your Results

‚Äç

Once you achieve your fat loss goal, the work isn't over. Reverse dieting‚Äîgradually increasing calories back to maintenance level‚Äîprevents weight regain.

‚Äç

Why Reverse Dieting Works

‚Äç

Extended calorie restriction leads to metabolic adaptation, where your body becomes more efficient and burns fewer calories. Reverse dieting helps restore metabolic rate while maintaining your new body composition.

‚Äç

The Process
Increase calories gradually: Add 50-100 calories per week
Monitor weight and measurements: Allow 1-2 weeks between increases
Prioritize protein: Maintain high protein intake throughout
Resume maintenance: Reach your new maintenance level over 4-8 weeks

‚Äç

Action Step: Plan your reverse diet before you finish your fat loss phase, and be patient with the process.

‚Äç

Building a Sustainable Mindset

‚Äç

The most sophisticated nutrition and training plan fails without the right mindset. Sustainable weight loss requires shifting from a diet mentality to a lifestyle approach.

‚Äç

Key Mindset Shifts

‚Äç

From Perfection to Progress:

Expect setbacks and plan for them
Focus on consistency over perfection
Celebrate small victories along the way

‚Äç

From Restriction to Flexibility:

Include foods you enjoy in moderation
Adapt your plan around social events and travel
Avoid labeling foods as "good" or "bad"

‚Äç

From Short-term to Long-term:

Make decisions based on what you can sustain for years
Focus on building habits, not just losing weight
Consider how your choices affect your pickleball performance

‚Äç

Practical Implementation

‚Äç

Weekly Planning:

Prep meals and snacks around your match schedule
Plan for challenging situations (restaurants, social events)
Schedule training sessions as non-negotiable appointments

‚Äç

Progress Tracking:

Use multiple metrics (weight, measurements, photos, performance)
Keep a simple food and activity journal
Regular check-ins with yourself or a coach

‚Äç

Recovery from Setbacks:

Get back on track with your very next meal
Don't let one bad day become a bad week
Learn from challenges to improve your plan

‚Äç

Your Personalized Game Plan

‚Äç

Here‚Äôs your simplified roadmap:

‚Äç

Focus on body composition
Create a slight calorie deficit.
Eat plenty of protein.
Move more‚Äîon and off the court.
Strength train at least twice a week.
Prioritize sleep like you prioritize practice.
Reverse diet to maintain results.
Stay consistent and flexible.

‚Äç

Ready to Optimize Your Training and Recovery for Better Results?

‚Äç

The science is clear: sustainable weight loss comes from consistent exercise, quality sleep, and smart recovery. While nutrition drives fat loss, having the right training and recovery plan makes all the difference in maintaining muscle, improving performance, and staying consistent.

‚Äç

Download the AIM7 app today and get the personalized support you need to:

‚úì Track your pickleball sessions and strength training workouts automatically
‚úì Monitor your sleep quality and get insights to improve your recovery
‚úì Access personalized warmups designed for your body and training needs
‚úì Follow custom strength plans to preserve muscle while losing fat
‚úì Get targeted mobility and cooldown routines to enhance recovery and prevent injury
‚úì Receive daily recommendations tailored to your readiness and goals

‚Äç

Your body composition goals require more than just good intentions‚Äîthey need a systematic approach to training and recovery that adapts to your unique needs.

Download AIM7 and get started for FREE on iOS

‚Äç

Final Thoughts: A Sustainable Approach to Health and Performance

‚Äç

This isn't about achieving a perfect body or following a perfect diet. It's about creating a sustainable approach that enhances your health, improves your pickleball performance, and fits into your life in the long term.

‚Äç

Remember that sustainable change takes time. Focus on building habits you can maintain for years, not just weeks. Your body is your most important piece of equipment, both on and off the court‚Äîtreat it with the respect and consistency it deserves.

‚Äç

With patience, consistency, and the right approach, you can lose fat, maintain your results, and enjoy every moment of your pickleball journey. The goal isn't to diet forever‚Äîit's to create a lifestyle that supports your health, performance, and love of the game for years to come.

‚Äç

Medical Disclaimer

The information provided in this blog is for educational and informational purposes only and is not intended as medical advice. This content should not be used to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any health condition or disease.

Before beginning any weight loss program, exercise routine, or making significant changes to your diet, please consult with a qualified healthcare professional, especially if you have any pre-existing medical conditions, are taking medications, or have concerns about your health.

Individual results may vary. The strategies and recommendations discussed in this blog may not be suitable for everyone. Always listen to your body and discontinue any activity that causes pain or discomfort.

AIM7 and its affiliates are not responsible for any adverse effects or consequences resulting from the use of the information or suggestions contained in this blog. By reading this content, you acknowledge that you are participating in these activities at your own risk.

title: How to Lose Weight Playing Pickleball | Tip 3: Prioritize Protein Intake
summary: Discover why protein is key for weight loss and pickleball performance. Learn how much to eat, the best sources, and how to fuel your recovery.
content:
The Pickleball Player's Science-Based Guide to Sustainable Weight Loss

‚Äç

You‚Äôve dialed in your focus on body composition, you're eating in a slight calorie deficit, and protein is on point. Now it‚Äôs time to unlock one of the most overlooked fat-loss accelerators: daily movement.

‚Äç

Pickleball is already doing a lot of the heavy lifting. It‚Äôs a powerful way to burn calories, build coordination, and stay consistent with exercise. But if fat loss is the goal, pairing your court time with intentional movement throughout the day can seriously level up your results (and pickleball ratings) and overall health.¬†

‚Äç

Whether it‚Äôs walking after meals, taking the stairs, or hitting a quick strength session, these small moves add up,¬† boosting your metabolism, improving recovery, and keeping your body in fat-burning mode between matches.

‚Äç

The Power of Daily Steps

‚Äç

Non-exercise activity thermogenesis (NEAT) can account for 15-30% of your daily calorie burn. Walking is the most accessible way to increase NEAT.

‚Äç

Benefits of increasing your step count:

7,000+ daily steps reduce all-cause mortality risk
Each additional 1,000 steps burns approximately 40-50 calories
Walking after meals improves glucose metabolism

‚Äç

Practical Strategies:

Take a 10-15 minute walk after meals
Use walking meetings or phone calls
Park farther away or take stairs
Set a weekly goal of 49,000+ steps (7,000 √ó 7 days)

‚Äç

Resistance Training: Your Metabolic Advantage

‚Äç

Strength training is non-negotiable during fat loss. Strength training helps preserve muscle, boost metabolism, and enhance body composition. It‚Äôs essential during weight loss to prevent muscle loss.

‚Äç

Minimum Effective Dose:

2-3 full-body sessions per week
6-12 sets per muscle group weekly
Focus on compound movements (squats, deadlifts, presses, rows)
Progressive overload to continually challenge muscles

‚Äç

Pickleball-Specific Benefits:

Improved power and stability
Potential injury prevention
Enhanced court reactivity and agility

‚Äç

‚Äç

Looking for a personalized strength training plan? DUPR players get 1 month FREE on GRAVL, an AI-powered platform that creates workouts tailored to your goals. Check it out here.

‚Äç

Cardiovascular Training Strategy

‚Äç

Beyond pickleball, additional cardio supports heart health, endurance, and fat loss.

‚Äç

Guidelines:

150 minutes moderate intensity OR 75 minutes vigorous per week
Pickleball sessions count toward this total
Add 1-2 HIIT sessions weekly for time efficiency
Include low-intensity activities like walking or swimming

‚Äç

Action Step: Schedule your training sessions like important appointments, and track your activities to ensure consistency.

‚Äç

Download the AIM7 app to calculate your needs and monitor your progress.¬†

‚Äç

You already know most of the information¬†you need to lose any extra weight that‚Äôs affecting your performance. However, there is one tip that‚Äôs super essential, and most people overlook.¬†

‚Äç

Check out our Weight Loss Tip #5 on Sleep.¬†

‚Äç

Medical Disclaimer

The information provided in this blog is for educational and informational purposes only and is not intended as medical advice. This content should not be used to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any health condition or disease.

Before beginning any weight loss program, exercise routine, or making significant changes to your diet, please consult with a qualified healthcare professional, especially if you have any pre-existing medical conditions, are taking medications, or have concerns about your health.

title: How to Lose Weight Playing Pickleball | Tip 2: Creating a Sustainable Calorie Deficit
summary: Learn how to create a sustainable calorie deficit for weight loss while playing pickleball. Lose weight without starving or sacrificing performance.
content:
The Pickleball Player's Science-Based Guide to Sustainable Weight Loss

‚Äç

If you‚Äôre trying to lose fat without losing your power on the pickleball court, protein is your secret weapon. It‚Äôs not just for bodybuilders; it‚Äôs essential for anyone who wants to get leaner, stronger, and recover faster after long matches or intense training sessions.

‚Äç

In Tip #1, we talked about focusing on body composition instead of just the number on the scale. Now it‚Äôs time to talk about what you‚Äôre eating, starting with protein.

‚Äç

Why? Because when you‚Äôre in a calorie deficit, your body isn‚Äôt just losing fat ; it can also start breaking down muscle. That‚Äôs where protein steps in: it helps preserve your lean muscle, keeps you full longer, and even burns more calories during digestion.

‚Äç

In this post, we‚Äôll break down exactly how much protein you need, when to eat it, the best sources (yes, plant-based too!), and how to balance it with carbs and fats for max pickleball performance.

‚Äç

Let‚Äôs dive in.

‚Äç

Prioritizing Protein for Performance and Fat Loss

‚Äç

Protein serves multiple crucial functions during fat loss that extend far beyond muscle building:

‚Äç

The Science Behind Protein's Power

‚Äç

Thermic Effect: Protein requires 20-30% of its calories to digest, compared to 5-10% for carbs and 0-5% for fats
Satiety: High-protein meals increase fullness hormones (GLP-1, PYY) while reducing the hunger hormone (ghrelin)
Muscle Preservation: Adequate protein intake maintains lean mass during calorie restriction
Recovery: Supports tissue repair after intense pickleball sessions

‚Äç

Optimal Protein Intake

‚Äç

Between 1.6 and 2.2 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight is recommended daily for active individuals in a calorie deficit. For a 70kg (154lb) player, this translates to 110-155 grams per day.

‚Äç

High-Quality Sources:

Lean meats (chicken, turkey, lean beef)
Fish and seafood
Eggs and egg whites
Dairy products (Greek yogurt, cottage cheese)
Plant-based options (tofu, tempeh, legumes, protein powders)

‚Äç

Timing Strategy: Distribute protein throughout the day, aiming for 25-30 grams per meal to support muscle protein synthesis.

‚Äç

Action Step: Plan each meal around a protein source first, then add carbohydrates and fats to complete the nutritional profile.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Balancing Carbohydrates and Fats for Performance

‚Äç

Contrary to popular diet trends, you don't need to eliminate entire macronutrient groups to lose fat effectively. Your body thrives on balanced nutrition that supports both fat loss and athletic performance.

‚Äç

Carbohydrates: Your Performance Fuel

‚Äç

Carbohydrates are your muscles' preferred energy source, especially during high-intensity pickleball rallies. The key is choosing quality sources and timing intake appropriately.

‚Äç

Best Choices:

Whole grains (oats, quinoa, brown rice)
Fruits (especially berries, apples, bananas)
Starchy vegetables (sweet potatoes, squash)
Legumes (beans, lentils, chickpeas)

‚Äç

Timing Tip: Consume carbohydrates around your training sessions to fuel performance and support recovery.

‚Äç

Healthy Fats: Essential for Hormones and Health

‚Äç

Dietary fat supports hormone production, nutrient absorption, and joint health‚Äîall crucial for pickleball players.

‚Äç

Quality Sources:

Avocados and olives
Nuts and seeds
Olive oil and avocado oil
Fatty fish (salmon, mackerel, sardines)

‚Äç

General Guidelines:

20-35% of total calories from fat
Emphasize monounsaturated and omega-3 fatty acids
Limit processed and trans fats

‚Äç

Action Step: Initially, use a food tracking app to understand your macronutrient balance, then transition to intuitive eating as you develop better habits.

‚Äç

It's time to boost your pickleball ratings! Want help measuring your protein intake? Download the AIM7 app to calculate your needs and monitor your progress.¬†

‚Äç

Check out Weight Loss Tip #4: Maximizing Movement.¬†

‚Äç

Medical Disclaimer

The information provided in this blog is for educational and informational purposes only and is not intended as medical advice. This content should not be used to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any health condition or disease.

Before beginning any weight loss program, exercise routine, or making significant changes to your diet, please consult with a qualified healthcare professional, especially if you have any pre-existing medical conditions, are taking medications, or have concerns about your health.

Individual results may vary. The strategies and recommendations discussed in this blog may not be suitable for everyone. Always listen to your body and discontinue any activity that causes pain or discomfort.

title: How to Lose Weight Playing Pickleball | Tip 1: Focus on Body Composition
summary: Want to get leaner and faster on the court? Discover why scale weight doesn‚Äôt tell the whole story. In this first tip of our science-based weight loss guide for pickleball players, learn how to shift your focus to body composition for lasting results.
content:
The Pickleball Player's Science-Based Guide to Sustainable Weight Loss

‚Äç

Pickleball is one of the most enjoyable and effective ways to stay active; but if your goal is to lose body fat, there‚Äôs one key truth you can‚Äôt ignore: playing alone isn‚Äôt enough. Without the right nutrition strategy, you might be undoing all your hard work on the court without even realizing it.

‚Äç

The good news? You don‚Äôt have to starve yourself or cut out the foods you love. You just need a sustainable calorie deficit; and we‚Äôre here to show you how to do it the right way.

‚Äç

In Tip #1, we focused on improving body composition instead of obsessing over the number on the scale. Now, it‚Äôs time to break down the balance between how many calories you‚Äôre consuming vs. how many you‚Äôre burning.

‚Äç

Creating a Sustainable Calorie Deficit

‚Äç

The fundamental principle of fat loss remains unchanged: you must burn more calories than you consume. However, the execution requires nuance and patience, not extreme restriction.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Calculate Your Needs Accurately

Use AIM7‚Äôs comprehensive weight loss calculator that factors in your age, height, current weight, body composition, and activity level (including pickleball sessions). This gives you a baseline for creating a modest deficit.

‚Äç

Target Range: Aim for 0.5 to 2 pounds of fat loss per week. This rate:

Preserves muscle mass and performance
Maintains energy for training and matches
Reduces metabolic adaptation
Increases long-term adherence

‚Äç

The Deficit Sweet Spot

‚Äç

A modest daily deficit of 300-500 calories typically produces optimal results. Larger deficits may seem appealing, but often lead to:

Muscle loss alongside fat loss
Decreased performance and recovery
Increased hunger and cravings
Higher likelihood of regaining weight

‚Äç

Action Step: Track your intake for one week without making any changes to establish your baseline, then create a modest deficit from there.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Fat loss doesn't have to mean cutting out all your favorite foods or feeling exhausted on the court. With the right numbers in place, and a little patience, you can lose fat while still performing your best in pickleball.¬†

‚Äç

Want help staying on track? Download the AIM7 app to calculate your needs, monitor your progress, and avoid guesswork.¬†

‚Äç

And if you're wondering what to eat to support this process, don‚Äôt miss Tip #3: Prioritizing Protein; it may just change the way you fuel forever.

‚Äç

Medical Disclaimer

The information provided in this blog is for educational and informational purposes only and is not intended as medical advice. This content should not be used to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any health condition or disease.

Before beginning any weight loss program, exercise routine, or making significant changes to your diet, please consult with a qualified healthcare professional, especially if you have any pre-existing medical conditions, are taking medications, or have concerns about your health.

Individual results may vary. The strategies and recommendations discussed in this blog may not be suitable for everyone. Always listen to your body and discontinue any activity that causes pain or discomfort.

AIM7 and its affiliates are not responsible for any adverse effects or consequences resulting from the use of the information or suggestions contained in this blog. By reading this content, you acknowledge that you are participating in these activities at your own risk.

title: Youth Pickleball Is Exploding in Arizona‚Äôs DUPR Club
summary: Discover how this Arizona DUPR Club is redefining youth pickleball with training, tournaments, and competitive pickleball ratings.
content:
[Delray Beach, FL.] ‚Äì [7.31.2025] ‚Äì DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating), the world's most accurate pickleball rating system, and DUPR Coach, a coaching and player development platform, today announced the launch of a new initiative to deliver accurate player ratings from video analysis using AI tools. As part of this initiative, PlaySight, the global leader in AI-driven sports video technology, becomes the first official integration partner.

‚Äç

This initiative marks a major step forward in making accurate pickleball ratings more accessible to players everywhere.

‚Äç

The core of the partnership is integrating PlaySight‚Äôs advanced AI-powered game analysis into DUPR, allowing players to receive an initial DUPR rating based on their video and evaluation by a DUPR Coach.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThis initiative is about unlocking access,‚Äù said Tito Machado, CEO of DUPR. ‚ÄúNot everyone plays in a league or tournament right away. Now, with a video of your match, you can get a trusted, data-driven rating. PlaySight is the ideal launch partner; they bring precision video capture and analytics already used by top-level athletes worldwide, and their presence in leading pickleball venues makes this a natural fit.‚Äù

‚Äç

Beyond ratings, the collaboration opens up new opportunities for content creation. PlaySight‚Äôs SmartCourts automatically produce highlight clips and full-match replays, which can now be curated and shared across DUPR‚Äôs digital channels. This makes it easier than ever for players to showcase their skills and for fans to engage with the sport.¬†

‚Äç

"We are proud to partner with DUPR, a clear leader who shares our vision for advancing pickleball through technology," said Chen Shachar, Co-Founder and CEO of PlaySight. "Our AI systems create a massive trove of performance data and video highlights every single day. This partnership provides the perfect platform to not only enhance rating accuracy but also to deliver this incredible content to millions of passionate players worldwide through DUPR's amazing community."

‚Äç

PlaySight is the first AI technology partner to integrate with DUPR, helping set a new standard for video-based ratings. As the need for AI assessment tools in pickleball grows, DUPR will support an evolving range of use cases‚Äîwhether captured on a SmartCourt, a mobile device, or other advanced tools. The goal is to make accurate ratings more accessible by opening up fresh ways for players to engage, get rated, and improve through video.

‚Äç

About DUPR

‚ÄçDUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) is the premier global pickleball rating system and technology platform, trusted by the world's leading clubs, tournaments, leagues, and players. DUPR's dynamic rating system unifies pickleball across age, gender, and location by analyzing match results to accurately evaluate all players across a 2.000 - 8.000 scale. DUPR is the official pickleball rating of leagues, tournaments and clubs around the world, including United Pickleball Association (UPA), PPA, Major League Pickleball (MLP), Pickleball.com, Life Time, The Picklr, National Team Pickleball League, National Pickleball League. It also owns and operates Minor League Pickleball and Collegiate Pickleball, two of the biggest amateur leagues in the sport. Players and operators can visit www.dupr.com to sign up and learn more.

‚Äç

About PlaySight

‚ÄçPlaySight is a pioneer in AI-driven sports technology. Its SmartCourt platform is used across more than 40 sports‚Äîincluding pickleball, tennis, padel, and basketball‚Äîproviding automated video production, live streaming, and advanced analytics. PlaySight is the official video technology partner of the PPA Tour and is installed at top pickleball facilities like Dill Dinkers, Ace Pickleball Club, and The Fort in Fort Lauderdale.

‚Äç

Media Contact:

‚ÄçKyrill Hartog
VP Marketing & Communications
kyrill@mydupr.com

title: National Junior Pickleball Launches Coach-Assigned DUPR Ratings for Junior Players
summary: National Junior Pickleball partners with MyJourney Pickleball to launch Coach-Assigned DUPR Ratings for players ages 8‚Äì18, ensuring fair, skill-based competition and player development at youth pickleball events nationwide.
content:
In Arizona, one club is proving that pickleball isn‚Äôt just an adult sport; it‚Äôs a pathway for young athletes to develop, compete, and dream big. Monster Athlete Juniors is building the next generation of pickleball players by blending high-level training, structured competition, and DUPR ratings into a program that rivals the established models of youth volleyball and soccer.

‚Äç

From its humble beginnings with just 40 kids, Monster Athlete Juniors has grown to over 200 players and is on track to hit 300 this fall. The secret? A proven structure, a commitment to player development, and a belief that kids deserve the same opportunities to excel in pickleball as they do in other sports.

‚Äç

From Volleyball to Pickleball: A Proven Model

‚Äç

Howard Vernick, founder of Monster Athlete Juniors, spent over 30 years coaching club and high school volleyball. When he moved to Arizona, one of the fastest-growing states for pickleball, he noticed a major gap: there were no structured pickleball training programs for kids, like those long established in volleyball or soccer.

‚Äç

So, he created it.

‚Äç

‚ÄúIf volleyball, soccer, and basketball have developmental pipelines, why not pickleball?‚Äù Vernick explained.

‚Äç

Initially, Monster Athlete Juniors offered both volleyball and pickleball, but the program soon focused entirely on pickleball for athletes ages 8‚Äì17. With partners and coaches experienced in both sports and a trademarked program name, Monster Athlete Juniors built a system from scratch that mirrored the proven success of club volleyball models: structured divisions, seasonal schedules, and tournament play.

‚Äç

A Division for Every Junior Player

‚Äç

The club has three core divisions:

‚Äç

Developmental:¬† Beginner players new to the game (8-week sessions).


Competitive: Intermediate players ready to commit to structured training (12-week sessions).


High Performance: Players near or above 3.5 DUPR ratings aiming for 4.0 and higher (12-week sessions).



Each team trains twice a week under dedicated coaches, with developmental teams practicing one hour per session and advanced teams training two hours. The curriculum combines singles, doubles, and even MLP-style team formats, ensuring players learn all aspects of competitive pickleball.

‚Äç

Tournaments That Build Players and Grow the Sport

‚Äç

Each 12-week season includes at least three tournaments, mixing indoor and outdoor venues, singles, doubles, and team events. These pickleball tournaments consistently draw 100+ junior competitors, a rare feat in youth pickleball.

‚Äç

And the competition isn‚Äôt limited to just members. About 30% of tournament players come from outside the club, providing Monster athletes exposure to new opponents and styles of play, and giving families an exciting look at what competitive youth pickleball can be.

‚Äç

Monster Athlete Juniors also offers ‚Äúupgrade‚Äù tournament packages for players who want to test themselves at higher levels like PPA and NJP events within driving distance of Arizona. This model provides a clear competitive pathway, something few junior programs in the country currently offer.

‚Äç

The DUPR Advantage

‚Äç

One of Monster Athlete Juniors‚Äô smartest moves was adopting DUPR ratings early.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe realized we needed a consistent way to evaluate kids,‚Äù Vernick said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not recreational; we‚Äôre competitive. DUPR gives kids a way to measure where they are and where they want to go.‚Äù

‚Äç

DUPR helps the club with:

‚Äç

Fair matchups by placing players in appropriate divisions and seeding tournaments accurately;


Recruitment by using DUPR‚Äôs search and messaging tools to find and connect with top junior talent;


Showcasing talent by highlighting players achieving 4.0+ ratings to inspire others and attract families who want serious development.



It also helps parents understand the difference between perceived skill and verified performance:

‚Äç

‚ÄúSome parents say, ‚ÄòMy kid‚Äôs a 3.5 because a coach told me so,‚Äô‚Äù Vernick explained. ‚ÄúBut DUPR gives an unbiased, data-driven rating based on actual match results. That clarity is huge for families.‚Äù

‚Äç

Partnerships and Expansion

‚Äç

Monster Athlete Juniors is already building relationships with universities like Grand Canyon University and Arizona State University, providing clinics and connecting youth players to collegiate pickleball opportunities. The program also has its eyes on charter schools, high school club programs, and long-term integration with scholastic athletics.

‚Äç

With plans to expand into Tucson, Flagstaff, California, Nevada, Utah, Texas, and even Naples, Florida, Monster Athlete Juniors is positioning itself as the national model for youth pickleball. Franchising and satellite clubs are on the horizon, bringing structure and opportunity to even more kids.

‚Äç

The Future of Youth Pickleball

‚Äç

Monster Athlete Juniors has cracked the code on how to grow youth pickleball:

Structured divisions and seasonal schedules


Frequent tournaments with verified DUPR ratings


Strong developmental and high-performance pathways



For other club directors and leaders, Monster Athlete Juniors offers a blueprint for building sustainable youth programs that keep kids engaged and push the sport forward.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre preparing kids for competition, building community, and creating future pickleball athletes,‚Äù Vernick said.

‚Äç

The result? A youth program that‚Äôs not just filling courts, but shaping the future of the sport.

‚Äç

title: Pickleball Transition Tips with Bobbi Oshiro

content:
The 8‚Äì18 age group is one of the fastest-growing segments in pickleball, with over 14,000 middle and high schools primed to support youth play and competition.

‚Äç

Las Vegas, NV - July 29, 2025 - National Junior Pickleball (NJP), the premier competitive platform for youth pickleball in the U.S., has announced a groundbreaking partnership with MyJourney Pickleball (MJP), the developer of DUPR Coach to ensure every junior player enters NJP events with a trusted and accurate rating. Through the launch of Coach-Assigned DUPR Ratings, junior athletes will now have the opportunity to be rated by credentialed DUPR Coaches via the My DUPR Coach app. This program establishes a new standard for youth-level competition and player development.

‚Äç

This initiative marks a major milestone in the evolution of junior pickleball. At the heart of NJP‚Äôs mission is the belief that every player, whether it‚Äôs their first tournament or they‚Äôre still chasing the podium, deserves to compete in a fair, skill-based environment. The Coach-Assigned DUPR Rating is a key step toward making that vision a reality.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThis partnership reflects our commitment to making sure every junior has the chance to compete against peers at their skill level, using the most trusted rating system in the sport,‚Äù said Courtney Loughridge, Founder and CEO of National Junior Pickleball. ‚ÄúWith MyJourney Pickleball and DUPR, we‚Äôre giving families a reliable way to prepare for events, grow in the sport, and connect with a larger community of junior players.‚Äù

‚Äç

Through this collaboration, MyJourney Pickleball will provide NJP players access to credentialed Master DUPR Coaches who will assess submitted film and assign Coach-Assigned DUPR Ratings through the My DUPR Coach app. This process allows non-rated players to become rated in advance of tournaments, ensuring accurate matchmaking, smoother seeding, and a more competitive, enjoyable experience for all.

‚Äç
‚ÄúThis is a major step forward for the sport of pickleball,‚Äù said Tito Machado, CEO of DUPR. ‚ÄúThe Coach-Assigned DUPR gives juniors a path to get rated before they even step into their first match. It also helps coaches guide development, parents and players track progress, and events maintain the integrity of competition.‚Äù

‚Äç

This partnership reflects a shared mission to grow the game the right way: through youth, through coaching, through community, and through DUPR.

‚Äç

‚ÄúNational Junior Pickleball is critical to the future of pickleball, representing the 8‚Äì18 age group that makes up a large and rapidly growing segment of the millions entering the sport,‚Äù said Katie Nimitz, President of MyJourney Pickleball. ‚ÄúWith DUPR Coach, credentialed coaches can now assign a DUPR Rating to junior players anywhere in the world, simply through uploaded match film. It‚Äôs remote, scalable, and purpose-built to support their development. We‚Äôre proud to help bring this level of access and opportunity to the next generation of players.‚Äù

‚Äç

National Junior Pickleball has redefined what it means to be a junior competitor. These events are more than tournaments. They are communities of like-minded players and families building friendships that last well beyond the final match. With the addition of Coach-Assigned DUPRs, those connections are now backed by the sport‚Äôs leading rating system, giving juniors the structure, clarity, and competitive experience they deserve.

‚Äç

National Junior Pickleball players can download the My DUPR Coach app to receive their Coach-Assigned DUPR rating here!

‚Äç

About National Junior Pickleball

National Junior Pickleball (NJP) is the leading tournament series dedicated exclusively to youth pickleball players ages 8‚Äì18. NJP provides a positive, competitive environment that supports player development at every level‚Äîfrom first-time participants to elite junior athletes. With regional and national events across the U.S., NJP is building a true pathway for junior athletes to grow in the sport. NJP fosters a community grounded in sportsmanship, inclusion, and lifelong love for the game.

‚Äç

About MyJourney Pickleball

MyJourney Pickleball is the developer of DUPR Coach and the My DUPR Coach app, empowering coaches to perform detailed skill assessments and assign official Coach-Assigned DUPRs. The platform supports player development while unlocking new revenue opportunities for coaches and clubs.

‚Äç

About DUPR

DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) is the premier global pickleball rating system and technology platform, trusted by the world's leading clubs, tournaments, leagues, and players. DUPR's dynamic rating system unifies pickleball across age, gender, and location by analyzing match results to accurately evaluate all players across a 2.000 - 8.000 scale. DUPR is the official pickleball rating of leagues, tournaments and clubs around the world, including United Pickleball Association (UPA), PPA, Major League Pickleball (MLP), Pickleball.com, Life Time, The Picklr, National Team Pickleball League, National Pickleball League. It also owns and operates Minor League Pickleball and Collegiate Pickleball, two of the biggest amateur leagues in the sport. Players and operators can visit www.dupr.com to sign up and learn more.

title: From College Courts to the Big Stage: Zack Card‚Äôs MLP Debut
summary: Florida Atlantic University‚Äôs Zack Card stepped onto the Major League Pickleball stage for the first time‚Äîfacing elite competition, high-pressure moments, and lessons that will shape his future and pickleball ratings. Here‚Äôs what he learned.
content:

‚Äç

And now, with their franchise model, they are ready to expand nationwide

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

Clinics & Drills: From ‚ÄúLearn to Play‚Äù for newcomers to skill-specific drills for advanced players.

Leagues: Always packed, always logged to DUPR.


Major Events: Including the Flying Pickle Open, which draws over 350 participants from across the country.

title: Vulcan V-PRO FLIGHT Named Official Ball of DUPR
summary: DUPR announces the Vulcan V-PRO FLIGHT as its Official Ball for all pickleball tournaments, leagues and events, including DUPR Clubs, Minor League, High School and Collegiate Pickleball.
content:
‚ÄçFlorida Atlantic University‚Äôs own Zack Card is no stranger to the court, but even for a seasoned collegiate athlete, stepping into the national spotlight at a Major League Pickleball (MLP) event offered a whole new kind of intensity.

‚Äç

We caught up with Zack to hear about his experience at the MLP Mid-Season Tournament, where his team, after qualifying through the Collegiate National Championship, faced off against some of the biggest names in pickleball. Zack shared how the FAU squad rose to the challenge under pressure, and what lessons they're bringing back to collegiate pickleball this fall.

‚Äç

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an experience like no other.‚Äù

‚Äç

For Zack, the opportunity to compete at the professional level was more than just a career milestone; it was validation to continue his journey.

‚Äç

‚Äç

"I‚Äôm so glad I can continue to play and represent my school in a sport that‚Äôs growing exponentially, especially at the college level,‚Äù Zack said.¬†

‚Äç

Pressure and Performance: Lessons from MLP

‚Äç

The FAU team went head-to-head with challenger squad Florida Smash, ultimately falling 1‚Äì3 in the overall matches, with Zack's match being the last one of the four. When asked if he felt pressure to prove himself, Zack admitted:

‚Äç

‚ÄúI did put a lot of pressure on myself at the MLP event, which is unfortunate because it prevented me from giving my best possible performance. I usually try to go into events with no expectations, which helps relieve pressure, but I failed to do that at MLP."

‚Äç

Many athletes can relate to this kind of moment. It's a true ‚Äúmake or break‚Äù test when stepping onto the professional stage for the first time. Zack‚Äôs reflection on how he handled the pressure reveals a strong sense of self-awareness and personal growth under high-stakes conditions.

‚Äç

The mental game plays a major role, and often, it‚Äôs the mindset that makes the difference against the opposing team. Find out more about how to build mental strength on the pickleball court!

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

From Campus Courts to the Biggest Stage

‚Äç

The speed and intensity of the MLP environment surprised even a player as seasoned as Zack.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThe level at MLP is a lot different than college pickleball. I practice with top-level players, so that part wasn‚Äôt new, but the pressure changed everything. The game at MLP is much faster and more relentless. In college, players have to slow things down because they can‚Äôt create the same level of offense.‚Äù

‚Äç

Once the excitement, hype, and atmosphere of the big leagues faded, Zack finally had time to reflect, and a powerful realization hit him on the flight home.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThe second I took my seat on the plane going back home, I thought, ‚ÄòI can‚Äôt ever let this [the pressure and overthinking] happen to me again.‚Äô I learned a lot from that tournament, and I‚Äôll carry those lessons with me in everything I do on and off the court.‚Äù

‚Äç

Looking Ahead to the Fall Season

‚Äç

Zack believes the MLP experience won‚Äôt just shape him; it‚Äôll elevate the entire FAU team.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThis experience will absolutely help our college team this fall. I think we‚Äôre all going into the season with a better attitude and a deeper understanding of what it takes mentally to perform in big situations like these.‚Äù

‚Äç

‚Äç

Advice for Aspiring College-to-Pro Players

‚Äç

Zack‚Äôs advice to other college players dreaming of going pro? Stay true to yourself.

‚Äç

‚ÄúBecome the best player you can be, not the best version of someone else. Know your strengths and weaknesses. Maximize what you're good at and minimize your weak spots. Trying to copy someone else‚Äôs game actually hurts your own. Watch and learn from the pros, but don‚Äôt try to be them.‚Äù

‚Äç

Zack Card‚Äôs journey is a reminder that success isn‚Äôt just about talent; it‚Äôs about growth, self-awareness, and learning to rise under pressure. As pickleball continues its rapid rise at the collegiate level, athletes like Zack are showing the world what the next generation of competitors looks like: passionate, focused, and ready to evolve. Keep up with Zack‚Äôs journey at the FAU Pickleball team this fall season!

‚Äç

Vulcan‚Äôs V-PRO FLIGHT technology is regarded as best-in-class, delivering elite performance, durability, and accuracy. Already trusted as the Official Ball of Major League Pickleball (MLP), Vulcan now strengthens its position as the leading brand in pickleball ball technology.

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

Together, DUPR and Vulcan are shaping the future of competitive pickleball.¬†

About Vulcan

Vulcan Pickleball is the premier equipment brand in pickleball and the creators of the V-PRO FLIGHT pickleball. The V-PRO FLIGHT is the official ball of DUPR, High School Pickleball, Collegiate Pickleball, Minor League Pickleball, and Major League Pickleball. Trusted by recreational players and professional pickleball players alike, the V-PRO FLIGHT is ‚ÄúThe Official Ball of Pickleball‚Äù. Learn more at vulcanpickleball.com

‚Äç

About DUPR

title: Where Do Pickleball Pros Serve and Why
summary: Discover top pro serving tips from world #1 Federico Staksrud. Learn where to serve and why to take control of the point from shot one and improve your pickleball ratings.
content:
My name is Alex Crum.

‚Äç

Two months ago, I beat the #1 ranked player on the PPA Tour.¬†

‚Äç

Eight days later, I beat the #1 ranked player on the APP Tour.

‚Äç

My life changed.

‚Äç

‚Äç

The First Swing That Shifted Everything

‚Äç

Exactly two years ago, I picked up a pickleball paddle for the first time and my life took a complete new direction.¬†

‚Äç

Never had a sport felt so natural to me. I felt I had total control over the ball after my first swing.¬†

‚Äç

As a lifelong tennis player, there is of course a natural skillset translation that exists for all tennis players, but for me this felt exacerbated . My 5‚Äô11 frame was no longer a disadvantage. My mediocre tennis serve instantly became a weapon on the pickleball court. This felt like the perfect game for me.¬†

‚Äç

After beating a top 60 touring pro a few days after first strike, I was convinced that within months I would take the Pickleball world by storm.¬†

‚Äç

I did not.

‚Äç

Reality Check in Cincinnati

‚Äç

At my first tournament‚Äîthe PPA in Cincinnati‚ÄîI lost in the first round of qualifying. In about ten minutes. Maybe I wasn‚Äôt that guy after all.

after all.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Back on Track

‚Äç

One month later, I won the USA Pickleball National Indoors, beating some pretty decent competition along the way and felt there was perhaps a small chance that maybe I could be that guy I once envisioned.¬†¬†

‚Äç

Balancing Work and Competition

‚Äç

Since then, I‚Äôve trained and competed sporadically. I've spent the last two years working full-time as a tennis coach at country clubs across the country. I love teaching and connecting with people. But nothing compares to the adrenaline I feel every time I get to compete.



I was jealous of the players who got to do it every weekend. I kept telling myself: one day, I‚Äôll have my breakthrough. One day, I‚Äôll be able to train and play full time.

‚Äç

That day came.

‚Äç

One month ago, I signed a contract with the PPA Tour.

‚Äç

My life changed again.

‚Äç

What‚Äôs Next

‚Äç

I will be joining my PPA schedule with some football games, where I‚Äôll head to the tailgates and play with everyone. There will be music, pros, and DUPR coaches giving out DUPR ratings. Starting in August, this will be my job. I‚Äôll travel the country competing in a sport that has already given me so much in such a short time. Now, it‚Äôs my turn to give everything I have back.

‚Äç

Check out the 2025 Collegiate Tailgate Tour schedule to see when I‚Äôll be at a campus near you and join the fun!

‚Äç

‚Äç

One Global Sport. One Global Rating.

‚Äç

In a historic move for international pickleball, the Global Pickleball Federation (GPF), world governing body for pickleball, has officially named DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) its official rating system.

‚Äç

This partnership marks a pivotal moment in the history of pickleball‚Äôs global development, uniting GPF‚Äôs four continental federations, member nations and GPF owned and operated events for the first time, under one trusted and universally adopted rating system.

‚Äç

A Shared Vision for Global Pickleball Growth

‚Äç

The GPF serves as the international federation for the Continental Federation of Africa (CAP), Pickleball Federation of the Americas (PFA), Oceania Pickleball Federation (OPF), Asia Pickleball Association (APA) as well as twelve European member countries and growing. DUPR is the preferred rating for the GPF, solidifying a truly global framework for fair and consistent competition.¬†

‚Äç

The GPF‚Äôs non-profit board of directors is led by active stewards of our sport, deeply invested in the future. The founders and leaders of pickleball in Australia, Canada, Chile, Ghana, India,¬† Ireland, Mexico, The Philippines, Poland and the United States serve as legacy members on the GPF board.¬†

‚Äç

¬†Players, coaches, and organizers will benefit from:

‚Äç

¬†One Standardized Rating:
DUPR‚Äôs trusted 2.000‚Äì8.000 scale brings clarity and consistency to all levels of play, from amateur matches to elite competition.

‚Äç

Smarter Player Development:
Whether you're a recreational player or a national team prospect, DUPR provides real-time, match-based ratings that reflect actual performance; not just wins and losses.

‚Äç

¬†Simplified Event Organization:
Federations and clubs worldwide can now use DUPR to accurately seed brackets, set divisions, and streamline tournament play.¬†

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre thrilled to partner with DUPR as we work to elevate and unify pickleball worldwide,‚Äù said GPF President Javier Regalado. ‚ÄúHaving a single, trusted rating system in place across continents is a positive step toward unifying pickleball, eliminating some of the confusion and fragmentation that inhibits growth.‚Äù¬†

‚Äç

A Step Closer to Olympic Recognition

‚Äç

This alignment also supports GPF‚Äôs long-term mission to instill best practices and standards, ultimately achieving International Olympic Committee (IOC) recognition for pickleball and future inclusion in the 2032 Brisbane Olympics. Last month, a GPF delegation officially entered its application for IOC recognition in Lausanne, Switzerland.¬†

‚Äç

‚ÄúUnder GPF and DUPR‚Äôs historic alignment, international players of all ages, gender and location are united under one technology platform to grow the great sport of pickleball.‚Äù added DUPR CEO Tito Machado.¬†

‚Äç

ABOUT GLOBAL PICKLEBALL FEDERATION (GPF)

‚Äç

The GPF is the world governing body for pickleball, serving as a not-for-profit organization focused on the integrity and development of pickleball globally ‚Äì from grassroots to recreational and high-performance levels. GPF‚Äôs unifying function, structure, and board are aligned with pickleball‚Äôs established continental federations and a valued volunteer network engaged in growing the sport worldwide. The GPF‚Äôs ethical framework and by-laws will ultimately lead the sport of pickleball to International Olympic Committee recognition and inclusion in the 2032 Brisbane Olympics. The constant interplay between the GPF with its respective continental and national federations ensures uniform rules, regulations, standards, and the ability to swiftly implement best practices. For more info, visit https://globalpickleballfederation.org/¬†

‚Äç

ABOUT DUPR

‚Äç

DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) is the premier global pickleball rating system and technology platform, trusted by the world's leading clubs, tournaments, leagues, and players. DUPR's dynamic rating system unifies pickleball across age, gender, and location by analyzing match results to accurately evaluate all players across a 2.000 - 8.000 scale. DUPR is the official pickleball rating of leagues, tournaments and clubs around the world, including United Pickleball Association (UPA), PPA, Major League Pickleball (MLP), Pickleball.com, Life Time, The Picklr, National Team Pickleball League, and National Pickleball League. It also owns and operates Minor League Pickleball and Collegiate Pickleball, two of the biggest amateur leagues in the sport. Players and operators can visit www.dupr.com to sign up and learn more.

title: Serving Rules in Pickleball
summary: Serving is one of the most misunderstood parts of pickleball. Can you spin it? Hit it above your waist? Step on the line? This updated 2025 guide breaks down all the official pickleball serving rules‚Äîso you can serve with confidence and avoid costly faults.
content:
Thinking about starting a pickleball club at your university? You‚Äôre not alone. With over 300 colleges in the U.S. already on board, the sport is booming, and your school could be next. Whether you're looking to play for fun, build a competitive team, or just grow the pickleball community on campus, this step-by-step guide will walk you through how to make it happen.

‚Äç

Step 1: Check Your School‚Äôs Club Requirements

‚Äç

Every college has its own process for approving new student organizations, so your first move is to find out what your school requires.¬†

‚Äç

A quick search like ‚Äú[Your School Name] how to start a club‚Äù will usually point you in the right direction.

‚Äç

Key things to look for:

‚Äç

Registration deadlines


Required leadership roles


Minimum number of members


Whether you need a faculty or staff advisor



Quick Note: Most colleges distinguish between ‚Äústudent organizations‚Äù and ‚Äúclub sports.‚Äù You‚Äôll usually need to register as a student organization¬† before applying for club sport status, so start there to save time.¬†

‚Äç

Once you‚Äôve submitted everything and your application is approved, congrats! You‚Äôve got an official pickleball club on campus. Now it‚Äôs time to build it.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Step 2: Recruit Consistent Members

‚Äç

In the early stages, it‚Äôs all about momentum. Use whatever equipment and space you have access to and get creative with recruiting.

‚Äç

Here are some great ways to find players:

‚Äç

Visit pickleball classes on campus and invite students


Show up at intramural tournaments and talk to participants

Participate in your school‚Äôs club fair
Build a simple website or social media presence so people can find you online. Choose a username or domain clearly linked to your school and pickleball club.
Post flyers and add a QR code linking to the social media account or talk to players at local pickleball courts
Reserve tennis/pickleball courts on campus or ask local facilities for discounted court time



Create a group chat or email list to keep everyone connected and informed. Be proactive: if someone shows interest, invite them personally. Make new players feel welcome by pairing them with others at their level and offering to teach the basics. This is what builds community and keeps them coming back.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Step 3: Grow Your Club

‚Äç

Once you have a core group, it‚Äôs time to scale.

‚Äç

Set Weekly Practice Times: Establish consistent meetups to create structure. It also gives you a clear answer when someone asks, ‚ÄúWhen can I join?‚Äù


Build Your Equipment Supply: Start collecting paddles, balls, portable nets, and hoppers. Ask experienced players or alumni if they can donate gear. You can also contact local businesses for sponsorships or fundraising support.



üí° Special Tip: Create a DUPR Digital Club to manage your members and track match results. It gives your club a professional presence and makes it easier to organize games, display your location, and help players improve with accurate ratings.¬†

‚Äç

Start your Digital Club for FREE¬† here.

‚Äç

Step 4: Compete with Other Schools

‚Äç

Once you have enough players and equipment, take things to the next level: college competition.

‚Äç

Connect with nearby schools that have clubs


Use social media or the DUPR club directory to find opponents


Organize scrimmages or join round robins and tournaments


Start incorporating drills to strengthen your team‚Äôs skills


Invite local coaches or high-level players to run clinics



Starting a pickleball club at your school is one of the most rewarding ways to make an impact, meet new people, and grow the game. It doesn‚Äôt take much to get started. All you need is a few players, some paddles, and a little passion.

‚Äç

Check out the Collegiate Pickleball Tournament (CPT) calendar to find upcoming events. CPT matches are co-ed and formatted for teams of 2 men and 2 women. Schools can bring multiple teams, and top performers may even earn scholarships or bids to the Collegiate National Championship in April.

‚Äç

Want even more help? Download our 24-page Collegiate Pickleball Club Guide, written by past and present club presidents. It‚Äôs full of detailed strategies, sample meeting templates, fundraising ideas, and practice plans that worked at real schools.

‚Äç

üì© Have questions? We‚Äôve got answers. Email us at college@mydupr.com

‚Äç

Let‚Äôs get your school on the map. üèì
