title: DUPR Coach Rates 150 Players in Just 2 Months
summary: DUPR Coach Tommy Welch helped grow Pickleball Kingdom to 400+ members in just 2 months‚Äîwhile personally rating 150 players.
content:
The serve starts every point, and it sets the tone for the entire rally. While it‚Äôs not about overpowering your opponent like in tennis, a well-placed serve in pickleball can throw them off balance and give you the upper hand in any pickleball tournament. It‚Äôs all about precision, consistency, and control.

‚Äç

Still, serving can be confusing, especially for newer players. Can you serve underhand or sidearm? Can you throw the ball up on a volley serve?? What about drop serves, time limits, or serving into the kitchen? And does pickleball even have a ‚Äúlet‚Äù rule?

‚Äç

We break it all down in this guide, answering the most common questions and clearing up the gray areas.

‚Äç

Let‚Äôs settle it once and for all: What are the serving rules in pickleball?

‚Äç

Official Pickleball Serve Rules (2025 Update)

‚Äç

1. Volley Serves¬†

‚Äç

A volley serve is when you hit the ball before it bounces, and you can throw the ball up for a volley serve. When you hit the ball, your arm must be in an upward arc, contact can't be made above the waist, and the paddle head must stay below the wrist.

‚Äç

2. One Foot Behind the Baseline

‚Äç

At least one foot must remain behind the baseline and on the ground until the ball is struck. The other foot can't be on the ground outside the service area.¬† Stepping on the line during the serve is a fault.¬†

‚Äç

3. Diagonal Placement

‚Äç

The serve must land in the opposite diagonal service box. If it lands outside the lines or on the kitchen line or in the kitchen (non-volley zone), it‚Äôs a fault.

‚Äç

4. Drop Serve Is Legal

‚Äç

The drop serve is still legal.. Yep, you heard that right!

‚Äç

Without applying any force to the ball, you can simply let it drop and hit it after it bounces‚Äîoffering a more flexible and strategic serving option. Your feet must remain in the same position as for a volley serve, but you can drop the ball anywhere, and none of the three volley serve requirements apply.

‚Äç

‚Äç

5. Single Attempt Only

‚Äç

Unlike in tennis, there are no second chances. If you commit a single fault on your serve, you lose the rally.¬†

‚Äç

6. No Spin Allowed

‚Äç

You can‚Äôt spin the ball with your hand or paddle before hitting it. ¬† Only a natural rotation is accepted on the release but, when you hit the ball, put all the spin you want on it!¬†

‚Äç

Serve Rules for Singles vs Doubles

‚Äç

In singles, the server switches sides after each point scored, always serving from the right when the score is even and from the left when it's odd. Only the serving person can score points.¬†

‚Äç

In doubles, only the serving team can score points. Each player on the team gets a turn to serve, except at the start of the game,¬† when only one player serves for the first team.

‚Äç

Service Sequence in Doubles

‚Äç

Let‚Äôs break it down with an example:

‚Äç

Team I: Player A and Player B


Team II: Player C and Player D

‚Äç

Players A and C are the starting servers for their teams. When their team's score is even, they will serve from the right side of their court.



Game starts with Player A serving from the right side of the court.


Each time Team I scores a point, they switch sides (right to left, left to right) and Player A continues serving.


When Team I makes a fault, they lose the serve.



Since it's the start of the game, only Player A serves for Team I. Then it‚Äôs a side out.

‚Äç

Player C (Team II) now serves from the right side.


Just like before, if Team II scores, the players switch sides and Player C keeps serving until they commit a fault.


After Player C faults, their partner, Player D, gets to serve.


Player D serves from the appropriate side based on the score (not necessarily the right side).


Once both players on Team II lose their serves, it‚Äôs a side out, and Team I regains serve; this time, starting on the right, with whichever player matches their score (if their score is even it will be Player A, odd will be Player B), and now both partners will get to serve in that turn.



This rotation continues throughout the match, with each player on a team getting a chance to serve‚Äîexcept for the first team to serve, where only one player serves before the side out.

‚Äç

Common Pickleball Serving Faults

‚Äç

Avoid these errors to stay legal:

‚Äç

Hitting the ball above waist level


Serving into the kitchen or on the kitchen line


Stepping on¬† the baseline when you make contact with the ball.


Missing the cross-court service court!



Being aware of these serving faults helps prevent easy point losses, especially when your pickleball rating and performance in pickleball tournaments are on the line.

‚Äç

üëâ 90% of players get these pickleball rules wrong. Don‚Äôt be one of them.¬†

‚Äç

title: DUPR Algo Update: Win or Lose, Your Rating Can Go Up
summary: DUPR‚Äôs updated algorithm rates you by performance, not wins or losses. Overperform and your rating will go up‚Äîeven if you lose. More accurate. More fair. Learn more today.
content:
This week, we released an update to the DUPR algorithm: ratings now adjust based on a player‚Äôs performance compared to the expected score. You can read the full update details here.¬†

‚Äç

We‚Äôve received a lot of good and thoughtful feedback ‚Äî along with some great questions and concerns. Below, we‚Äôre addressing some of the most common comments to help explain the thinking behind the update and what it means for you.

‚Äç

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt make sense to go down with a win.‚Äù


‚Äç

We know it‚Äôs never enjoyable to see your rating drop ‚Äî especially after a win.¬†

‚Äç

Our goal as a rating system is to most accurately measure skill and predict future performance. DUPR is not a reward system, it‚Äôs a rating system.

‚Äç

So while a win may earn you a trophy, a better seed, or advancement in a tournament, it doesn‚Äôt always mean your rating should go up. If you scored fewer points than expected, that‚Äôs a signal you underperformed relative to your current rating, and we adjust accordingly. The reverse is also true: if you lose but overperform, your rating can rise.

‚Äç

In all cases, your DUPR reflects performance, not just outcomes, because that‚Äôs what makes the system more accurate for everyone.

‚Äç

‚ÄúIt makes sense to go up for overperforming in a loss ‚Äî but not down with a win.‚Äù


‚Äç

That sounds nice in theory, but it doesn‚Äôt work in practice.

‚Äç

Each player‚Äôs rating exists within a larger ecosystem. While we aim to assign the most accurate rating to every individual, we also have to maintain the balance of the overall rating system.

‚Äç

If neither team goes down after a match, the entire distribution would drift upward over time. To keep the system stable and meaningful, one team‚Äôs rating goes up and the other‚Äôs goes down, based on how each performed relative to expectations, not just the result.

‚Äç

‚ÄúElements like net cords, wind, or fatigue make point-level granularity unfair.‚Äù


‚Äç

We get it ‚Äî not every match is played in perfect conditions. Sometimes the wind, net cords, or fatigue work against you. But here‚Äôs the reality: those same factors can just as easily work for you in other matches.

‚Äç

Your DUPR is built from the full body of your results, not any single match. One unlucky day won‚Äôt define your rating, especially if it‚Äôs already well-established. There will always be some natural swings, but over time, your rating will reflect your true level as long as your performance does too.

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚ÄúThis hurts high-rated players ‚Äî there‚Äôs no reason for them to play.‚Äù

‚Äç


In each match, both teams have the chance to move up or down based on how they perform compared to expectations.

‚Äç

Our goal as a rating system is to most accurately rate players according to their performance in match results, which is a consistent approach to all levels of players.

‚Äç
‚Äç

"Will you adjust ratings with this update?‚Äù

‚Äç

No, we will not be adjusting ratings at this time.

‚Äç

As you continue to play, the system will naturally reflect your performance under the new model, improving accuracy across the board.
‚Äç

‚Äç

‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt this just the old DUPR algorithm?‚Äù


‚Äç

It might feel familiar, and that‚Äôs intentional. This update reintroduces the idea of performance vs. expectation, which was part of a previous version of DUPR. But it‚Äôs not a return to the old system.

‚Äç

DUPR has evolved over time, with updates focused on transparency, user experience, and rating accuracy. Since that earlier version, we‚Äôve added features like near-instant rating updates and more visibility into how each match affects your rating.

‚Äç

This change builds on those improvements, not by going backward, but by combining proven ideas with the features players now expect. We‚Äôre committed to continually refining DUPR to best reflect player performance and the evolving game of pickleball.

‚Äç

For more information, check out our How It Works page.

title: How to Go Pro in Pickleball: Bobbi Oshiro's Road to Pro Guide
summary: Thinking of going pro in pickleball? Bobbi Oshiro‚Äôs road to pro guide breaks down training schedules, top tournaments and equipment tips to become a pro pickleball player.
content:
We‚Äôve made an important update to the DUPR rating algorithm. Starting today, your rating will move based on how you‚Äôre actually performing‚Äînot whether you win or lose.¬†

‚Äç

What‚Äôs Changed?

‚Äç

Your rating now moves based on performance vs. expectation.

‚Äç

Every match has an expected score, calculated from the ratings of the players involved.

‚Äç

‚ÄçIf you score more than expected, your DUPR rating will go up - even if you lose. If you score less, it will go down - even if you win.

‚Äç

Whereas before, the winning team would always go up and the losing team would go down.

‚Äç

Doubles Example:

‚Äç

If a team is expected to win 11‚Äì3 but wins 11‚Äì8, their DUPR rating will go down.

‚Äç
The losing team, which was expected to score fewer points, will go up.

‚Äç

Singles Example:

‚Äç

If you‚Äôre a 3.5 playing against a 4.0, we expect the score to be 5-11. If you instead lose 9-11, you‚Äôve overperformed expectations, so you will see your rating go up.¬†

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

What this recent update solves for

‚Äç

‚úÖ Performance-based

‚Äç

Your rating now reflects how you perform relative to expectations ‚Äî not whether you win or lose. Every point matters.

‚Äç

‚úÖ More accurate

‚Äç

By going deeper into point-level performance, DUPR delivers a more precise measure of your current skill level.

‚Äç

‚úÖ Fair for everyone

‚Äç

Every player has a chance to improve their rating by overperforming ‚Äî whether you're the favorite or the underdog.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Bottom line: every point counts. Whether you‚Äôre the underdog or the favorite, the algorithm rewards players who perform above expectations. Even if you lose, proving you can compete at a higher level will improve your DUPR rating.

‚Äç

As the rating of the sport, we are committed to constantly improving rating accuracy and player experience ‚Äî this update shows our continued focus on delivering that commitment.

‚Äç

Have questions? Check out this blog, where we answer the most frequently asked questions regarding the algorithm update.

‚Äç

Thanks for being part of the DUPR community!

‚Äç

üëâ Find out more about how the DUPR algorithm is calculated.

‚Äç

title: Over 50% of People Don‚Äôt Know The Most Important Shot in Pickleball
summary: DUPR‚Äôs poll of 1,000+ players reveals most prioritize the wrong shot. Learn why resets are the most important shot in pickleball and key to improve your pickleball ratings.
content:
Road to Pro Guide - by Bobbi Oshiro

‚Äç

Just like in any professional sport, going pro in pickleball requires immense time, dedication, and discipline. You have to treat it like a full-time job‚Äîbalancing a traditional 9-to-5 alongside a serious pickleball career is no longer realistic.¬†

‚Äç

A look at the Top 20 DUPR Rankings in both Men‚Äôs and Women‚Äôs Doubles shows nearly every athlete has left conventional office work to fully commit to the sport (with the amazing exception of the Kawamoto twins, who still work full-time for the NCAA while competing at the highest level!).

‚Äç

‚Äç

Many professional players also build financial stability through pickleball by creating educational content, becoming influencers, launching podcasts, and teaching camps or clinics.

‚Äç

But hey, if life has taught us anything, it‚Äôs that anything is possible with enough passion‚Ä¶and maybe a really good third-shot drop.

‚Äç

Thinking About Going Pro? Here‚Äôs How to Get Started

‚Äç

Training & Practices

‚Äç

Dedicate 20+ hours per week to on-court and off-court work.


A typical Monday to Friday includes 3 - 4 hours of training per day, split into drills and match play.


Saturdays and Sundays are often tournament days - if you‚Äôre not competing, take at least one day to rest and recover.


Don‚Äôt forget your off-court fitness and recovery - they‚Äôre just as important as practicing.



Here‚Äôs what a sample week might look like:

‚Äç

Equipment

‚Äç

Be sure to check out what the pros are using. The most trusted paddle brands tend to be the ones that are fully invested in pickleball, not just repurposing tennis tech. Companies like JOOLA, Paddletek, Proton, Franklin and Selkirk focus on the sport and support their pro players, leading the way in innovation and performance.

‚Äç

Competitive Tournament Pathway

‚Äç

A perfect training schedule must go hand in hand with a tailored tournament plan. Choosing the right tournaments is essential to raising your pickleball ratings and gaining valuable experience. If you‚Äôre serious about going pro, start targeting these key events:

‚Äç

Collegiate Pickleball


Minor League Pickleball (MiLP) DUPR 20 & 22


PPA Challenger and Tour
¬†Major League Pickleball (MLP)


APP Tour


International Tours: Global Sports, PPA Asia, Vietnam Tour

‚Äç

Build a Personal Brand

‚Äç

Establish a strong social media presence on Instagram, TikTok, YouTube, etc.


Decide how you want to portray yourself to fans, brands, and the community.


Network with other pro players, influencers, and industry insiders. Relationships are key.


Track your Progress

‚Äç

If you want to go pro, you need to set clear goals and track your progress. Focus on your plan and trust the process. Identify areas for improvement using the DUPR app, and make film study part of your routine, where you watch top players to analyze patterns, strategies, and shot selections.

‚Äç

With dedication, smart planning, and the right resources, you can set yourself on the path to becoming a professional pickleball player, and maybe one day see your name climbing the DUPR rankings.

title: RSPA Pickleball Certification to Include DUPR Coach
summary: RSPA launches the first pickleball certification combining advanced education with DUPR Coach, giving coaches tools to rate players & generate revenue.
content:
Pickleball is no longer just America‚Äôs fastest-growing sport‚Äîit‚Äôs quickly becoming Asia‚Äôs favorite too. New research from UPA Asia and YouGov Singapore reveals that 1.9 billion people across Asia have heard of pickleball, and 812 million have played it at least once.

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

A Closer Look at the Numbers

‚Äç

To put that in perspective, the entire U.S. population is around 340 million. That means more people in Asia have played pickleball than the total number of people living in the United States.¬†

‚Äç

Even more impressive? 282 million people in Asia play pickleball at least once a month. That‚Äôs the equivalent of more than 80% of the U.S. population engaging with the sport regularly.

‚Äç

The findings are based on responses from over 14,000 participants in 12 Asian markets, including: China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, The Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Hong Kong, Thailand, and Vietnam.

‚Äç

Here‚Äôs How Some of the Top Countries Stack Up:



India takes the crown in total number of monthly players with 178 million.


China follows with 60 million monthly players.

‚Äç

Vietnam leads in awareness and participation percentages: 88% of people know about pickleball and 37% play the sport regularly. Vietnam boasts over 16 million frequent players.

‚Äç

Malaysia ranks #3 in countries with the most DUPR users.¬†

‚Äç

What Does This Mean for Pickleball's Global Future?

‚Äç

The opportunities are huge for brands, federations, and facilities investing in pickleball growth:

‚Äç

Massive market potential: With hundreds of millions of regular players, the demand for courts, coaches, and equipment is booming across Asia.


Global expansion strategies: Organizations looking to globalize their pickleball presence need to focus on Asia now more than ever.


Cultural crossover: Pickleball‚Äôs accessibility and low entry cost make it ideal for densely populated, fast-growing regions.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Pickleball isn‚Äôt just a U.S. phenomenon‚Äîit‚Äôs a global movement. With hundreds of millions of players across Asia playing the sport, this isn‚Äôt just a trend‚Äîit‚Äôs a cultural shift. From Vietnam to India, Asia is not only embracing pickleball, it‚Äôs shaping its future. Whether you‚Äôre a brand, athlete, investor, a player seeking a higher pickleball rating, or fan, the next era of pickleball is being written in Asia.

title: Facing Pros To Dominate College Pickleball
summary: Discover how Utah Valley‚Äôs Bryce Larson uses PPA events to sharpen his game, build confidence, and lead his team to college pickleball dominance.
content:
Industry‚Äôs First Education + Revenue Generator Combination exclusively for RSPA Members¬†

‚Äç

Orlando, FL - July 3, 2025 - The Racquet Sports Professionals Association (RSPA), formerly the United States Professional Tennis Association (USPTA), today announced a groundbreaking new benefit exclusively for its members: the addition of DUPR Coach to the official RSPA Pickleball Certification program. This marks the first time a racquet sports certification combines advanced education with an immediate income opportunity for coaches.

‚Äç

Launching initially for RSPA Pickleball-certified members only, the program will roll out in phases with an expanded profile soon to further strengthen the reach and impact of DUPR Coach across the racquet sports community.

‚Äç

As part of this launch, current RSPA-certified Pickleball members can upgrade for only $50 ‚Äì a $200 savings ‚Äì to add DUPR Coach credentialing to their certification. This special member offer ensures coaches remain at the forefront of the fast-growing pickleball market with tools that set them apart.

‚Äç

Through the new offering, certified RSPA coaches will be credentialed as DUPR Coaches, unlocking exclusive access to DUPR‚Äôs Coach-Assigned Rating system and assessment tools. DUPR Coaches can assess players in-person or remotely, either via DUPR Rating Sessions or game film, and instantly generate an official Coach-Assigned DUPR for any non-rated player.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThe addition of DUPR Coach to the RSPA Pickleball Certification is more than a feature; it‚Äôs a shift in what it means to be a coach,‚Äù said Brian Dillman, CEO of RSPA. ‚ÄúFor the first time in our industry, professionals will leave a certification workshop with not just training, but with the immediate ability to improve their bottom line. This is a certification built for the future of coaching.‚Äù

‚Äç

This means coaches can now offer rating services, host DUPR Assessment Events, and lead skills improvement sessions designed around helping players earn and improve their DUPRs, all while generating new revenue streams.

‚Äç

The RSPA Pickleball certification, modeled after their industry-leading successful tennis protocols and co-designed with leading pickleball educators, will include instructional education followed by credentialing on how to become a DUPR Coach. RSPA Pickleball workshops are already available nationwide across all 17 RSPA divisions.

‚Äç

‚ÄúCoaches are the key to growing pickleball at every level,‚Äù said DUPR CEO Tito Machado. ‚ÄúBy adding DUPR Coach along with the RSPA certification, we‚Äôre giving them real tools to lead with education, credibility, and a new way to earn. This partnership is about empowering coaches to build stronger programs and stronger communities.‚Äù

‚Äç

‚ÄúRSPA‚Äôs adoption of DUPR Coach and its reach to more than 14,000 members signals a powerful commitment to growing the game of pickleball,‚Äù said Katie Nimitz, President of My Journey Pickleball. ‚ÄúNow, over 4,000 country and racquet clubs will be equipped to meet the sport‚Äôs rapid growth and generate meaningful income for their coaching programs and facilities.‚Äù

‚Äç

With millions of non-rated players across the U.S., the need for accessible ratings and a strong coaching infrastructure has never been more pressing. The RSPA Pickleball Certification with DUPR Coach answers that call, giving coaches the foundation to teach and the technology to build thriving programs in their communities.

‚Äç

RSPA Pickleball-certified members can upgrade their certification and start their DUPR Coach journey HERE.

‚Äç

About the RSPA

The Racquet Sports Professionals Association (RSPA), formerly the United States Professional Tennis Association (USPTA), is the leading trade organization for racquet sports professionals. Since 1927, the RSPA has grown to support the diverse needs of the racquet sports industry, including tennis, pickleball, padel, squash, and platform tennis. With more than 14,000 members worldwide and 17 divisions across the country, the RSPA offers career advancement support, certification, and development opportunities, from coaching to club management, executive development to sales and marketing, and beyond. Our mission is to champion the passion of racquet sports by developing professionals who lead with integrity, innovate in coaching, and inspire a diverse and inclusive racquet sports community. Learn more at RSPA.net.

‚Äç

About DUPR Coach

DUPR Coach is a program designed to empower pickleball coaches to launch Coach-Assigned DUPR ratings for the 34 million non-rated players worldwide. Powered by MyJourney Pickleball, DUPR Coach helps coaches provide valuable insights into players‚Äô skill levels and supports the growth of pickleball through more competitive, enjoyable play. Coaches interested in becoming DUPR Coaches can visit duprcoach.com/coach-cert to sign up and learn more.

‚Äç

content:
For Bryce Larson (DUPR 5.701 singles) of Utah Valley University, summer isn‚Äôt a time to slow down ‚Äî it‚Äôs a chance to set himself apart by challenging the best. And he‚Äôs doing just that by stepping onto the court with some of the top pickleball players in the world.

‚Äç

We caught up with Bryce to learn his secret weapon for staying sharp before the collegiate season kicks off. His approach? Choosing the right tournaments, finding high-DUPR opponents, and pushing himself outside his comfort zone every time he plays.

‚Äç

Fearless on Court: Embracing Challenges

‚Äç

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no better way to improve than competing against some of the best players in the world,‚Äù Bryce explained. ‚ÄúThose experiences give me confidence, and I bring that energy straight back into college tournaments.‚Äù

‚Äç

For Bryce, these matches aren‚Äôt just practice ‚Äî they‚Äôre essential for maintaining and boosting his DUPR rating while sharpening every aspect of his game.

‚Äç

Why Working on His DUPR Rating Matters

‚Äç

So, how important is it for Bryce to keep his DUPR strong during the summer?

‚Äç

¬†‚ÄúDUPR is the most accurate way to determine a player‚Äôs skill and rating,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúCompeting against top players in the PPA Challenger and Qualifier events helps me stay on top of my game and fully prepared for the upcoming college season.‚Äù

‚Äç

Mindset & Discipline Over Talent

‚Äç

The best athletes know how to perform under pressure ‚Äî and Bryce thrives in those moments. As Billie Jean King once said, ‚ÄúPressure is a privilege.‚Äù Bryce agrees, and credits these high-stakes matches for building his composure and leadership.

‚Äç

¬†‚ÄúI can be a leader for my team in big moments because PPA events have already put me in pressure situations and helped me build my composure,‚Äù he shared.

‚Äç

Main Motivation: Leading His Team to the Championship

‚Äç

When it comes to his goals, Bryce isn‚Äôt holding back.

‚Äç

¬†‚ÄúMy goals for the summer are to keep training and playing against top talent so that when the collegiate season starts, I‚Äôm ready to help Utah Valley University remain a powerhouse in the pickleball scene.‚Äù

‚Äç

With a mindset focused on growth and a summer packed with elite competition, Bryce isn‚Äôt just preparing ‚Äî he‚Äôs raising the standard for what it means to train like a champion. We can‚Äôt wait to see how his dedication translates on the court this fall.

‚Äç

title: Staying Sharp in the Offseason: Summer Training with UF Pickleball
summary: While most college pickleball players take the summer off, UF Pickleball is doubling down. Co-Captain Christian Franke shares how the team trains for the upcoming season.
content:
Let‚Äôs be real‚Äîif you really love pickleball, you don‚Äôt stop playing just because you‚Äôre on vacation. In fact, you plan your vacation around it.

‚Äç

We‚Äôve rounded up 10 jaw-dropping pickleball courts across the U.S. that pair excellent views with top-tier play.¬† From sunset dinks in Maui to skyline matches in NYC, these are the places every pickleball player needs to experience at least once in their life.

‚Äç

‚Äç

1. Central Park Pickleball Courts ‚Äì New York, NY

‚Äç

‚Äç

Set in the heart of Manhattan, these pickleball courts combine iconic city views with green space serenity. Whether you're a beginner still learning pickleball rules or a seasoned pro focused on your pickleball ratings, Central Park is the perfect place to test your skills under the skyline.

‚Äç

These courts are open during the off season months so enjoy them while you can!

‚Äç

2. Wailea Tennis & Pickleball Club ‚Äì Maui, Hawaii

‚Äç

‚Äç

You haven‚Äôt truly experienced pickleball paradise until you‚Äôve played at Wailea Tennis & Pickleball Club. This award‚Äëwinning facility offers a luxury country‚Äëclub vibe with panoramic views over the Pacific and West Maui Mountains

‚Äç

Tucked into the hills of Maui‚Äôs Wailea Resort, these courts deliver sunshine, spin, ocean views‚Äîand maybe even a little romance. If you ask us, it‚Äôs the perfect honeymoon combo: breezy rallies by day, sunsets over the Pacific by night, and lots of pickleball.¬†

‚Äç

Whether you're sharpening your serve or just soaking it all in, this is where your love for pickleball (and maybe your partner) hits new heights.

‚Äç

3. PGA Village Verano ‚Äì Port St. Lucie

‚Äç

‚Äç

Planning a Summer Vacation With the Family? This Pickleball Spot Has You Covered

‚Äç

If your dream vacation includes quality time, warm weather, and plenty of pickleball, PGA Village Verano in Port St. Lucie, FL needs to be on your list.

‚Äç

This upscale, resort-style community along Florida‚Äôs scenic Treasure Coast isn‚Äôt just for serious players‚Äîit‚Äôs perfect for families, too. Parents can jump into round-robins or morning clinics while the kids learn to rally on beautifully maintained courts. Or, better yet, join in together and make pickleball a family affair.

‚Äç

The relaxed, welcoming vibe makes it easy to meet new friends, while palm-lined walkways and sunny skies set the tone for a laid-back stay. And with community events, open play, and plenty of space to unwind, it‚Äôs the kind of place where ‚Äúone vacation‚Äù turns into a new tradition.

‚Äç

Pickleball + family time = summer done right.

‚Äç

4.¬† Town of Springdale Community Park ‚Äì Springdale, UT

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

If Zion National Park is on your travel list, you‚Äôre in luck‚Äîbecause just outside its gates lies one of the most scenic pickleball spots in the country. The public courts at Springdale Community Park aren‚Äôt just a place to play‚Äîthey‚Äôre a full sensory experience.

‚Äç

Picture this: you're mid-rally, paddle in hand, and all around you are towering red rock cliffs, glowing in the sunlight and echoing every bounce of the ball. It‚Äôs a surreal backdrop that makes even the most intense matches feel a little more peaceful.

‚Äç

Whether you‚Äôre battling it out in a competitive game or just casually warming up with a partner, the setting alone is worth the trip. These courts are clean, well-maintained, and open to players of all levels. It‚Äôs the perfect mix of outdoor adventure and pickleball bliss.

‚Äç

5. Carmel Valley Ranch Resort ‚Äì Carmel, CA

‚Äç

‚Äç

Tucked into the rolling hills of California‚Äôs Central Coast, Carmel Valley Ranch is where world-class pickleball meets wine country charm. This luxury resort doesn‚Äôt just offer a place to play‚Äîit delivers a full-on experience that‚Äôs equal parts relaxation and recreation.

‚Äç

The courts are surrounded by oak-studded hills, lavender fields, and vineyard views‚Äîmaking it nearly impossible to have a stressful match. You might come for the pickleball, but you‚Äôll stay for the sunsets, spa treatments, and post-game glasses of wine.

‚Äç

Whether you‚Äôre drilling with a pro, joining a round-robin, or just having a casual rally with friends, every game here feels like something out of a postcard. And with upscale dining, scenic hiking trails, and luxurious suites just steps away, it‚Äôs the kind of place where your partner won‚Äôt mind that your vacation revolves around pickleball.

‚Äç

6. Steamboat Tennis & Pickleball ‚Äì Steamboat Springs, CO

‚Äç

‚Äç

Calling all mountain-loving players‚Äîthis is one for the bucket list. Nestled in the heart of the Rockies, Steamboat Tennis & Pickleball isn‚Äôt just a place to play‚Äîit‚Äôs an experience. The cool, crisp mountain air adds an extra edge to your cardio, while the alpine views surrounding the courts make every rally feel cinematic. Whether you‚Äôre competing in a tournament or just dinking under bluebird skies, it‚Äôs hard to beat the elevation‚Äîboth in altitude and atmosphere.

‚Äç

7. JW Marriott Phoenix Desert Ridge ‚Äì Phoenix, AZ

‚Äç

‚Äç

Desert pickleball has never looked this good. With 17 dedicated pickleball courts, the JW Marriott Phoenix Desert Ridge is a luxury hotspot for serious players and vacationers alike. Expect pristine surfaces, expert-led clinics, and upscale accommodations all within steps of your next match. Plus, with 300+ days of sunshine a year, you‚Äôll never have to worry about rain delays. Whether you‚Äôre sharpening your third shot or sipping cocktails poolside post-match, this resort brings the heat‚Äîin every way.

‚Äç

8. Timbers Kaua'i ‚Äì H≈çk≈´ala, HI

‚Äç

‚Äç

Yes, Hawaii has pickleball‚Äîand it‚Äôs as magical as it sounds. These courts at Timbers Kaua‚Äôi overlook crystal-clear turquoise waters and palm trees gently swaying in the breeze. It‚Äôs not just a match‚Äîit‚Äôs a memory waiting to happen.

‚Äç

Romance? This is your chance to score big‚Äîon and off the court. Surprise your partner with a weekend escape to paradise where you can chase higher pickleball ratings by day and toast the sunset by night. The views are unreal, the vibes are unbeatable, and honestly... the picture speaks for itself.

‚Äç

9. Old Mill Pickleball Courts ‚Äì Mesquite, NV

‚Äç

‚Äç

Tucked into Nevada‚Äôs desert landscape, the Old Mill Pickleball Courts offer a scenic and community-friendly place to play. With 14 dedicated outdoor courts, this spot is known for its smooth surfaces, warm weather, and welcoming atmosphere.¬†

‚Äç

These courts combine competitive energy with small-town charm. Play a few sets, then cool off in the Pacific. It‚Äôs hard to beat that combo.

‚Äç

10. Highland Park Pickleball Courts ‚Äì South Jordan, UT

‚Äç

‚Äç

Set against the backdrop of Utah‚Äôs striking Wasatch Mountains, Highland Park‚Äôs pickleball courts offer a clean, modern space for casual play and local competition. The friendly community vibe and beautiful surroundings make this suburban gem a standout in the Salt Lake Valley pickleball scene.

Traveling solo? Use the DUPR app to find and connect with players nearby‚Äîso you can hit the courts wherever you go.

title: Pickleball Club Cracks the Code on Retention - 80% of Players Keep Coming Back
summary: Discover how director Ben Rasey built one of the Midwest‚Äôs most successful DUPR pickleball clubs through fun events, strong community, and strategic programming.
content:
While many students slow down over the summer, the University of Florida Pickleball Club stays in full swing. The summer schedule is all about keeping the energy high, the competition strong, and the team connected‚Äîeven when school‚Äôs out and the heat is brutal. It‚Äôs a true showcase of what collegiate pickleball dedication looks like.

‚Äç

Christian Franke, Co-Captain of UF Pickleball, shares how the team trains during the offseason and how they‚Äôre preparing for a big year ahead.

‚Äç

Summer Practice Schedule

‚Äç

Yes, the team continues to train throughout the whole summer. Practices are held twice a week, every Tuesday and Thursday from 6‚Äì8 PM, at the University of Florida‚Äôs on-campus courts. With four courts equipped with temporary lines, the team has plenty of space to stay sharp.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThe setup isn‚Äôt perfect, but it gets the job done,‚Äù says Franke. ‚ÄúIt gives us the space to stay active, get reps in, and keep our game at a high level.‚Äù

‚Äç

Focus on Match Play

‚Äç

The summer focus is simple: Get on the court and compete.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre really centered on match play right now,‚Äù Franke explains. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the best way to stay tournament-ready and work on decision-making in real-time situations. Everyone‚Äôs out there grinding, and it keeps us sharp.‚Äù

‚Äç

Tournaments and Competitive Play

‚Äç

UF Pickleball players are no strangers to summer tournaments.

‚Äç

‚ÄúA lot of our competitive players stay active,‚Äù says Franke. ‚ÄúWe had around ten players at a recent PPA event, and I‚Äôm teaming up with Maxwell Ruyle this weekend for another one.‚Äù

‚Äç

Even off-campus, players are still getting high-level reps.

‚Äç

‚ÄúI‚Äôm back home in Naples this summer, playing at East Naples with Will Lieberman and a few pros. It‚Äôs been a great way to stay in form,‚Äù Franke shares.

‚Äç

Staying Connected Off-Campus

‚Äç

Despite being scattered across the state‚Äîand the country‚Äîthe team stays closely connected.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe keep in touch through group chats and socials. Whether it's training updates or tournament highlights, it helps us stay in the loop and motivated,‚Äù Franke says.

‚Äç

Individual Skill Development

‚Äç

Summer is also the perfect time for targeted improvement.

‚Äç

‚ÄúPersonally, I‚Äôve been focused on developing a consistent flick and improving my shot selection,‚Äù says Franke. ‚ÄúA lot of the team is using this time to sharpen specific parts of their game, whether it‚Äôs footwork, placement, or serve variety.‚Äù

‚Äç

Preparing for the Season Ahead

‚Äç

Without the pressures of school and travel, summer offers space to grow.

‚Äç

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a chance to refine our game without distractions,‚Äù Franke notes. ‚ÄúWhen fall comes, we‚Äôre not just picking up where we left off‚Äîwe‚Äôre showing up better prepared.‚Äù

‚Äç

Looking Ahead to Fall 2025

‚Äç

The team has high aspirations heading into the new season.

‚Äç

‚ÄúI‚Äôm really excited for DUPR Nationals and other high-level events this fall,‚Äù Franke says. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got the talent and the work ethic. Now it‚Äôs about continuing to prove ourselves as one of the top collegiate programs in the country.‚Äù

‚Äç

Whether you're training with your college team or grinding solo over the summer, staying consistent pays off‚Äîespecially in collegiate pickleball. By focusing on match play, skill development, and smart strategy, UF Pickleball is proving that the offseason is where real gains are made. As the new season approaches, players aren‚Äôt just showing up more prepared‚Äîthey‚Äôre climbing in pickleball ratings and sharpening their knowledge of pickleball rules and eligibility requirements, setting themselves up for a strong run at the Collegiate National Championship and beyond.

‚Äç

Want the latest updates on collegiate pickleball? Join our Instagram channel on College Pickleball News and never miss a beat.

title: 5 Pro Tips to Become a 5.0 Pickleball Player
summary: Want to become a 5.0 pickleball player? Pro James Ignatowich shares 5 game-changing tips‚Äîfrom resets to dinks‚Äîplus a bonus DUPR strategy to level up your pickleball ratings.
content:
What started as a college side hustle has now become one of the most active and successful DUPR clubs in the Midwest. Meet Ben Rasey, the Pickleball Director at Lake Geneva Tennis & Pickleball Club, and the driving force behind a community that blends high-level play, heart-pumping cardio, and genuine connection‚Äîall under one roof.

‚Äç

‚Äç

From College Club Founder to DUPR Tournament Director

‚Äç

Ben‚Äôs pickleball journey began in the most grassroots way possible‚Äîplaying at public parks during COVID and being adopted into a local league. After returning to the University of Wisconsin‚ÄìWhitewater in 2020, he realized there was no official pickleball group on campus. So, he built one from scratch.

‚Äç

What began with just 7 players is now the largest club sport at UW‚ÄìWhitewater, with over 100 active members.¬†

‚Äç

‚ÄúIn 2023, I helped raise $18,000 for the club. Back then, no club had that kind of money,‚Äù Ben says.

‚Äç

This experience laid the groundwork for what was to come next.

‚Äç

The Birth of Lake Geneva‚Äôs Pickleball Scene

‚Äç

Ben started working with Lake Geneva Tennis & Pickleball in late 2023, originally running a few events on the side. When the former head pro stepped down, Ben stepped up.

‚Äç

Today, he manages the DUPR club by running monthly tournaments, hosting everything from the Dink Minor League Pickleball events to state championships. Their Christmas tournament draws over 200 players annually, and even their smaller events average 120 players.

‚Äç

What makes Lake Geneva special?

‚Äç

¬†‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not just competitive. We‚Äôre fun. We‚Äôre a family,‚Äù Ben says.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Building Community, One Drill and Cardio Class at a Time

‚Äç

Lake Geneva‚Äôs programming is as diverse as its players. From drill & play sessions and free intro clinics to kids' classes, pizza parties, and the fan-favorite Cardio Pickleball, Ben has turned the club into a hub for players of all ages and levels.

‚Äç

‚ÄúCardio Pickleball is the most fun I‚Äôve ever had running an event,‚Äù Ben shares. ‚ÄúWe cap it at 20 people, play games like King of the Court and Beat the Pro, and just hype people up the whole time.‚Äù

‚Äç

The club recently opened a dedicated 6-court indoor pickleball facility with tournament-level specs: 10 feet of space behind and between courts, sliding court dividers, and upward-facing lights to reduce glare. It‚Äôs built for serious play‚Äîwithout sacrificing the social spirit.

‚Äç

A Culture of Belonging‚Äîand a Bit of Matchmaking

‚Äç

For Ben, the magic of pickleball goes beyond ratings.

‚Äç

‚ÄúPickleball changed my life,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt gave me my closest friends. I‚Äôve seen couples meet at my events. It‚Äôs become this unofficial matchmaker.‚Äù

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

He texts hundreds of players personally before each event, adding little inside jokes and personal notes.

‚Äç

¬†‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre not sociable in this role, you‚Äôre going to fail,‚Äù Ben says. ‚ÄúPeople come back because they feel seen and valued.‚Äù

‚Äç

DUPR-First, Player-Focused

‚Äç

Ben has been a DUPR believer since day one‚Äîstarting at the collegiate level and bringing it straight into Lake Geneva‚Äôs core programming.

‚Äç

‚ÄúPlayers want their ratings to reflect who they really are,‚Äù Ben explains. ‚ÄúWe use DUPR to highlight meaningful competition, not random matchups.‚Äù

‚Äç

Lake Geneva is now ranked in the top 1% of all DUPR clubs‚Äîwith over 6,000 clubs on the platform.¬†

‚Äç

Most Clubs Hope for Retention‚Äî This DUPR Club Hit 80%.¬†

‚Äç

According to Ben, Lake Geneva‚Äôs Christmas-time PPA-style tournament brings in an average of 200 players each year. Their Minor League pickleball events, hosted every 7‚Äì8 weeks, consistently draw between 80 and 144 players.

‚Äç

‚ÄúOur retention rates have been really exciting to track,‚Äù said Ben. ‚ÄúAt one of our recent state championships, 60‚Äì70% of players were brand new‚Äîwhich was awesome. But the tournament before that? We had an 80% return rate. That‚Äôs pretty wild.‚Äù

‚Äç

He credits the strong turnout to running events frequently enough to match players' availability‚Äîwithout overwhelming them.

‚Äç

Advice for New Club Directors

‚Äç

Ben‚Äôs biggest piece of advice?

‚Äç

‚ÄúAsk for help. Listen to players. Talk to other clubs who‚Äôve done it. I had to figure out a lot on my own‚Äîbut now that our club is a big success, clubs are coming to us asking what we‚Äôre doing right.‚Äù

‚Äç

He also keeps it simple: be present, be social, and build relationships.¬†

‚Äç

‚ÄúPickleball is the people's business,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIf they like you, they‚Äôll come back.‚Äù

‚Äç

‚Äç

What‚Äôs Next?

‚Äç

Ben‚Äôs still juggling a full-time job outside of pickleball‚Äîbut don‚Äôt expect him to slow down. He‚Äôs got even more programming, tournaments, and creative events planned as Lake Geneva continues to grow.

‚Äç

And if you‚Äôre ever in Wisconsin, don‚Äôt be surprised if you meet your next doubles partner‚Äîor your future spouse‚Äîat one of Ben‚Äôs events.

‚Äç

Want to start a DUPR Club Like Lake Geneva?

‚Äç

Fill out this form and an account manager will guide you on how to succeed with your pickleball programming.

title: How to Hit the Perfect Slice in Pickleball (Pro Tips from Bobbi Oshiro)
summary: Want to master the slice? Pro player Bobbi Oshiro shares how to hit this underrated shot to stay in points, reduce unforced errors, and boost your pickleball ratings.
content:
Everyone talks about how important dinking is ‚Äîbut how do you actually get to that point in a rally? It doesn‚Äôt just happen. One of the most important steps to get there is learning how to reset the ball from the transition zone.

‚Äç

So what exactly is a reset‚Äîand why is it such a game-changer for players trying to level up their game (and their pickleball ratings)?

‚Äç

Master the Reset in Mid-Court

‚Äç

A reset in pickleball is a soft, controlled shot typically played from mid-court or the transition zone with the purpose of neutralizing your opponent's offensive advantage. It is used to ‚Äúreset‚Äù the pace of the rally, often after a fast exchange or when a player is under pressure.

‚Äç

Instead of hitting a hard counter, players use a reset to drop the ball gently into the non-volley zone (also known as the kitchen), allowing time to recover and transition to the net.

‚Äç

Why is Resetting Important?

‚Äç

Mastering the reset shot is key for:

Regaining control of the point¬†
Moving up into the kitchen¬†
Transitioning from defense to offense
Improving overall court strategy
How to Perform a Reset

‚Äç

Grip and Paddle Angle: Use a soft grip and open paddle face.
Body Position: Stay low with bent knees and keep your paddle out front.
Soft Hands: Focus on absorbing the pace of the ball.
Target Area: Aim for the kitchen with a gentle arc.
Recovery: Be ready to advance to the non-volley line.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Practicing resets regularly will not only help with defense but also improve your confidence during pickleball tournaments where pressure situations are common.

‚Äç

Resets vs. Dinks

‚Äç

‚Äç

While both resets and dinks involve soft touch, they serve different purposes. A dink is typically used in an established kitchen rally, while a reset transitions a point into a dink rally. Both are critical shots to master and heavily influence your pickleball strategy.

‚Äç

Reset To Improve Your Pickleball Ratings

‚Äç

A solid reset can be the difference between a 3.5 and a 4.0 player. The ability to control the pace and force your opponent into neutral exchanges plays a significant role in pickleball ratings and success in pickleball tournaments.

‚Äç

Looking to raise your DUPR? Start by adding resets to your training program. Keep practicing, study the best, and track your progress using DUPR.

‚Äç

title: What Does NVZ Stand For in Pickleball?
summary: Learn what the NVZ (Non-Volley Zone) is in pickleball, why it‚Äôs called the kitchen, and how mastering it can help you improve your DUPR pickleball ratings.
content:
Let‚Äôs be honest: hitting every single ball hard is not going to make you a better player, but adding variation to your game will.¬†

‚Äç

Sometimes, the most annoying shot to deal with is the one that just... stays low and barely even bounces. That‚Äôs the magic of the slice.

‚Äç

And lucky for you, pro player Bobbi Oshiro dropped some gems on how to actually hit it right.

‚Äç
First, What Is a Slice in Pickleball?

‚Äç

In pickleball, a slice‚Äîor backspin shot‚Äîis made by swinging the paddle in a downward motion, which puts reverse spin on the ball. This causes the ball to travel slower, stay low after the bounce, and skid toward your opponent, making it tough for them to attack.

‚Äç

While everyone‚Äôs out there practicing their Erne or lining up a cheeky Nasty Nelson, don‚Äôt forget: mastering the slice (and knowing your pickleball rules) can win you just as many points‚Äîquietly and efficiently.

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

Pro Tips from Bobbi Oshiro: How to Hit the Perfect Slice

‚Äç

Pro pickleball player Bobbi Oshiro shared her go-to technique for slicing, and here's exactly how she breaks it down:

‚Äç

‚úÖ Grip:

‚Äç

Use a continental grip for better control and natural slice mechanics.

‚Äç

‚úÖ Paddle Angle:

‚Äç

Angle the face of your paddle slightly upward‚Äîthis helps apply that crisp backspin.

‚Äç

‚úÖ Swing Path:

‚Äç

Start your swing high

Follow a high-to-low trajectory


Keep your wrist and elbow locked


Use your shoulder to drive the motion, not your wrist
‚Äç

‚úÖ Follow-Through:

‚Äç

Keep it low and forward toward your target. You‚Äôre not trying to hit a winner‚Äîyou're placing a ball that‚Äôs tough to attack.

‚Äç
When Should You Use a Slice?

‚Äç

According to Bobbi, here are the best times to use a slice:

‚Äç

When pulled wide or in a defensive position


To reset the point and buy yourself time


To mix up your spin game and keep opponents guessing


To force a low bounce and make their next shot tougher

‚Äç

Slice Your Way to Higher Pickleball Ratings

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

Smarter shot selections lead to more wins‚Äîand that means higher pickleball ratings. Simple math.

‚Äç

The perfect slice is subtle, sneaky, and strategic. Use it to:

‚Äç

Stay in more points


Reduce unforced errors


Force weaker returns and set up your counterattack


‚Äç

Want to see how your slice impacts your game?
Try out these tips on your next pickleball tournament and see your pickleball rating move up.¬†

‚Äç

title: What Is a Dink in Pickleball?
summary: Learn what a dink is in pickleball, why it‚Äôs crucial for strategy, and how mastering it can improve your pickleball ratings. Discover tips from top players on how to dink to win more points.
content:
Whether you‚Äôre new to pickleball or just eager to learn pickleball rules, you‚Äôve definitely heard about the NVZ - which stands for Non-Volley Zone.

The Non-Volley Zone‚Äîaka The The Kitchen‚Äîis one of the most important (and misunderstood) parts of the game. Master it, and you will be one step closer to improving your pickleball ratings.¬†

‚Äç

What Is the Non-Volley Zone?

‚Äç

The Non-Volley Zone (NVZ)‚Äîbetter known as the kitchen‚Äîis the 7-foot area on both sides of the net.

‚Äç

Let‚Äôs be clear: It‚Äôs totally legal to stand in the kitchen‚Äîjust not while hitting a volley, or if your momentum carries you into it after a volley.

‚Äç

Thinking about hitting an Erne or attacking up at the net?

‚Äç
Know the rules first‚Äîor risk giving up free points.

‚Äç

Because when it comes to your DUPR pickleball ratings, every point counts.

‚Äç

Why Is the NVZ Called "The Kitchen"?

‚Äç

‚Äç

‚Äç

There‚Äôs no definitive origin story for why it‚Äôs called ‚Äúthe kitchen‚Äù in pickleball, but the most widely accepted theory links it to shuffleboard. In shuffleboard, the ‚Äúkitchen‚Äù is a penalty zone‚Äîland there, and you lose 10 points. While the rules are different, the concept is similar: it‚Äôs a restricted space where bad positioning can cost you. In pickleball, stepping into the kitchen at the wrong time‚Äîespecially during a volley‚Äîresults in a fault. (Thankfully, it‚Äôs just one point, not ten.)

‚Äç

The nickname isn‚Äôt officially documented, but it‚Äôs stuck‚Äîand for good reason. If you‚Äôre serious about your game (and your DUPR rating), you‚Äôll learn to respect the kitchen.

‚Äç

The Importance of the NVZ in Pickleball Tournaments

‚Äç

Mastering your footwork around the Non-Volley Zone (NVZ) is essential‚Äîespecially in tournament play, where the pace is faster and margins are tight.

High-level players don‚Äôt avoid the kitchen‚Äîthey use it. The NVZ becomes a tool to slow the game down, control tempo, reset points, and bait opponents into making mistakes.

‚Äç

üèì Key NVZ Tips:

‚Äç

Stay low and balanced‚Äîgood footwork = fewer pop-ups


Dink with purpose, not just to keep the rally going


Use angles to pull your opponent wide and open up the court


Know when to reset vs. attack‚Äîtiming is everything

‚Äç


üé• Check out Bobbi Oshiro‚Äôs tips on using the NVZ effectively in singles play.

‚Äç

NVZ Rules You Must Know

‚Äç

Here are some core pickleball rules regarding the NVZ:

‚Äç

No volleying while touching the NVZ line: Your feet must be behind the line if you want to hit a volley.

‚Äç


Momentum counts: Even if you hit the volley outside the NVZ, if your momentum carries you into the zone afterward, it's a fault.

‚Äç

Dinking is legal: You can hit the ball inside the kitchen if it has bounced first. This opens up one of the most strategic plays in pickleball‚Äîthe dink.


NVZ Strategy

‚Äç

Players who use the NVZ effectively tend to:

‚Äç

Extend rallies


Reduce unforced errors


Win more dink battles


Perform better in competitive environments

‚Äç

Whether you call it the Non-Volley Zone or the kitchen, mastering this space is vital for players looking to excel in pickleball. From casual play to competitive pickleball tournaments, understanding how to move, position, and strike in relation to the NVZ can give you a strategic edge.

‚Äç

Want to raise your pickleball rating? Start by mastering the NVZ‚Äîand let the numbers speak for themselves.

‚Äç

title: What Is an ATP Shot in Pickleball? How (and When) to Use It
summary: Learn what an ATP shot is in pickleball, when to use it, and how to execute it like the pros. Discover the rules, strategies, and tips to master this advanced shot and boost your pickleball ratings.
content:
Rome, Italy ‚Äî June 13, 2025 ‚Äî DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) is proud to announce its official partnership with the Federazione Italiana Tennis e Padel (FITP), making DUPR the rating system for all sanctioned pickleball activity in Italy.

‚Äç

This is a major milestone for DUPR and the global growth of pickleball. Italy has quickly become one of the most exciting pickleball markets in Europe ‚Äî with thousands of new players, clubs forming every month, and serious momentum behind national and international competition.

‚Äç

‚ÄúItaly is not just growing in numbers ‚Äî it‚Äôs growing with ambition,‚Äù said Mortada Stitou, Vice-President of Commercial at DUPR. ‚ÄúFITP‚Äôs leadership is building a true ecosystem, and we‚Äôre honored they chose DUPR as the foundation. This gives every Italian player access to the same trusted, global rating used by pros and amateurs around the world.‚Äù

‚Äç

With this partnership, all FITP-sanctioned events and clubs will use DUPR to track player progress and seed matches. Italian players can now see how they stack up on a worldwide scale ‚Äî with real-time updates, match history, and cross-border comparability.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe believe that fair and transparent competition is essential to the sport,‚Äù said Giulia Soresina from FITP. ‚ÄúDUPR brings exactly that ‚Äî a reliable rating, easy to use, and trusted internationally. This is a big step forward for the Italian pickleball community.‚Äù

‚Äç

Why It Matters

‚Äç

Italy is a gateway to broader European adoption.
DUPR helps standardize competition ahead of future international events.
It brings player development, tournament planning, and talent scouting onto one platform.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen what happens when a country fully adopts DUPR ‚Äî tournaments get better, players level up faster, and clubs thrive,‚Äù said Stitou. ‚ÄúItaly is next.‚Äù

‚Äç

About DUPR

‚Äç

DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) is the premier global pickleball rating system and technology platform, trusted by the world's leading clubs, tournaments, leagues, and players. DUPR's dynamic rating system unifies pickleball across age, gender, and location by analyzing match results to accurately evaluate all players across a 2.000 - 8.000 scale. DUPR is the official pickleball rating of leagues, tournaments and clubs around the world, including United Pickleball Association (UPA), PPA, Major League Pickleball (MLP), Pickleball.com, Life Time, The Picklr, National Team Pickleball League, National Pickleball League. It also owns and operates Minor League Pickleball and Collegiate Pickleball, two of the biggest amateur leagues in the sport. Players and operators can visit www.dupr.com to sign up and learn more.

‚Äç

About FITP

The Federazione Italiana Tennis e Padel is Italy‚Äôs governing body for tennis, padel, and pickleball. It organizes national competitions, oversees player development, and promotes the growth of racket sports throughout Italy.¬†

title: Arizona‚Äôs Master Instructor Turned His Family into a Pickleball Dynasty
summary: Brad Lees, a certified RPPK Master Instructor and DUPR Coach, shares how structured coaching, pickleball ratings, and family passion turned Arizona into a rising pickleball powerhouse.
content:
If you've ever played or watched a competitive pickleball match, you may have heard players or commentators mention an "ATP" shot. But what exactly is an ATP in pickleball‚Äîand how can it improve your game and your pickleball ratings?

‚Äç

What does ATP stand for in pickleball?

‚Äç

ATP stands for Around The Post, one of the most exciting and skillful shots in pickleball. Unlike most shots that travel over the net, an ATP travels around the net post‚Äîcompletely outside the boundary of the net‚Äîand still lands inbounds on your opponent‚Äôs side.

‚Äç

Is the ATP Legal?

‚Äç

Yes! According to official pickleball rules, a ball does not need to go over the net, as long as:

‚Äç

It crosses to the opponent‚Äôs side,


Lands within the court boundaries, and


The player does not touch the net or opponent‚Äôs court..


When to Hit an ATP Shot

‚Äç

ATP opportunities usually happen when your opponent hits a sharp-angled dink or drive that pulls you far off the court. If that ball bounces near the sideline, you may have a clean angle to hit an ATP.

‚Äç

Key tip from the pros: Be patient and wait as long as you can to hit the shot.¬† The longer you wait, the better angle you have to hit the ball around the post.

‚Äç

The ATP and Competitive Pickleball Tournaments

‚Äç

In high-level pickleball tournaments, the ATP isn‚Äôt just a flashy shot‚Äîit can be a momentum-shifting tactic. Players who master it can surprise opponents, win crowd-pleasing points, and show off a deep understanding of pickleball strategy.

‚Äç

Key Pickleball Rules for ATP Shots

‚Äç

You can go around the net post, but cannot touch the net, posts, or your opponent‚Äôs court while the ball is live.


The ball must land in bounds, even though it travels around the net.


If your momentum carries you onto the opponent‚Äôs court‚Äîor if anything you‚Äôre wearing or holding (like a paddle or hat) crosses the line before your shot‚Äîit‚Äôs a fault.


You can‚Äôt cross the imaginary extension of the net unless you‚Äôve already made contact with the ball (unless the ball has already bounced on your end of the court and has bounced back to the opponent‚Äôs end. Yeah, it gets complicated!)


How to Practice the ATP

‚Äç

Want to add the ATP to your game? Try this:

‚Äç

Drill wide-angle dinks with a partner to simulate real ATP scenarios.


Focus on footwork‚Äîpositioning early is everything.


Work on paddle angle and follow-through to keep your shot low and in bounds.

‚Äç



The ATP is more than just a flashy highlight‚Äîit‚Äôs a powerful, legal weapon when executed correctly. Whether you're chasing higher DUPR ratings or just want to win more games, learning to hit the Around The Post shot gives you a serious edge.

‚Äç

title: Introducing DUPR+: Pickleball Just Got Better
summary: DUPR+ is a premium pickleball membership created with the community in mind‚Äîoffering ad-free access, exclusive events, and big discounts on paddles, balls, and more. Try it free for 7 days.
content:
When Brad Lees first picked up a paddle, he had no idea it would change the dynamic of his entire family. What started as a "stupid little game" he tried with his kids in the neighborhood quickly spiraled into something much more. Today, Brad is a DUPR Coach, RPPK Master Instructor, and proud dad to a crew of five highly rated pickleball players.

‚Äç
‚Äç
A Family That Pickleballs Together

‚Äç

"We have five kids; my daughter is my mixed partner, and my sons coach as well,‚Äù Brad shared. ‚ÄúOne's a 5.7 DUPR, the other is a 5.0 and my daughter is a 4.5"

‚Äç

Even cooler? Their pickleball skills helped them to transition to other sports. It took his daughter only 6 months to learn tennis and become #2 on her high school team, qualifying for the State Championship. According to Brad, the transition was seamless. "She picked up volleys and quick hands from pickleball. That gave her the confidence to rush the net in tennis while others stayed back."

‚Äç
‚Äç
Calling out the "Anyone Can Teach" Myth

‚Äç

"Anyone can teach... But not everyone can teach well," Brad joked.

‚Äç

What separates a great coach from a decent player, he explained, is patience, strategy, and an actual framework.

‚Äç

A lot of high-rated players think they can coach‚Äîbut playing well doesn‚Äôt always translate to teaching well. ‚ÄúWe need structure in this sport,‚Äù Brad explained. ‚ÄúCertification ensures you‚Äôre not passing down bad habits or outdated strategies.‚Äù

‚Äç
How DUPR Ratings Changed the Game

‚Äç

Brad doesn‚Äôt just coach‚Äîhe rates. As a DUPR Coach, Brad runs multiple rating sessions each week, using them not only to help players get started, but also to build long-term relationships.

‚Äç

‚ÄúA lot of the Picklr facilities are DUPR-limiting their leagues and open plays. If someone doesn‚Äôt have a DUPR, they can‚Äôt even get into those events.‚Äù

‚Äç

More and more clubs are making having a DUPR rating a requirement, and that gives certified DUPR Coaches like Brad the chance to connect with players right from the beginning.

‚Äç

‚ÄúPlayers meet you during the session and see how you coach. It‚Äôs a great way to build relationships‚Äîand grow your coaching business.‚Äù

‚Äç

Once a player has a rating, the journey doesn‚Äôt stop there. Brad works with many players whose goal is simple: raise their DUPR.

‚Äç
‚Äç
‚ÄúI have several athletes that I work with who are always trying to raise their DUPR. That‚Äôs their ultimate goal. So we‚Äôre coming up with strategies, matches, and game plans that can help them get there.‚Äù

‚Äç

For Brad‚Äôs students, coaching goes beyond technique‚Äîit‚Äôs about access. To better matchups, more competitive events, and a better overall experience. And it all starts with the right rating.

‚Äç
‚ÄúEveryone thinks they‚Äôre better than they really are."

‚Äç

‚ÄúPeople sign up for tournaments thinking they‚Äôre a 3.5, then get trashed and only play two games after paying a lot of money,‚Äù Brad noted.

‚Äç

That‚Äôs why getting rated by a DUPR Coach matters. It‚Äôs the fastest, fairest way to figure out where you actually stand‚Äîso you can start in the right bracket, have a great time, and build from there.

‚Äç
Why Arizona Is Leading the Pickleball Boom Right Now

‚Äç

According to Coach Brad Lees, Arizona‚Äôs rise as a pickleball hotspot comes down to three key factors: great weather, an active outdoor lifestyle, and a rapid increase in courts and events.

‚Äç

The state regularly hosts major tournaments like PPA and Major League Pickleball, drawing large crowds and growing interest at every level. Arizona is also home to many local pro players, adding to the region‚Äôs competitive energy.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThere are five Picklr facilities in the Valley already,‚Äù Brad shared, ‚Äúand there are even plans for a new indoor facility with 50 courts.‚Äù

‚Äç

¬†With more events, more courts, and more talent, it‚Äôs no surprise amateur participation is surging across the state.

‚Äç
Why Coaching Education Matters

‚Äç

Coach Brad Lees believes structured programs like RPPK are essential for growing the sport the right way. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre making up your own curriculum every time, players get inconsistent instruction‚Äîand that‚Äôs not good for anyone,‚Äù he shared.¬†

‚Äç

While it‚Äôs natural to adjust lessons for different players, a strong foundation helps ensure that players learn the right habits from day one and can actually progress.

‚Äç
RPPK Isn‚Äôt Just About Curriculum

‚Äç

Beyond the teaching framework, Brad pointed out the practical perks of certification‚Äîlike liability insurance, which is often required at parks and facilities. ‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre coaching without insurance, you‚Äôre taking a big risk. Accidents happen‚Äîbetter to be covered.‚Äù

‚Äç

RPPK also gives coaches credibility, structure, and tools that help them deliver more consistent, effective instruction‚Äîand stand out in a growing field.

‚Äç
The Future: DUPR + RPPK as the Standard

‚Äç

Brad envisions a future where every club and league uses DUPR ratings and RPPK certification as the norm.



‚ÄúWe‚Äôve never had one clear coaching standard in pickleball. But with RPPK‚Äôs structure and DUPR‚Äôs reach, we finally could. That‚Äôs how we build long-term growth‚Äîand do it the right way.

‚Äç

Want to learn more about becoming a Master Instructor? Click here to explore your next step.

title: What Is a Momentum Fault in Pickleball? (And How to Avoid It)
summary: Learn what causes a momentum fault in pickleball and how to avoid it. Understand pickleball rules, real-match examples, and tips to improve your footwork and boost your pickleball ratings.
content:
MLP Midseason Check-In, Standings Breakdown & Playoff Predictions

‚Äç

We‚Äôre nearly halfway through the 2025 MLP season, and the pressure is building. Daytona (June 5‚Äì8) marks the fifth event on the calendar, with five more stops still to come before the postseason begins.

‚Äç

With pickleball ratings and team performance shaping the playoff picture, let‚Äôs break down where teams stand after Phoenix‚Äîand who‚Äôs in (and out) of contention.

Current Standings (Post-Phoenix)

‚Äç

‚Äç

Ranked by Points per Match to account for unequal games played

‚Äç

The Battle for the Final Playoff Spots

‚Äç

It‚Äôs shaping up to be a three-team race for the final two playoff spots. The Utah Black Diamonds, Miami Pickleball Club, and Chicago Slice are all within striking distance heading into the second half of the season.

‚Äç

Shoutout to Chicago, who had to completely redraft their roster after last season and still managed to stay in the hunt. With five events left, momentum swings, injuries, burnouts and a sense of urgency could shake things up quickly. And if sports have taught us anything‚Äîit‚Äôs that passion and grit can go a long way!

‚Äç

Lack of Parity: A Growing Concern?

‚Äç

A recent stat shared by Matty Pickles (and featured in The Dink newsletter) highlighted something striking:¬†

‚Äç

The top 8 teams are a combined 42‚Äì0 against the bottom 8.¬†

‚Äç

‚Äç

Yep‚Äîundefeated. That‚Äôs a huge gap.

‚Äç

All four teams that moved up from last season‚Äôs Challenger division currently sit in the bottom 8, showing just how tough it is to draft well when depth in the MLP talent pool is still developing. Many of these teams had to take chances on new talent, which often takes time to pay off.

‚Äç

That said, if any bottom-8 team is going to pull off an upset, my bet‚Äôs on Miami. Any team going against them must be mentally present to fight. They‚Äôve got fire and fight‚Äîtwo things you can‚Äôt coach.

‚Äç

Newbies vs. Veterans

‚Äç

Back in March, I published a blog on the MLP roster updates following the Premier and Challenger Drafts held on March 2‚Äì3. I highlighted the wave of new talent entering the league this season ‚Äî and now that we‚Äôre halfway through, let‚Äôs take a look at how those players have performed so far.

‚Äç

At the time, I noted 34 new players had been drafted across both Premier and Challenger divisions‚Äînone of whom had played an MLP match in 2024. Most were picked in the 5th or 6th round, so many haven‚Äôt seen any court time yet.

‚Äç

Those who have broken into the starting lineups include:
Victoria Di Muzio, Liz Truluck, Max Freeman, Mya Bui, Alex Walker, and, yes‚Äî¬æ of the NY Hustlers.¬†

‚Äç

From that group, Victoria, Max, Mya, and the Hustlers trio have consistently started matches for their teams. Mya Bui stands out as the strongest performer so far, though all five are currently ranked outside the Top 50 in the player standings.

‚Äç

It‚Äôs worth remembering: most veteran players have been competing at a high level for years. These newcomers are still adjusting to the pace and pressure of top-tier play. With time, mentorship, and experience, several of them could absolutely become key contributors in future seasons.

‚Äç

üèÜ Semifinal Predictions: Early Call

‚Äç

You can prove me wrong later, but I‚Äôm seeing a repeat of last season‚Äôs semifinals.¬†

‚Äç

Right now, my top four picks heading into August are:

St. Louis Shock


New Jersey 5s


Dallas Flash


Texas Ranchers



These teams have shown the most consistency and depth so far this season.

‚Äç

As for the final? I‚Äôd put my money on a Dallas Flash vs. St. Louis Shock matchup. Two strong, well-balanced rosters that know how to close.

‚Äç

Let‚Äôs see how it plays out.

‚Äç

title: What Is a Regional Showdown in Minor League Pickleball?
summary: Discover how Regional Showdowns in Minor League Pickleball work, how to qualify for the National Championship, and how these events boost your DUPR pickleball ratings.
content:
Ever lost a point after a killer volley‚Äîonly to hear ‚Äúmomentum fault‚Äù?

‚Äç

It‚Äôs one of the most frustrating ways to lose a point in pickleball. You hit a winning shot near the kitchen line, but your foot‚Äîor even your paddle‚Äîends up in the non-volley zone. The point? Gone.

‚Äç

If you're aiming to improve your pickleball ratings,, don‚Äôt just learn the lesser-known¬† pickleball rules‚Äîapply them.

‚Äç

What Is a Momentum Fault in Pickleball?

‚Äç

A momentum fault happens when a player's motion‚Äîsuch as their follow-through after a volley‚Äîcauses them or anything they‚Äôre wearing to touch the non-volley zone or ‚Äúkitchen.‚Äù It‚Äôs a fault because the player‚Äôs momentum wasn‚Äôt fully stopped before making contact with the NVZ.¬†

‚Äç

Momentum isn‚Äôt considered complete until you‚Äôve regained control and balance‚Äîenough to safely step away from the NVZ. There‚Äôs no time limit: if your momentum carries you into the kitchen after a volley at any point, it‚Äôs still a fault.

‚Äç

This includes:

‚Äç

Your foot or any body part touching the kitchen line or floor after a volley.


Your paddle, hat, or any part of your body or gear touching the kitchen‚Äîeven after the ball is ‚Äúdead.‚Äù

‚Äç

üëâ Rule of thumb: If your body or gear ends up in the kitchen because of momentum after a volley, it‚Äôs a fault.

‚Äç

What‚Äôs the Non-Volley Zone (AKA The Kitchen)?

‚Äç

The non-volley zone, or "kitchen," is a 7-foot area on both sides of the net marked by a line. You cannot volley the ball while standing in‚Äîor stepping into‚Äîthis zone, including the line itself.

‚Äç

Note: You can stand in the kitchen, just not while volleying.

‚Äç

Common Examples of Momentum Faults

‚Äç

Here‚Äôs how momentum faults sneak up on even experienced players:

‚Äç

1. Singles Match

‚Äç

You are playing a pickleball tournament and you stretch to volley a ball near the kitchen. The shot lands‚Äîclean‚Äîbut your toe lands on the line a split second later. Fault.

‚Äç

2. Doubles Play

‚Äç

Your partner finishes a great volley at the net, but they stumble forward into the kitchen. Momentum fault, even if the ball was unreachable.

‚Äç

3. Equipment Drop

‚Äç

Your paddle drops into the kitchen after a volley‚Äîstill a momentum fault.

‚Äç

How to Avoid Momentum Faults

‚Äç

Improving your footwork and body control near the kitchen line can help you avoid losing points.

Try these tips:

‚Äç

Stay balanced after every volley‚Äîdon‚Äôt overreach.


Avoid lunging unless you‚Äôre sure you can stop safely.


Drill footwork near the kitchen so it becomes second nature.


Practice ‚Äúfreeze‚Äù drills to control forward movement after contact.


Watch for ‚Äúline creep‚Äù‚Äîinching forward during fast-paced points leads to accidental faults.

‚Äç

Momentum faults are avoidable‚Äîbut only if you know what to watch for.

‚Äç

Whether you're training for a local pickleball tournament or playing socially, minimizing avoidable faults is key to progress as a player and start boosting your pickleball ratings.

‚Äç

Next time you‚Äôre chasing that perfect volley, don‚Äôt let your momentum turn a winning shot into a kitchen disaster.

‚Äç

title: New Eligibility Requirements for the 2025‚Äì26 Collegiate Pickleball Season
summary: Get the latest updates on collegiate pickleball for 2025‚Äì26: new eligibility rules, tournament bids, and how to boost your pickleball ratings this season.
content:
If you‚Äôve played pickleball tournaments, you know that tempo matters. One small‚Äîbut important‚Äîrule that helps keep things moving is the 10-second rule.

‚Äç

So, what is it?

‚Äç

The 10-Second Rule in Pickleball consists of the following: Once the score is called, the server has 10 seconds to start the serve. That‚Äôs it. No long pauses, no endless bouncing the ball‚Äîjust call it and go. The rule exists to keep the game fair and flowing, especially in competitive settings.

‚Äç

Why does it matter?

‚Äç

This isn‚Äôt just a nitpicky rule. In high-level play‚Äîor any match that counts toward your pickleball ratings‚Äîthose little delays can break rhythm and shift momentum. Pickleball rules keep things clean and consistent.

‚Äç

Here‚Äôs what it helps with:

‚Äç

‚úÖ Keeps the pace up ‚Äì Nobody likes standing around.


‚úÖ Stops mind games ‚Äì No stalling to throw off your opponent.


‚úÖ Makes it fair ‚Äì Everyone follows the same countdown.
‚Äç

‚Äç


What if you take too long?

‚Äç

If you wait more than 10 seconds after the score is called, it‚Äôs a fault. You lose the point.¬† And in a tight match? That can hurt‚Äîespecially when your DUPR rating is on the line.

‚Äç

How to avoid a violation:

‚Äç

Have a go-to pre-serve routine. Keep it short and repeatable.


Stay tuned in‚Äîlisten for the score to be called.


No official clock, so get a feel for 10 seconds and stay within it.

‚Äç

It might seem like a small detail, but respecting the 10-second rule shows discipline‚Äîand it can make a real difference in how your match unfolds. Whether you‚Äôre trying to improve your pickleball ratings or just play better pickleball, sticking to this rule is part of showing up like a serious competitor.

‚Äç

title: What is a Nasty Nelson?

content:

Each year, we make key updates to support players, improve event structure, and elevate the sport. Whether you're chasing higher pickleball ratings or building team chemistry, the 2025‚Äì26 season is packed with new opportunities to grow and compete.

‚Äç

Starting in the 2025‚Äì26 season, we‚Äôre adjusting the credit hour requirements for undergraduate players to better reflect the evolving level of competition. Our goal is to ensure student-athletes are maintaining academic commitments while still representing their schools with pride.

Campus Regionals continue to be a critical part of the Collegiate Pickleball Tour, helping new and returning schools compete for a shot at Nationals. In 2024, we hosted 16 Regionals, and in 2025 we hosted 14‚Äîeven with a shortened season.

In 2025‚Äì26, we‚Äôre dedicating 30 of the 64 total Nationals bids to Campus Regionals‚Äîaiming for 15 Campus Regionals each semester. These tournaments will follow the Collegiate Pickleball Tour Format, creating a clear and unified path to the Collegiate National Championship.

title: What Is a Dream Ticket Team in The Dink Minor League Pickleball?
summary: Learn what a Dream Ticket is, how to qualify, and why it‚Äôs your clearest path to the 2025 The Dink MiLP National Championship and $100K+ in prize money.
content:
Just the name itself can stir up quite some chaos on the pickleball court. A Nasty Nelson is the kind of shot that can flip the momentum of a game, leaving opponents flustered and teammates grinning at the well-executed disruption. But what exactly is a Nasty Nelson, and why does it carry such a mischievous reputation?

‚Äç

Just ask Mariana Paredes, who famously pulled off a Nasty Nelson at 10-4 match point to clinch a gold medal at the US Open. In her post-match interview with The Dink, she said, ‚ÄúI saw an opportunity and took it. Nothing wrong with that!‚Äù Bold? Definitely. Controversial? Maybe. But moments like that are exactly why the Nasty Nelson continues to spark debate on pickleball courts everywhere.
‚Äç
The rudest shot in pickleball?

‚Äç

In pickleball, the serve is your first chance to set the tone, control the pace, and occasionally catch your opponents off guard. A Nasty Nelson does exactly that‚Äîit‚Äôs a serve aimed intentionally at the non-receiving partner, trying to hit them before the ball bounces. If it hits the non-receiver player, it results in an immediate fault on the receiving team‚Äîone of the few ways to score outright off a serve.¬†

‚Äç

It‚Äôs not illegal under the official pickleball rules, but it‚Äôs definitely unconventional‚Äîand depending on who you ask, maybe even a little unsportsmanlike. If you‚Äôre chasing better pickleball ratings, a well-timed Nasty Nelson might score you a point‚Ä¶ but it could also cost you a friend.

‚Äç
When to execute a Nasty Nelson?

‚Äç

Some players use the Nasty Nelson strategically, especially in official pickleball tournaments where every point counts. If the opposing partner isn‚Äôt paying attention or stands too close to the kitchen, they‚Äôre a prime target. Others argue that it goes against the spirit of the game, preferring serves that challenge the receiver through placement and spin rather than deception.

‚Äç
Why is it called Nasty Nelson?¬†

‚Äç

Tim ‚ÄúThe Puppet Master‚Äù Nelson is the guy behind the shot everyone loves to argue about‚Äîthe Nasty Nelson. He‚Äôs a top-level pickleball player known for his bold (and sometimes sneaky) style of play. The shot was named after him for a reason‚Äîhe used it often, and with zero shame. He‚Äôs also famous for doing a little puppeteer hand motion after pulling it off, just to rub it in a bit more.

‚Äç

‚Äç
Should you use it?

‚Äç

Like any shot in pickleball‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs a third shot drop, ATP, or Erne‚Äîthe Nasty Nelson is a tool. Whether you use it or avoid it depends on your style of play.

‚Äç

One thing‚Äôs for sure: if you're serious about climbing the pickleball ratings ladder or competing in Minor League Pickleball events, understanding shots like this gives you an edge‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs just to defend yourself against the opponent trying to pull one over on you.

‚Äç

So next time you‚Äôre on the court, stay alert during the serve. You never know when a little bit of ‚Äúnasty‚Äù might be headed your way.

‚Äç

Adding Value With DUPR+

When The Flying Pickle¬† decided to integrate DUPR+ into its Pro Membership package, it wasn‚Äôt about raising prices or chasing revenue. As Club Director Tristan Belue explains, it was about one thing: adding value for their most dedicated players.

Why Other Clubs Are Watching

The success of The Flying Pickle‚Äôs Meridian location has sparked plans for franchising the model. summary: Learn what an Erne is in pickleball, why it‚Äôs legal, and how to use it strategically. Discover tips to master this advanced shot and boost your DUPR pickleball ratings.
content:
The biggest team event in amateur pickleball is back. The 2025 Dink Minor League Pickleball (MiLP) National Championship is officially set for December 3-7.¬†

‚Äç

Thousands of amateur players across the United States and around the world compete all year long for a chance to qualify. The best of the best will descend upon Pickler Universe in Dallas to fight for national glory and a piece of the $100,000 prize pool.¬†

‚Äç

¬†A Global Stage for Amateur Pickleball Talent

‚Äç

This isn‚Äôt just a national event ‚Äî it‚Äôs a global stage. Players from over a dozen countries are battling through their own national pathways for the chance to represent their country. It‚Äôs a truly international showcase, powered by DUPR ratings and driven by talent, teamwork, and ambition.

‚Äç

The Path to Nationals: Leaderboards, Dream Tickets & More

‚Äç

The 2025 Season runs from October 15, 2024, through October 20, 2025. During this time, players of all ages and skill levels compete in official MiLP tournaments to earn leaderboard points and Dream Tickets by performing well at events such as:

‚Äç

State Championships across Oklahoma, Arizona, Illinois, Colorado, and more
Regional Showdowns in Texas, New Jersey, Florida, California, and beyond

‚Äç

Anyone with a DUPR account can compete in State Championships and Regional Showdowns. But at Nationals, it's invite-only.¬†

‚Äç

Who Can Play at Nationals?

‚Äç

Dream Ticket teams: Teams that win gold at a State Championship or Regional Showdown earn a Dream Ticket ‚Äî an automatic invitation to Nationals. Each team must include at least two original players from the qualifying event and will compete in the same division they qualified in (unless player substitutions affect their DUPR aggregate).
Top-ranked players from the 2025 National DUPR Leaderboard will receive an invitation to assemble their teams
State Pro League and MLP-affiliated teams via Wild Card bids

‚Äç

Confirmed State Pro Leagues include:

‚Äç

All Florida Pro League
Michigan Pickleball League
Oklahoma Premier Pickleball League
Wichita Premier Pickleball League

‚Äç

‚Äç

MLP Teams competing at Nationals:
