content:
PodPlay is excited to announce the launch of DUPR Challenge Matches for clubs with PodPlay Pro Monitors. Just choose ‚ÄúSubmit Results‚Äù at the beginning of a match and results are automatically reported to DUPR at the end of the match.¬†

‚Äç

‚Äç

Players no longer need to login to DUPR, find the other players, enter scores, and wait for confirmations. All those steps are condensed into a single press of a button at the beginning of the match. For clubs that choose to default to Submit Results for a court or event, the single button press is eliminated, and what is left is totally frictionless reporting to DUPR.¬†

‚Äç

Why it Matters

DUPR stands for Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating. Putting Universal in the name turned out to be prescient, as DUPR has become the universal standard for pickleball ratings.¬†

>1 million players
>5 million matches records
>5,000 pickleball clubs and facilities
158 countries represented

‚Äç

DUPR is a rating system designed to provide accurate and dynamic player ratings. Unlike traditional static rating systems, DUPR's algorithm continuously adjusts ratings based on match results, ensuring that ratings reflect current skill levels. DUPR's dynamic rating system unifies pickleball across age, gender, and location by analyzing match results to accurately evaluate all players across a 2.000 - 8.000 scale.

‚Äç

DUPR promotes fair and balanced gameplay by accurately assessing player skill levels. Accurate and accessible ratings help drive:

Skill Development. Players can track their progress and identify areas for improvement through their DUPR ratings.
Precise Programming. DUPR allows clubs to create programming for specific skill levels and require a DUPR rating to participate, eliminating the issue of matching players with very different skill levels.¬†
Community Engagement. DUPR fosters a vibrant pickleball community by providing a platform for players to connect, compete, and grow together.

‚Äç

DUPR has achieved broad adoption across the pickleball community. The biggest barrier to greater adoption and more games being reported is the friction currently involved in submitting scores. PodPlay‚Äôs DUPR Challenge Match feature eliminates all of that friction.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Eliminating Friction is a Core PodPlay Design Principle

In Your App is Your Front Door, we wrote about PodPlay‚Äôs obsession with creating the kind of customer experience for end users that is so good they want to tell others about it. An insanely great technology experience is one that allows customers to get what they want with as little work as possible. When it comes to the user experience, less is often more. Some of the areas where PodPlay has made dramatic improvements over legacy systems are:

‚Äç

Onboarding. Customers are able to browse court availability, programming, and more before creating a customer account. We don‚Äôt make customers fill out a long form and give you their payment info before they know what you offer. Create too much friction at onboarding and customers may give up before they even get started.
Quick Replays. Customers love capturing magic moments and sharing them with their network. They DO NOT love doing any work to get those replays. Make them set up a camera, scan a QR Code, or create a login on a separate system to get their highlights and usage plummets. PodPlay‚Äôs game-changing replay functionality is designed to allow players to capture great moments without taking them out of the flow of their game.¬†
Coach Connect. Using PodPlay‚Äôs Coach Connect feature, customers are able to discover, coordinate and pay coaches with a couple of clicks. No e-mails, no texts, no need for Venmo after the lesson. By eliminating friction, the feature drives large increases in coaching activity.¬†

‚Äç

With DUPR Challenge Matches, we can add reporting scores to DUPR to the list of functions where PodPlay has collapsed a multi-step process into a single step.¬†

‚Äç

‚Äç

The Pickleball Tournament of the Future

PodPlay does not yet offer tournament and league management, but these are areas we plan to tackle in 2025. By combining tournament and league management with PodPlay Scoreboards and the DUPR Challenge Match feature, it is not hard to imagine a massive reduction in the need for tournament and league staffing. Stay tuned for future developments!

‚Äç

‚Äç

The PodPlay Advantage

PodPlay gives venue operators all the tools they need to digitally manage a physical space - integrating video replays, automated scoreboards, and autonomous functionality with a reservation engine, event management, coach connect, membership module, and payments.¬†

‚Äç

Originally built to power PingPod, the network of futuristic autonomous ping pong clubs, PodPlay is now being used to manage venues across pickleball, padel, ping pong, golf simulators, racing simulators, soccer and pool, with more experience verticals to come in the future.

‚Äç

If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, request a demo.

‚Äç

title: Indoor Pickleball: Master the Basics, Elevate Your Game
summary: Learn about the best indoor pickleball strategies, essential equipment, and competitive leagues. Plus,track your progress with DUPR‚Äîthe leading pickleball rating system.
content:
If you're new to pickleball, one of the first questions you might ask is, what does a pickleball look like? The pickleballs appearance is one of the most distinctive aspects of the sport. Let‚Äôs break down the pickleballs design, shape, texture, and other important features to give you a better idea of what makes this ball so unique.

‚Äç

Pickleballs Shape and Size

The most obvious feature of a pickleball is its shape. It is round, like most balls, but it‚Äôs design sets it apart. Pickleballs typically measure between 2.87 and 2.97 inches in diameter, making them slightly smaller than a tennis ball but still large enough to handle comfortably. The pickleball ball sizes are standardized for most play, whether you're on an indoor or outdoor court.

‚Äç

Pickleballs Material and Texture

When you look at a pickleball up close, you'll notice it‚Äôs made of a durable plastic material. Unlike a traditional tennis ball that‚Äôs covered in felt, the pickleballs material is hollow and solid plastic, with holes strategically placed around the surface. This perforation affects its texture, creating a smooth yet slightly dimpled surface. The texture is crucial because it helps the ball glide smoothly through the air and bounce predictably on the court. The holes in the design also reduce the ball‚Äôs bounce compared to other sports balls, creating a more controlled game.

‚Äç

Pickleballs Colors

As for the pickleballs‚Äô colors, they are often quite bright and vibrant. Most commonly, outdoor pickleballs are yellow, making them easy to see under the sun. However, you can also find pickleballs in other bold colors, such as orange, green, pink or even white. These pickleball colors are designed to enhance visibility, which is essential for fast-paced games.

‚Äç

Pickleballs Features

What truly sets the pickleball design apart is its combination of features that make it perfect for the game. Pickleballs features include the hole pattern‚Äîtypically 26-40 holes depending on whether the ball is designed for indoor or outdoor use. The outdoor balls usually have more holes to help reduce wind interference, while indoor balls tend to have fewer holes, resulting in a slightly different flight and bounce.

‚Äç

Pickleball Ball Sizes for Different Environments

There‚Äôs a subtle difference in pickleball ball sizes depending on the type of court you're playing on. Indoor pickleballs are generally lighter and have fewer holes, making them better suited for the calmer environment of indoor courts. Outdoor pickleballs, on the other hand, are heavier and have more holes to better resist wind. The slight differences in pickleball ball sizes ensure that the game plays fairly no matter the conditions.

title: Indoor Pickleballs: Everything You Need to Know
summary: Master the game with the right indoor pickleball. This guide highlights the unique features of indoor pickleballs, including their lighter weight, larger holes, and softer bounce. Learn how these elements impact your control, precision, and overall performance to take your game to the next level.
content:
Dual Matches Redesign

After observing dual matches in 2024, we‚Äôve made some edits to the dual match format to better accommodate team sizes and schedules! Regularly scheduled head to head games are the foundation of nearly every sports league, so it‚Äôs something we want to implement as well. All dual matches will be recorded on our collegiate website, including a standings section.¬†

‚Äç

Dual Match Presentation, Rules, and Results

View the following links to see in more detail the dual match format presentation, rules, and results:

Dual match format presentation
Dual match rules
Dual match results

‚Äç

Bids

For the 2025 season, the top 2 teams with the most dual match wins will get a bid to nationals. Ties will be broken by overall dual match performance, including match/game/point/win %. Dual Matches played on or before March 30th, 2025 will count towards this. Submit your Dual Match results to this form as soon as possible, and on or before March 30th, 2025 to guarantee they will be counted.

‚Äç

For counting dual match wins, a school can only gain 1 win per semester from beating a particular opposing school. All other stats will count to help your tiebreaker, but only 1 win can be gained.¬†

‚Äç

Showcase Matches

We‚Äôre bringing the college action under the lights on championship court at PPA tour stops in 2025. Showcase Matches will feature college teams competing in dual matches against each other on PPA livestream. Certain stops will showcase top teams playing against and with PPA Pros and the top PPA Juniors talent. Matches played between schools will be counted as official dual matches.

‚Äç

Below is the schedule of these matchups:
Mesa Cup Feb. 22 ASU vs Grand Canyon
Cape Coral Open March 8 Florida vs Florida State
North Carolina Open April 5 By Invitation
Red Rock Open April 9 By Invitation
Atlanta Slam May 17 By Invitation

‚Äç

Dual Match Weekends

To facilitate many dual matches at once, we recommend schools organize Dual Match Weekends to have 3-4 schools all play dual matches against each other.¬†

All schools involved need to bring the same number of teams
We estimate each match taking 75 minutes, so use that number to schedule out the Dual Match Weekend depending on how many teams each school brings.
1 team - 75 minutes (1.25 hours) per dual match
2 teams - 150 minutes (2.5 hours) per dual match
3 teams - 225 minutes (3.75 hours) per dual match
For both 3 and 4 schools in attendance, 3 ‚Äúrounds‚Äù of dual matches will be played. If it is 3 schools, have the host take the bye in the middle so the visiting schools can leave or arrive early.
3 schools - (R1) A vs B; (R2) B vs C; (R3) A vs C
4 schools - (R1) A vs B, C vs D; (R2) A vs C, B vs D; (R3) A vs D, B vs C

‚Äç

Exhibition Games

We are always looking for ways to get players not on the starting team involved in the action! We recommend creating an exhibition bracket or pools to get games for these players. This can take any form you think will work best.¬†

‚Äç

One way to do this is to use ‚Äúinverse groups‚Äù: groups where you play no one of your group but everyone from a different group. School A and School B could create groups of 4 that only contain players from their school, and then they would play everyone from the opposing group, ensuring maximum cross-school play.¬†

‚Äç

We are also working on creating the No-Same-School Scheduling Tool (NoSSST for short). When functioning, NoSSST will create a round robin with players from different schools but omit rounds where players from the same school face each other. This will allow for higher flexibility in scheduling exhibition games while also maximizing cross-school play!

‚Äç

To learn more about DUPR¬†Collegiate Pickleball, visit our website.

title: Analyzing the Johns‚Äô Brothers Dominant Pickleball Partnership
summary: Explore the stats, wins, and legacy of Ben and Collin Johns, one of pickleball's most successful teams, and their future in 2025.
content:
If you're diving into the world of pickleball, understanding the differences between indoor and outdoor pickleballs is crucial. Whether you're a seasoned player or just starting out, choosing the right indoor pickleball can make all the difference in your game. This guide will explore the unique features of indoor pickleballs, the best brands available, and essential equipment, so you can optimize your gameplay.

‚Äç

What Makes Indoor Pickleballs Unique?

‚Äç

Indoor pickleballs are designed specifically for indoor play on smooth courts. Unlike outdoor pickleballs, which are built to withstand wind and rough surfaces, indoor pickleballs are optimized for controlled indoor environments.

‚Äç

Weight and Control: Indoor pickleballs tend to be lighter than their outdoor counterparts, making them easier to control. This lighter weight allows for more precise shots and greater maneuverability. It‚Äôs particularly helpful for players who prefer finesse and control rather than power.

‚Äç

Larger, Fewer Holes: Indoor pickleballs typically feature fewer holes and larger openings. This reduces drag and creates a more predictable flight pattern. Since there‚Äôs no wind indoors to affect the ball‚Äôs movement, the larger holes provide a balanced trajectory.

‚Äç

Softer Bounce and Impact: Indoor pickleballs are crafted to provide a consistent bounce, making them ideal for indoor courts. They also feature a softer impact, which contributes to a smoother playing experience and less noise during matches. This is important in indoor settings, where sound levels can be more noticeable.

‚Äç

Best Indoor Pickleballs on the Market

‚Äç

When selecting indoor pickleballs, personal preference and playing style play a significant role. High-quality indoor pickleballs are designed for durability, visibility, and performance. Below are some of the top-rated brands:

‚Äç

ONIX Fuse Indoor Pickleballs


ONIX Fuse balls are known for their durability, true flight, and consistent bounce, making them a favorite among competitive players. Their design ensures that the ball maintains a steady path throughout the game, providing excellent control.

‚Äç

Gamma Photon Indoor Pickleballs

‚Äç

These pickleballs are praised for their visibility and balanced feel, offering precision and consistency. The unique hole pattern and the soft feel make them ideal for players who rely on control.

‚Äç

Jugs Indoor Pickleballs


Jugs balls are lightweight and soft, perfect for recreational play. Their softer construction makes them a great choice for beginners or those who prefer a less aggressive playing style.

‚Äç

When selecting the best indoor pickleballs for you, consider the material used, bounce consistency, and hole pattern that best aligns with your style of play.

‚Äç

Indoor vs Outdoor Pickleballs: Key Differences

‚Äç

Understanding the differences between indoor and outdoor pickleballs can help you adapt your strategy for each environment. Both types are designed with specific needs in mind, so it's essential to recognize how they impact gameplay.

‚Äç

Bounce: Indoor pickleballs have a softer bounce compared to outdoor balls. This is ideal for finesse shots, where precision and control are crucial. The softer bounce also makes it easier to perform delicate shots like dinks and drops.

‚Äç

Noise: Indoor pickleballs are quieter than outdoor ones, which is important in indoor environments where noise can be disruptive. This quieter performance makes indoor balls more suited to the acoustics of indoor courts, where sound tends to echo.

‚Äç

Visibility: Indoor pickleballs often come in bright colors, such as neon green or yellow, to improve visibility under artificial lighting. This ensures that players can track the ball more easily during fast-paced rallies, especially in gyms or courts with low lighting.

‚Äç

Hole Pattern: Indoor balls generally have fewer, larger holes. This reduces drag and makes the ball fly with greater consistency. In contrast, outdoor pickleballs have more, smaller holes to better withstand wind and other elements outside.

‚Äç

Surface Compatibility: Indoor pickleballs are made for smooth surfaces, allowing for a more predictable bounce. In contrast, outdoor balls are designed to withstand harsher surfaces, such as asphalt or concrete, which makes them more rugged and durable.

‚Äç

Indoor Pickleball Reviews: What Players Are Saying

‚Äç

Indoor pickleball reviews often highlight the importance of selecting the right ball for your playing style. Competitive players typically prefer balls with consistent performance, while recreational players may opt for lighter, softer balls. Reviews also mention that the best indoor pickleballs deliver a dependable bounce and durability over time.

‚Äç

Competitive Players: Many competitive players favor ONIX and Gamma balls due to their consistent flight and durability. These brands are recognized for their ability to maintain control even in high-intensity games.

‚Äç

Recreational Players: Recreational players often prefer Jugs for their lightweight feel and affordability. These balls are easy to play with and provide a great experience without the high cost.

‚Äç

Feedback from players consistently emphasizes the importance of choosing indoor pickleballs with a good balance of durability, visibility, and consistent bounce.

‚Äç

Why Brand Matters in Indoor Pickleballs

‚Äç

The brand of your indoor pickleball can have a significant impact on your gameplay. Trusted brands invest in quality materials and conduct rigorous testing to ensure their products meet the expectations of players at every skill level. Popular brands like ONIX, Franklin, and Gamma are known for their consistency, durability, and innovation.

‚Äç

ONIX: ONIX is a leading brand known for producing durable balls with excellent flight characteristics. Their indoor pickleballs are designed to provide precision and consistency, making them a popular choice for competitive play.

‚Äç

Gamma: Gamma pickleballs are known for their balance and precision. They offer excellent visibility and are ideal for players who want a reliable ball for recreational and competitive play.

‚Äç

Franklin Sports: A trusted name in pickleball, Franklin Sports provides high-quality indoor pickleballs that are perfect for casual and competitive players alike. Their commitment to durability and innovation makes them a top choice.

‚Äç

Dura: Dura is a great choice for competitive players. Known for their durability and consistent flight, Dura balls are designed to withstand intense gameplay and provide reliable performance.

‚Äç

Pickleball Now: Pickleball Now balls are designed with recreational players in mind. They provide an affordable option for casual games without sacrificing playability.

‚Äç

Specifications to Look For in Indoor Pickleballs

‚Äç

When choosing indoor pickleballs, understanding their specifications can help you make an informed decision. Indoor pickleballs are typically about 2.87 inches in diameter and weigh between 0.8 and 0.9 ounces. These measurements provide an optimal balance of control and durability for indoor courts.

‚Äç

Hole Pattern: Indoor balls generally have larger, fewer holes, which helps reduce drag and makes the ball fly more smoothly. This design is ideal for indoor conditions where wind isn‚Äôt a factor.

‚Äç

Bounce Quality: The bounce of an indoor pickleball is softer than that of an outdoor ball, which is crucial for indoor play. The softer bounce ensures that the ball reacts predictably on smooth surfaces, making it easier to control during play.

‚Äç

Material: Polyethylene is the most common material for indoor pickleballs. It offers a good balance of durability, softness, and consistent bounce, making it the preferred choice for most indoor balls.

‚Äç

Key Differences Between Indoor Pickleballs

‚Äç

While all indoor pickleballs are designed for smooth courts, they are not all the same. Some are made for competitive play, offering precision and durability, while others are better suited for casual games due to their softer feel and affordability.

‚Äç

Material: Polyethylene is widely used in indoor balls for its balance of softness and durability. It ensures a consistent bounce while maintaining the ball's structural integrity.

‚Äç

Visibility: Bright colors like neon green or yellow improve visibility, ensuring players can track the ball easily in indoor settings, even under artificial lighting.

‚Äç

Control: Indoor pickleballs are designed to provide better control and spin, thanks to their smooth surfaces and predictable bounce. This allows for a more strategic game focused on placement and precision.

‚Äç

Indoor Pickleball Buying Guide

‚Äç

Purchasing indoor pickleballs doesn't have to be overwhelming. Here are a few steps to help you choose the right ball for your needs:

‚Äç

1. Assess Your Needs: Determine whether you play recreationally or competitively. Competitive players may prioritize durability and consistent performance, while recreational players might look for affordability and a lightweight design.

‚Äç

2. Research Brands: Stick to trusted names in the pickleball industry. ONIX, Gamma, and Jugs are all well-regarded brands known for producing high-quality indoor pickleballs.

‚Äç

3. Read Reviews: Check player reviews to get an idea of how the ball performs in real-world conditions. This can give you valuable insights into bounce quality, durability, and overall playability.

‚Äç

4. Test Different Balls: Try out different balls from various brands to see which one feels best for your style of play. You may find that one ball‚Äôs bounce or weight suits your game better than another.

‚Äç

Features That Make Great Indoor Pickleballs

‚Äç

The best indoor pickleballs deliver consistent bounce, durability, and excellent visibility. High-quality indoor balls also feature smooth surfaces for better control and spin, and their durability minimizes the need for frequent replacements. Bright colors help players keep track of the ball during fast exchanges, while lightweight designs enhance maneuverability.

‚Äç

How DUPR Enhances Indoor Pickleball Matches

‚Äç

For serious players, DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) offers a tool to track performance and find opponents of similar skill levels. DUPR allows players to measure their improvement and ensures competitive fairness in matches. Whether using ONIX Fuse Indoor Pickleballs or competing in a league, DUPR helps players set goals and achieve steady progress, making every match more rewarding.

‚Äç

title: Kickstart Your Pickleball Journey With Coach-Assigned Ratings
summary: Get your personalized DUPR rating with MyDUPRCoach! Start your pickleball journey with a coach-assigned rating and confidently join tournaments and leagues.
content:
The professional pickleball world was recently met with the news that Ben and Collin Johns, one of the sport's most dominant partnerships in this era of of the sport, will be parting ways heading into 2025. As this chapter closes on one of pickleball's most successful teams, we want to take a look at the remarkable statistics that defined their partnership and explore how they have helped shape the game.

‚Äç

By the Numbers

‚Äç

The statistics behind the Johns brothers' partnership tell a story of unprecedented dominance. From 2020 through 2023, they maintained win percentages that redefined excellence in professional pickleball. Their peak came in 2023 with an extraordinary 93.51% win rate, securing 72 victories against just 5 losses. This followed equally impressive showings in 2020/2021 (91.38%) and 2022 (90.11%).

‚Äç

With an 81.71% win rate in 2024 (67 wins, 15 losses), the Johns brothers showed signs of change while maintaining a level of success most partnerships dream of. Their consistency across seasons set competitive standards in professional pickleball. Meanwhile, competition is tougher than ever. Ben remains number 1, but Collin, once ranked in the mid-teens for male doubles, has dropped to 33rd over the last year. The sport has evolved around them with new talent raising the bar.

‚Äç

Medal Count and Tournament Dominance

‚Äç

Their tournament achievements paint an even more compelling picture. Across 66 tournaments, they accumulated 52 medals - 43 golds, 8 silvers, and 1 bronze. This translates to a remarkable 79% podium percentage and a 65% rate of securing gold medals. Their year-by-year consistency tells its own story:

‚Äç

2024/2025: 8 gold medals (tour-leading), 2 silvers
2023: 13 gold medals, 1 silver - their most dominant year
2022: 13 gold medals, 4 silvers - establishing their dynasty
2021/2020: 9 gold medals, 1 silver, 1 bronze (in just 12 tournaments)

‚Äç

To put these numbers in perspective, Ben Johns has accumulated 43 career gold medals in men's doubles, while Collin has 33. The next closest competitor, Matt Wright, stands at 18. As a team, their 33 gold medals significantly outpace other partnerships - Frazier/Johnson and Newman/Wright follow with 10 and 8 golds respectively (Pickleball.com).

‚Äç

The 2024 Transition Year

‚Äç

The 2024 season marked a notable shift in their dominance, coinciding with broader changes in professional pickleball. The sport's evolution toward a more power-driven style presented new challenges to their traditionally patient, strategic approach. Their 81.71% win rate, while still impressive, represented the first time in four years they performed below the 90% threshold.

‚Äç

This transition reflected larger changes in professional pickleball, where the emphasis shifted from the dinking game to a more aggressive, power-based style. The introduction of new equipment and evolving tactics meant that the patient, methodical approach that had served them so well faced new challenges.¬†

‚Äç

The Johns brothers' adaptation to these changes, while successful by most standards, couldn't quite match their previous levels of dominance.

‚Äç

Tournament-by-Tournament Analysis

‚Äç

A closer look at their tournament performances reveals remarkable consistency. In their 58 tournaments together, they reached at least the semifinals in 51 events - an 88% rate of deep tournament runs. This level of consistency is particularly impressive given the increasing depth of talent in professional pickleball and the physical demands of the modern game.

‚Äç

Their ability to perform under pressure was equally notable. In gold medal matches, they maintained a winning percentage above 80%, demonstrating their capacity to elevate their game when the stakes were highest. This clutch performance helped establish their reputation as the team to beat in any major tournament.

‚Äç

Individual Achievements and Partnership Synergy

‚Äç

While both players brought individual strengths to the partnership, their success stemmed from exceptional teamwork and complementary skills. Ben's aggressive style and dynamic shot-making paired perfectly with Collin's steady defensive play and consistent resetting ability. This combination created a partnership that could adapt to any opponent's strategy while maintaining their own high level of play.

‚Äç

Their individual achievements within the partnership are equally impressive. Ben's 43 career gold medals in men's doubles set a standard that may never be matched, while Collin's 33 gold medals would be a career-defining achievement for most players, highlighting the extraordinary nature of their partnership.

‚Äç

Looking Ahead to 2025

‚Äç

As both players look toward 2025, the professional pickleball landscape enters a new era. Ben Johns, widely regarded as one of the sport's premier players, has several potential high-profile partnerships on the horizon. For Collin, who has demonstrated particular strength on the right side, opportunities exist to forge new partnerships that could showcase different aspects of his game.

‚Äç

The dissolution of this partnership will lead to changes across professional pickleball as players adjust their strategies for the 2025 season. The season is expected to be one of the most dynamic in recent memory, with new partnerships and rivalries forming.

‚Äç

It has been rumored that Ben will team up with Gabe Tardio, Hayden Patriquin, and Maxwell Freeman, a left-handed player, along with potentially others not mentioned. The combination of an aggressive right-handed player with a lefty-righty duo will be closely watched, as Ben has previously stated that this type of pairing could be the future of the game‚Äôs top partnerships.

‚Äç

Overall, the Johns brothers' partnership represents more than just statistical excellence - it established a benchmark that may stand unchallenged in professional pickleball. Their consistent performance over multiple years, maintaining extraordinary win percentages and accumulating medals at an unprecedented rate, speaks to a level of dominance rarely seen in any sport.

‚Äç

Their legacy extends beyond their on-court achievements. They helped establish professional pickleball's competitive standards, influenced training methodologies, and contributed to the sport's growing popularity. While their partnership may be ending, their impact on the sport will continue to be felt for years to come.

‚Äç

Attribution: Data and background information sourced from DUPR and Pickleball.com

‚Äç

title: Enhancing Accuracy: Exciting Updates to Your DUPR Rating
summary: Explore the latest DUPR rating updates, including dynamic ratings and rally scoring improvements, to better reflect your pickleball performance.
content:
Your service stance in pickleball can significantly influence your game. Whether you're aiming for power, spin, or balance, understanding the pros and cons of different stances can elevate your serve. Pro player Bobbi Oshiro breaks down the common service stances and their unique advantages.

‚Äç

1. The Open Stance

The open stance is characterized by feet and hips aligned slightly parallel to the baseline. Tyson McGuffin, a top pro player, is a prime example of this stance in action.

Advantages: This stance helps generate more topspin, often resulting in a serve with a noticeable arch. By loading the dominant leg and efficiently rotating the hips, players can get underneath the ball to add that extra spin.
Ideal For: Players who want to add a curve to their serve and aim to challenge opponents with unpredictable ball movement.
2. The Closed Stance

In the closed stance, feet and hips are positioned slightly perpendicular to the baseline. Dekel Bar, known for his powerful serves, often uses this stance.

Advantages: This position typically produces a flatter and faster serve. The perpendicular alignment allows for a more direct and forceful ball trajectory.
Ideal For: Players looking to dominate with speed and power, keeping opponents on the defensive.
3. The Semi-Open Stance

The semi-open stance is a hybrid of the open and closed stances. According to Bobbi Oshiro, this stance offers a balanced approach.

Advantages: It provides versatility, enabling players to switch between generating topspin and delivering a flatter serve when needed.
Ideal For: Players seeking a middle ground between power and spin, offering adaptability to different match situations.
Finding Your Perfect Serve Stance

Each stance has its unique strengths, so the key is experimenting to discover what suits your playing style. Whether you‚Äôre aiming to outspin, outpace, or outmaneuver your opponent, your service stance can be a game-changer. Take inspiration from the pros, hit the court, and start fine-tuning your serve today!

content:
At DUPR, we‚Äôre committed to providing you with the most accurate and dynamic rating system possible. We value your input and are always looking for ways to improve.

‚Äç

Disclaimer: This blog post may reference a previous version of the DUPR algorithm. Our system is constantly evolving to provide the most accurate and fair ratings possible. For the most up-to-date information on how your rating is calculated, please visit our How It Works page.

‚Äç

As of Januart 2025, Sarah Carpenter, Lead Data Scientist at DUPR, is here to walk you through the latest updates:

‚Äç

More Dynamic Ratings for Active Players

‚Äç

Some active players have reached a point where their new matches aren‚Äôt impacting their ratings enough, so we‚Äôve made an adjustment to the algorithm to allow for more movement with each match.

Following our initial update at the end of October 2024, this adjustment is another step toward ensuring your rating keeps up with your performance.

‚Ää

‚ÄäRally Scoring Differentiation

Rally scoring matches often have closer scores compared to traditional scoring. To reflect this, we‚Äôve refined the win intensity formula to reward performance more fairly in rally scoring games.

‚Äç

‚ÄäA Boost to Your Ratings

With these algorithm improvements, all matches have been recalculated. You might notice a slight increase in your Doubles and/or Singles rating! While your match-by-match history stays the same, your overall rating now better reflects your play.

‚Äç

To learn more about these adjustments and other hot topics surrounding the DUPR Rating, check our our How It Works Page

‚Äç

We‚Äôre always working to make DUPR the most accurate and player-focused rating system out there. If you have any questions or feedback about these updates, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out.


Thanks for being such a valued part of the DUPR community!

content:
D.C. Pickleball Team and Down the Line Sports Center Partner on Groundbreaking Initiative for Local Amateur Pickleball Players launching Road to Minors (RTM) Tournament Series

‚Äç

New Program to Give Opportunity for D.C.-Area Players to Earn Spots On DCPT‚Äôs Minor League Pickleball Team Rosters

‚Äç

Washington, D.C. ‚Äì January 13, 2025 ‚Äì Major League Pickleball‚Äôs (MLP) D.C. Pickleball Team (DCPT), Down the Line Sports Center (DTL), Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating (DUPR), and Pickleball Drop Shop (PDS) have partnered to announce the launch of a first-of-its-kind pathway for amateur pickleball players: Road to Minors (RTM) Tournament Series.

‚Äç

The RTM Tournament Series is the first-ever year-round program designed to identify and cultivate local talent to ladder up to D.C. Pickleball Team‚Äôs Minor League Pickleball rosters.

‚Äç

All events will be hosted exclusively by Down the Line Sports Center, where players will participate in DUPR sessions and monthly tournaments to earn points in an effort to qualify for DCPT‚Äôs MiLP DUPR 12 to 22 rosters. Weekly DUPR sessions begin Friday, January 31, and the first tournament kicks off Friday, February 28.

‚Äç

This initiative marks a significant milestone for pickleball enthusiasts, providing a structured pathway to elevate their game, compete at a higher level, and engage with D.C. Pickleball Team‚Äôs leading coaches and talent evaluators.

‚Äç

Registration is now open via Pickleballtournaments.com and the DCPT and DTL websites.

‚Äç

How It Works

RTM DUPR Sessions: Participants must complete a minimum number of RTM DUPR sessions to ensure accurate ratings and fair competition. All sessions will be offered weekly, starting Friday, January 31, at Down the Line Sports Center in Fairfax, Virginia. Events will move to the new state-of-the-art Annandale facility when it opens this Summer. This local focus reflects DCPT and DTL‚Äôs shared commitment to fostering talent within the DMV community.
Tracking Progress: Player performance will be monitored via DUPR and Pickleballbrackets, ensuring transparent and accurate tracking of scores and progress. This system enables participants and the DC Pickleball Team to effectively evaluate top players throughout the year.
Monthly RTM Tournaments & Wildcard Opportunities: Beginning in February, RTM tournaments will feature men‚Äôs doubles, women‚Äôs doubles, and mixed doubles at DUPR levels ranging from 3.0 to open division. Points will be awarded to the top four teams in each division. In addition to monthly tournaments, players will have opportunities to enhance their profiles and impress DCPT scouts through special combines and mini-tournaments throughout the year.
Year-End RTM Cup: The series will culminate in an MiLP-format tournament, where top players will showcase their skills in front of DCPT ownership and coaching staff for potential Minor League roster spots and an opportunity to represent the team at The Dink MiLP Nationals in December.
Unique Giveaways at all the events there will be unique giveaways for participants including RTM branded shirts provided by RTM‚Äôs Official Retail Partner, Pickleball Drop Shop, and other brands. The first round giveaway sponsor, Paddletek, will provide each RTM first round winner a Paddletek paddle. Limited edition Helios arm sleeves will also be provided.

‚Äç

Don‚Äôt miss your chance to join the Road to Minors and take the first step toward a spot on the D.C. Pickleball Team‚Äôs Minor League roster!

‚Äç

If you are interested in running an RTM Tournament, go to www.roadtominors.com for more information.

¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ###

About D.C. Pickleball Team:

D.C. Pickleball Team (DCPT) is DC‚Äôs Premier Level Major League Pickleball (MLP) team that joined MLP ahead of the 2023 season. DCPT‚Äôs ownership group includes Al Tylis, Sam Porter, Eva Longoria, Justin Verlander, Kate Upton, Rip Hamilton, Shawn Marion, Odell Beckham Jr., Cliff Avril and Mesut Ozil.

‚Äç

DCPT won the franchise‚Äôs first ever MLP Championship on November 5, 2023 in Dallas. The current roster includes James Ignatowich, world ranked #3 in pickleball; Rachel Rohrabacher, former D1 tennis star at the University of South Carolina, MLP Champion, and top ten ranked pickleballer; Dekel Bar, former pro tennis player and world pickleball ranked #6; and Vivian Glozman, former D1 tennis standout at the University of Virginia, and now pickleball‚Äôs fastest rising star.

‚Äç

For more information about D.C. Pickleball Team, visit dcpickleballteam.com and follow on social media: Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, TikTok, and YouTube.

‚Äç

About Down the Line (DTL) Sports Center

Down the Line Sports Center is a premier pickleball and sports facility dedicated to fostering growth, competition, and community engagement. Located in the heart of Virginia, DTL provides state-of-the-art facilities and programs for athletes of all levels. From organized leagues and tournaments to open play, private instruction, and social events, DTL provides a place for your love of pickleball to thrive.

‚Äç

DTL is a one-of-a-kind facility that offers training and events to take your game to the next level. From beginners looking to learn to seasoned players looking to compete at a higher level, DTL provides the best resources to elevate your game. DTL also features a custom app that revolutionizes the way you book courts, sign up for events, and capture your most remarkable pickleball moments. With this innovative app you can record game footage that can be replayed and shared as you relive your best shots. For more information about DTL, visit dtlsportscenter.com and follow on Instagram @dtlsportscenter and Facebook @Down the Line Sports Center

‚Äç

About DUPR

DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) is the premier global pickleball rating system and technology platform, trusted by the world's leading clubs, tournaments, leagues, and players. DUPR's dynamic rating system unifies pickleball across age, gender, and location by analyzing match results to accurately evaluate all players across a 2.000 - 8.000 scale.

‚Äç
DUPR is the official pickleball rating of leagues, tournaments and clubs around the world, including United Pickleball Association (UPA), PPA, Major League Pickleball (MLP), Pickleball.com, Life Time, The Picklr, National Team Pickleball League, National Pickleball League. It also owns and operates Minor League Pickleball and Collegiate Pickleball, two of the biggest amateur leagues in the sport. Players and operators can visit www.dupr.com to sign up and learn more.

‚Äç

About MiLP

Minor League Pickleball (MiLP), owned and operated by DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating), is the premier amateur pickleball tour and a one-of-a-kind platform offering players a ‚Äúplay like the pros‚Äù experience. Modeled after Major League Pickleball, MiLP has been empowering amateur teams to compete at the highest level for several years. Teams participate in a series of local events that culminate in the highly anticipated Nationals event each year, with prize money on the line.

‚Äç

With its unique team-based format, Minor League Pickleball has not only grown to become the largest amateur pickleball tour but has also served as a proving ground for future professional players. Notable alumni like Connor Garnett have made the leap to the pro ranks, showcasing the league‚Äôs ability to develop talent. Whether you‚Äôre aiming to sharpen your skills or compete for glory, Minor League Pickleball is the ultimate pathway for passionate players to elevate their game.

‚Äç

About Pickleball Drop Shop

Pickleball Drop Shop (PDS) is a team of individuals who share a love, passion, and drive to spread pickleball through their communities. The company believes that pickleball isn‚Äôt just a sport or business, but a place to build friends, family, and endless opportunities. PDS has an online presence and now brick-and-mortar location based just outside the heart of Georgia in Norcross. Specializing in selling high end pickleball products ranging from paddles, gear, accessories, and their own line of merchandise, PDS continues to expand their reach around their brand with their iconic moon man logo. ¬†PDS is working with B2C, B2B, and prides their work in being more than a ‚Äútraditional‚Äù retail store. For more information on Pickleball Drop Shop, visit the official website and follow on Instagram @pickleballdropshop; just look for the Moon Man.

‚Äç

About Major League Pickleball (MLP by Margaritaville)

Founded in 2021, Major League Pickleball (MLP by Margaritaville) is the preeminent, coed, team-based professional pickleball league, featuring nearly 100 of the best athletes across 22 teams, a unique format, easy to understand scoring, iconic team owners, and the most electric live events and fan experience in the sport. In 2024, MLP and the PPA Tour merged under the newly-formed United Pickleball Association, bringing together the leading professional pickleball organizations under a single entity. For more information on Major League Pickleball, visit the official website and follow MLP on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, TikTok and YouTube.

‚Äç

title: STL Shock Announces Formation of Minor League Pickleball Teams, Welcomes John Kleinschmidt as Director of Talent & MiLP Operations
summary: St. Louis Shock announces the creation of Minor League Pickleball teams and hires John Kleinschmidt as Director of Talent & MiLP Operations, expanding pickleball opportunities.
content:
When it comes to unique places to play pickleball, Lieutenant Colonel Jared Wood might just take the crown. The Air Force veteran recently made waves on social media when he posted a video of himself playing pickleball in Antarctica, trading the usual court surface for packed snow and ice. While the conditions weren't exactly regulation ‚Äì there wasn't even a net ‚Äì the video captured the imagination of pickleball enthusiasts worldwide and highlighted just how far the sport has spread.

‚Äç

For Wood, who is stationed near Tacoma, Washington, the journey to becoming a pickleball ambassador in one of Earth's most remote locations began with a simple Father's Day gift in 2024. His daughters gave him a starter pickleball set from Target, and what started as a casual introduction to the sport quickly developed into a passionate pursuit. With a background in tennis, Wood found himself naturally drawn to the game's familiar yet distinct mechanics.

‚Äç

From Military Aviation to Antarctic Pickleball

‚Äç

As Director of Operations for the Air Force's Antarctica mission supporting the National Science Foundation, Wood's path to playing pickleball at McMurdo Station was anything but typical. His role involves coordinating C-17 flights from Christchurch, New Zealand, to Antarctica, and transporting scientists, support personnel, and essential equipment to the research station. The mission represents a crucial partnership between military aviation and scientific research, ensuring that vital studies can continue in one of the world's most challenging environments.

‚Äç

The Antarctic video wasn't exactly a planned exhibition match. Wood and a fellow service member ventured onto the parking apron, where the surface was relatively flat and compact. Despite temperatures hovering around five degrees Fahrenheit and the absence of a net, they managed to rally back and forth, though Wood admits with a laugh that there wasn't much dinking involved ‚Äì mostly lobs.

‚Äç

"Next time I think we probably need to put up a net," Wood said. "You know, that would make it a little more legit."

‚Äç

The extreme conditions required careful preparation, with players donning multiple layers of specialized cold-weather gear. Wood explained that in Antarctica, even your eyes need protection.

‚Äç

"You've got to make sure that you have goggles on, because your eyes literally will freeze open because it's so cold,‚Äù he stressed.

‚Äç

Finding a Pickleball Community Abroad

‚Äç

While his Antarctic pickleball adventure gained attention, Wood's regular pickleball routine actually blossomed during his time in New Zealand. The owner of their hotel in Christchurch, upon learning about the team's enthusiasm for pickleball, converted his tennis court into two pickleball courts. This thoughtful adaptation allowed Wood and his fellow service members to play almost daily during their stays.

‚Äç

"We played almost every day," Wood recalled. "And then in Christchurch, there's a local pickleball group where they have indoor sessions, and when the weather turns nice, they go outdoors. It's an up-and-coming pickleball locale in New Zealand."

‚Äç

Strengthening Military Bonds Through Pickleball

‚Äç

As both an active Air Force Reserve pilot and a veteran of 10 years of active duty service, Wood sees tremendous potential for pickleball to bring together service members and veterans. The sport's accessibility and social nature make it an ideal platform for building connections within the military community.

‚Äç

"Anytime that you have people that have served, veterans... one thing they like to do is, especially when you're waiting for a game, they just love to talk about their time," Wood explained. "If they know that you're a veteran, they love to share their stories and their experiences and just kind of talk about their service."

‚Äç

Wood believes a veterans-based pickleball league would be highly successful, citing the unspoken camaraderie that naturally emerges when veterans connect and share their experiences.

‚Äç

"It would be a great way for veterans to kind of bond and to lead not only into pickleball, but then also talk about life. Any issues that veterans have, they can find someone to have an ally in,‚Äù Wood shared.

‚Äç

For active duty service members considering picking up a paddle, Wood emphasizes the natural fit between military values and pickleball culture.

‚Äç

"Being a service member, staying fit, being competitive, right? Those are important things," he notes. "And for those of us that maybe don't have the chops to play tennis anymore like we used to, pickleball is a nice way to downshift."

‚Äç

Bringing Pickleball to Military Bases and Beyond

‚Äç

When he's not flying C-17s or playing pickleball in extreme conditions, Wood keeps busy with various pursuits. He works as a simulator instructor for Air Force pilots and runs a youth basketball league with 150 teams in the East Seattle metro area. A native of Central Washington, he embraces the outdoor lifestyle of the Pacific Northwest, enjoying activities like skiing, camping, and mountain biking.

‚Äç

Looking ahead, Wood envisions pickleball continuing to grow within military communities, both on and off base. He sees potential for partnerships between pickleball organizations like DUPR and Military Welfare and Recreation (MWR) programs to help facilitate this growth, suggesting that existing tennis court infrastructure could be converted to support the rising interest in pickleball among service members.

‚Äç

From the frozen expanse of Antarctica to the courts of New Zealand and back home in Washington state, Wood's pickleball journey exemplifies the sport's ability to create connections and community in unexpected places. His story reminds us that whether you're playing on a professional court or the Antarctic ice, pickleball's true value lies in its power to bring people together ‚Äì even at the bottom of the world.

‚Äç

title: Who Invented Pickleball? A Complete History and Origins of the Sport
summary: Learn about the origins of pickleball and the evolution of the game. Explore the history, name‚Äôs origins, and impact on the pickleball community.
content:
St. Louis, MO ‚Äì The St. Louis Shock of Major League Pickleball (MLP) is proud to announce two major developments: the formation of teams for the 2025 season of Minor League Pickleball (MiLP), owned and operated by Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating (DUPR), and the appointment of John Kleinschmidt as the franchise‚Äôs Director of Talent & MiLP Operations. These initiatives mark a significant step forward in the Shock‚Äôs mission to expand its footprint in all levels of professional and amateur pickleball, while fostering talent development and the pursuing championship culture.

‚Äç

The formation of multiple Shock MiLP teams makes the Shock the first MLP franchise to build an official presence in Minor League Pickleball. This initiative will launch with teams competing in multiple MiLP DUPR levels, creating a pathway for emerging players to refine their skills, compete under the Shock brand, and rise to the professional ranks of one of the league‚Äôs top franchises. The Shock plan to expand the program to encompass all MiLP DUPR levels, and establish a comprehensive

network of players and fans ‚Äì all united under the Shock banner.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThis is a monumental step for the St. Louis Shock and the sport of pickleball,‚Äù said Andrew Haines, Chief Operating Officer of the St. Louis Shock.

‚ÄúBy committing to Minor League Pickleball, we‚Äôre not just investing in the future of our franchise but also in the future of pickleball itself. This initiative will allow us to spotlight the best emerging talent in the sport, create meaningful connections within the community, and provide opportunities for players at every level to grow their skills and affiliation with the Shock.‚Äù

‚Äç

To oversee the new initiative and to help elevate players to their highest level, the Shock welcome St. Louis native John Kleinschmidt. John is a Senior Pro Player and nationally recognized competitor, who has won Gold at the highest levels, including multiple medal finishes at the Pickleball US Open. Kleinschmidt is also a IPTPA Level 2 and NPA Certified Instructor with over six years of coaching experience.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe are thrilled to announce this MiLP initiative ‚Äì a first for MLP teams ‚Äì and welcome John to the Shock family in this pivotal role,‚Äù

said Ross Chaifetz, the Owner, General Manager, and Vice Chairman of the St. Louis Shock. ‚ÄúJohn‚Äôs experience as a Senior Pro player, instructor, and member of the St. Louis community makes him the ideal leader to oversee our Minor League Pickleball program and develop the best up-and-coming talents in the sport. His commitment to growing the sport aligns

perfectly with our vision, and our desire to be best-in-class for everything we do.‚Äù

‚Äç

As Director of Talent & MiLP Operations, Kleinschmidt will oversee the operations of the Shock‚Äôs MiLP teams, which will feature:

‚Äç

Development Opportunities: Access to professional coaching, structured practices, and competitive tournaments the emerging players at all DUPR levels. Community Engagement: Shock-hosted events, including clinics, exhibitions, instruction, and outreach programs.¬†
Visibility & Branding: Representing the Shock brand in premium uniforms at events and competition, further integrating players into the franchise's ecosystem.¬†
Competition: Overseeing the performance of the Shock‚Äôs MiLP teams at the most competitive levels of the sport: 3.0 up to 5.0+ DUPR level. DUPR Algorithm: Latest News

‚Äç

In addition to his leadership of the MiLP program, Kleinschmidt will run regular Shock-branded clinics to help players of all levels enhance their skills and grow the game. His first event, a 4-Hour Pickleball Session on Saturday, February 1st, will include two hours of DUPR Rating Matches and two hours of skill-building clinics. Registration is available at CLICK HERE; space limited to 16 participants.

‚Äç

‚ÄúThis is an exciting time for pickleball, and I‚Äôm honored to join the St. Louis Shock,‚Äù said Kleinschmidt. ‚ÄúThe Shock has set a standard of excellence both in our community and at the highest level of Major League Pickleball, and I‚Äôm eager to contribute to building talent, engaging the community, and driving the sport forward through initiatives like Minor League Pickleball and regular clinics.‚Äù

‚Äç

DUPR‚Äôs Director of Minor League Pickleball, Caroline Luelf, echoed the significance of this partnership:

‚ÄúBy aligning with a forward-thinking franchise like the Shock, we‚Äôre creating a clear pathway for players to advance their skills, enhance their DUPR ratings, and connect with the broader pickleball community. Together, we‚Äôre redefining how talent is discovered and developed in this sport.‚Äù

‚Äç

Open tryouts for the inaugural MiLP teams will be announced soon, giving players the opportunity to compete under the Shock banner and advance their skills in a structured, competitive environment. Interested players can sign up to receive more information here: CLICK HERE

‚Äç

For updates on Minor League Pickleball opportunities, upcoming events, and tryout dates, visit www.stlshock.com and follow the Shock on social media at @STLSHOCKMLP.

‚Äç

About St. Louis Shock

The St. Louis Shock is a Major League Pickleball team which competes in the Premier level of the league. The Shock are dedicated to the pursuit of championships, and promoting the growth of both recreational and professional pickleball, providing fans and players with exciting opportunities to engage in the sport. Through partnerships, events, and community involvement, the St. Louis Shock is committed to expanding pickleball‚Äôs reach and inspiring players across the region.

‚Äç

About MiLP

Minor League Pickleball (MiLP), owned and operated by DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating), is the premier amateur pickleball tour and a one-of-a-kind platform offering players a ‚Äúplay like the pros‚Äù experience. Modeled after Major League Pickleball, MiLP has been empowering amateur teams to compete at the highest level for several years. Teams participate in a series of local events that culminate in the highly anticipated Nationals event each year. With its unique team-based format,

Minor League Pickleball has not only grown to become the largest amateur pickleball tour but has also served as a proving ground for future professional players. Notable alumni like Connor Garnett have made the leap to the pro ranks, showcasing the league‚Äôs ability to develop talent. Whether you‚Äôre aiming to sharpen your skills or compete for glory, Minor League Pickleball is the ultimate pathway for passionate players to elevate their game.

‚Äç

title: Welcome to DUPR ‚Äì Let‚Äôs Get Started on Your Pickleball Journey!
summary: Join 1M+ players using DUPR to track your pickleball progress! Learn how our rating system, Reliability Score, and events help you improve and connect.
content:
Pickleball, America's fastest-growing sport, began as a simple backyard game created to entertain children. Today, it has evolved into a beloved game for people of all ages. Its quirky name, easy-to-learn rules, and inclusive nature have helped pickleball gain massive popularity worldwide. But who invented pickleball, and why did it become so popular?

The Birth of Pickleball: Who Invented It and Why?

Pickleball‚Äôs origins trace back to the summer of 1965 on Bainbridge Island, Washington. Three dads‚ÄîJoel Pritchard, a congressman; Bill Bell, a businessman; and Barney McCallum‚Äîcreated the game to entertain their families. The Pritchard family returned from a golf outing to find their children bored and looking for something fun to do. These fathers quickly came together to create a new game, one that would be enjoyable for everyone, regardless of skill level.

‚Äç

Over several weekends, the dads tested different rules and equipment. Their families became their test subjects, helping shape the early development of pickleball. The inventors‚Äô commitment to making the game accessible for all players laid the foundation for pickleball‚Äôs future success.

Pickleball Invention Facts: When Was Pickleball Invented?

The pickleball invention date is clearly documented, marking its inception in 1965. The inventors used an old badminton court, ping-pong paddles, and a perforated plastic ball to create the initial setup. The rules of pickleball combined elements from badminton, tennis, and table tennis, creating a unique game with simple, accessible rules.

‚Äç

As neighbors became interested, the game‚Äôs popularity spread quickly throughout the Bainbridge Island community. The accessibility and social aspects of pickleball contributed to its rapid growth and laid the groundwork for its future success.

Why Is It Called Pickleball? The Name‚Äôs Origins

The question "Why is it called pickleball?" has two main theories. One popular explanation is that Joan Pritchard, Joel‚Äôs wife, named the game after "pickle boats" in crew racing. These boats are often crewed by rowers from different teams, much like how pickleball combines elements of various sports. The name "pickleball" perfectly represents the sport's inclusive nature, welcoming players from all skill levels and backgrounds.

The Evolution of Pickleball: Milestones and Growth

From its humble beginnings to global recognition, pickleball has grown significantly. Key milestones in pickleball‚Äôs history include:

1967: First permanent pickleball court built.
1972: Official corporation formed to protect the sport.
1990: Pickleball becomes popular across all 50 states.
2022: Pickleball is named the official state sport of Washington.

In the 1970s, tournament play began, and by the 1980s, pickleball was a staple in community centers and retirement communities. Its widespread appeal contributed to its continued growth.

Pickleball Equipment: Early Developments and Innovations

The evolution of pickleball equipment showcases the creativity and problem-solving involved in the game‚Äôs development. Initially, the inventors used hand-carved wooden paddles, which were heavier than today‚Äôs designs. The first pickleball balls were repurposed wiffle balls, chosen for their perfect combination of bounce and air resistance.

‚Äç

As pickleball gained popularity, specialized paddles and balls were created, improving play quality and making the game more standardized. These innovations helped ensure the sport‚Äôs continued growth and appeal.

Pickleball‚Äôs Impact on Communities and Health

One of the most significant aspects of pickleball's growth is its ability to bring communities together. Initially played in community centers and retirement homes, pickleball has been praised for its social nature and the bonds it creates. The sport is particularly popular with older adults, who benefit from its low-impact nature, while also attracting younger generations to the game.

‚Äç

Pickleball‚Äôs appeal lies in its ability to engage people of all ages, providing a fun and active way to connect socially. It has become a staple of community wellness programs, praised for its ability to keep players physically active, mentally sharp, and socially connected.

Modern Pickleball: Rules and Competitive Growth

Today's pickleball rules have evolved while staying true to the sport‚Äôs core values of accessibility and fun. Played on a court similar to a badminton court, the game uses specially designed paddles and a perforated ball. The game combines social play with competitive elements, making it suitable for recreational players and serious athletes alike.

‚Äç

Pickleball‚Äôs growth in recent years is nothing short of extraordinary. In 2023, the Sports & Fitness Industry Association reported that pickleball had more than 8.9 million players in the U.S., making it the fastest-growing sport in the country for the third consecutive year.

The Legacy of the Pickleball Inventors

The story of pickleball is a celebration of American ingenuity and community spirit. What began as a backyard game created by three dads has grown into a global phenomenon. Joel Pritchard‚Äôs legacy extends beyond pickleball. He also served as a Washington State representative and lieutenant governor, contributing to the development of the state and its communities.

‚Äç

Today, pickleball continues to grow in popularity while remaining true to the values set by its inventors: inclusivity, fun, and community engagement. The inventors may not have become wealthy from their creation, but they gave the world a sport that unites people across generations and promotes healthy, active living.

‚Äç

Image credit: jpritchard.com

title: Scott Fliegelman: A Journey to the Top 10 in Senior Pickleball Doubles and Singles
summary: Explore Scott Fliegelman‚Äôs rise to a top 10 senior in pickleball and see how the DUPR pickleball ratings system tracks his progress and performance.
content:
[Delray Beach, Florida] ‚Äî DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) is thrilled to announce the launch of the first-ever High School Pickleball National Pathway, established to provide high school athletes across the country with a pathway to compete at state and national levels. This program is set to revolutionize the sport by fostering young talent, building community, and bringing the excitement of pickleball to high school campuses nationwide.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Inaugural Event¬†

The inaugural event will be hosted at Life Time Lakeville, MN, from April 25-27, showcasing the pathway's commitment to fostering young talent, building community, and bringing the excitement of pickleball to high school campuses nationwide. This program is set to revolutionize the sport by providing new opportunities for student-athletes to compete and grow in pickleball.

‚Äç

Building a Pathway for All Levels of Play

The 2025 DUPR High School National Pathway introduces a competitive structure tailored for both Varsity and JV1 teams, ensuring athletes of all skill levels have the opportunity to participate and shine. State championships will feature coed, men‚Äôs, and women‚Äôs divisions across both levels, with winners advancing to the highly anticipated National Championships.¬†

‚Äç

‚ÄúDUPR‚Äôs High School Pickleball National Pathway is a key step in our mission to make pickleball the most inclusive and accessible sport in the world. By creating structured opportunities for high school players, we‚Äôre laying the foundation for a vibrant, competitive ecosystem that nurtures talent and fosters lifelong passion for the game."

Tito Machado, CEO DUPR

‚Äç

State and National Competitions: A Unified Vision

State Championships: In 2025, DUPR aims to host 15 state-level championships, providing a clear path for Varsity and JV1 teams to compete for national recognition. Open to high school teams across the country, these events will highlight the growing talent and enthusiasm for pickleball at the grassroots level.

‚Äç

National Championships: The National Championships will feature the top-performing Varsity and JV1 teams from state competitions, with divisions for Coed, Men‚Äôs, and Women‚Äôs teams. To accommodate high schools with all-girl or all-boy teams, the competition will include a unique 3-person gender format, offering a tailored opportunity for these schools to showcase their talent and compete at the highest level. Additionally, individual competitions for singles players will highlight the best high school athletes in the country. Coed Teams will follow the popular MLPlay format ‚Äî also a signature of DUPR‚Äôs Minor League Pickleball format ‚Äî emphasizing the fast-paced, dynamic style of play that has captivated pickleball fans worldwide.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWe are thrilled to launch a pathway for high school pickleball players that not only provides opportunities to compete locally and nationally but also lays the foundation for their future in the sport. This initiative gives the next generation of collegiate, post-collegiate, and Major League pickleball players a starting point for growth, fostering community, and developing a lifelong passion for a sport that enriches lives at every age."

Ryan Maher, VP of Partnerships and Programs, DUPR

‚Äç

Get Involved

Interested in starting or joining a high school club? Contact Ryan Maher, DUPR VP of Partnerships and Programs, at ryan@mydupr.com.

---

‚Äç

About DUPR

DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) is the most accurate and trusted global rating system in pickleball, empowering players of all levels to track their progress and compete with confidence. DUPR is committed to growing the sport by creating opportunities for players, clubs, and organizations worldwide.

title: 2024 Pickleball Powerhouses: PPA, MLP Premier & Challenger Season Recap
summary: Explore the 2024 PPA and MLP Premier & Challenger highlights, including top doubles partnerships, singles performers, and standout teams.
content:
Scott Fliegelman‚Äôs story is one of passion, persistence, and a love for competition. From his early days as a competitive tennis player to his rise as a top 10 senior pickleball player, Scott has embraced every twist and turn in his athletic journey. Let‚Äôs dive into what inspired Scott to start playing pickleball, what motivates him, and his advice for aspiring players.

‚Äç

Discovering Pickleball: From Tennis Pro to Pickler

‚Äç

Scott‚Äôs athletic journey began at just 8 years old when he started playing competitive tennis. His talent led him to a successful D1 college career and a stint in the professional tennis world, but by his mid-20s, he decided to hang up his racket. Moving to Boulder, CO, Scott immersed himself in endurance sports, competing in triathlons and enjoying mountain sports like snowboarding. Then, in 2019, everything changed. A friend suggested he try pickleball, and though he initially dismissed it as a casual backyard game, Scott quickly realized its potential.

‚Äç

‚ÄúAt first, I thought pickleball was just some backyard BBQ game, like cornhole,‚Äù he admits. ‚ÄúBut within a week, I‚Äôd sold two bikes, dropped out of all my upcoming races, and set off on becoming a pickler!‚Äù
Scott fondly calls pickleball his ‚ÄúBack to the Future sport,‚Äù saying, ‚ÄúIt feels like it was custom-designed for me, blending my tennis background, endurance sports, and even the silly after-school games I used to play as a kid.‚Äù

‚Äç

Now in his late 50s, Scott is thriving in the sport, competing at the highest levels and feeling grateful for every moment on the court.

‚Äç

What Keeps Scott Motivated

‚Äç

For Scott, pickleball offers more than just athletic competition. The camaraderie, especially in doubles play, is what he treasures most. While he enjoys the physical grind of singles, doubles is, in his opinion, ‚Äúthe essence of pickleball.‚Äù

‚Äç

‚ÄúI really dig the camaraderie that exists in the game,‚Äù Scott shares. ‚ÄúIn doubles, it‚Äôs not just about athleticism; it‚Äôs about trust, teamwork, and strategy. That‚Äôs what makes it so special.‚Äù

‚Äç

Over the past two years, Scott has competed in the National Pickleball League (NPL), a team-based league for players aged 50 and over. As the captain of the Denver Iconics, Scott thrived on the intense competition, team spirit, and mentoring opportunities.

‚Äç

‚ÄúI loved the amazing competition against the best senior pro players in the game,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut the coaching, mentoring, and team bonding throughout the season made it an unforgettable experience.‚Äù

‚Äç

Tracking Progress with DUPR

‚Äç

As a competitor, Scott values measurable progress, and DUPR has become an essential tool. Reflecting on his junior tennis days, Scott recalls waiting weeks to see ranking updates. In contrast, DUPR provides real-time data, allowing him to track his performance and progress.

‚ÄúI love how DUPR gives feedback within days‚Äîor even sooner,‚Äù Scott says. ‚ÄúAfter a strong outing, I get excited to check the DUPR app and geek out on my matches to see how they‚Äôve impacted my rating. Then I cross my fingers, hoping I‚Äôve moved up a spot or two on the rankings page!‚Äù

‚Äç
Over the past year, we‚Äôve seen incredible progress from senior pro player Scott, proving that improvement has no age limit! His DUPR rating increased by 0.3 in doubles (from 5.578 to 5.874) and 0.2 in singles (from 5.422 to 5.675), while his average opponent rating also climbed as he consistently sought out higher-level competition. By challenging himself with tougher matchups, Scott not only elevated his game but demonstrated that you can keep improving‚Äîno matter your age. It‚Äôs inspiring to see players 50+ continue to thrive, push boundaries, and grow through DUPR. In addition, his games and points won % went up - meaning he continued to win against tougher competition.

‚Äç

‚Äç

For Scott, DUPR isn‚Äôt just a rating system‚Äîit adds a fun, gamified element to his competitive journey.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like a game within the game,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt keeps me motivated between tournaments.‚Äù

‚Äç

Future Goals and Growing the Game

‚Äç

Scott and his wife, Kari, are not just players but also ambassadors for the sport. They own a 5-court indoor pickleball facility in Boulder, CO, where they foster a thriving community of players. Through DUPR programs and events, their members focus on improving their skills and ratings.

‚Äç

‚ÄúMy goal is to continue representing our community at the top of the pro game while sharing everything I can with players of all levels,‚Äù Scott explains. ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs through our club or online platforms, I want to help others experience the joy and growth this game offers.‚Äù

‚Äç

Advice for Aspiring Pickleball Players

‚Äç

Scott‚Äôs advice for newcomers is simple but invaluable: find your community and seek proper guidance.

‚Äç

‚ÄúWhen I started, I was lucky to have seasoned players who adopted me and didn‚Äôt let me fall into bad habits from my tennis background,‚Äù he recalls. His recommendation? ‚ÄúJoin open play sessions, seek out proper instruction through clinics, and take private lessons.‚Äù

‚Äç

One of Scott‚Äôs favorite learning formats is the ‚Äú3-and-me‚Äù session, which includes three players and a teaching pro.

‚Äç

‚ÄúYou get a lot of play, and the coach can see and critique you during live action. These sessions are super fun and highly productive,‚Äù he shares.

‚Äç

Scott Fliegelman‚Äôs journey from competitive tennis to senior pickleball is a testament to his love of sport, community, and growth. Whether competing at the highest levels, mentoring players, or fostering his local pickleball community, Scott is making a lasting impact on the game.

‚Äç

As Scott puts it, ‚ÄúPickleball has been the perfect sport for me. It‚Äôs given me the chance to compete, connect, and grow‚Äîboth as a player and as a person.‚Äù

‚Äç

Follow Scott‚Äôs journey on Instagram or visit his Boulder facility to learn from one of the sport‚Äôs most passionate ambassadors. You can find Scott sharing his knowledge on Instagram (@scottfliegelmanpickleball and @boulderpickleball) and YouTube (BoulderPickleball).

‚Äç
