title: Your Pickleball Journey: A Physical and Mental Performance Guide
summary: Unlock your full potential on the court! Learn how to improve your pickleball game and increase your pickleball rating with expert tips on warmups, strength training, mental preparation, and recovery.
content:
Pickleball has exploded in popularity in recent years, and with players of all skill levels joining the court, the demand for high-quality pickleball paddles has skyrocketed.¬†

‚Äç

Choosing the right paddle is essential to success on the court, as it can greatly influence your game and confidence.¬†

‚Äç

Here, we'll guide you through finding the best pickleball paddle for your skill level based on the DUPR rating scale, which classifies players from beginners to advanced (rated from 2 to 8).

DUPR Rating Scale

‚Äç

Key Factors in Choosing a Pickleball Paddle

‚Äç

Before diving into the best paddles for each skill level, let‚Äôs review the main features to consider:

Grip Size: A proper grip size provides better control and reduces the risk of strain. Smaller grips offer more wrist flexibility for spin, while larger grips add stability.
Paddle Weight: Lighter paddles are ideal for precision and control, while heavier paddles provide power.‚Äç
Paddle Shape: Some paddles offer wider sweet spots for forgiving shots, while others are designed to focus power, making them best for advanced players.

‚Äç

Choosing the Right Pickleball Paddle Based on Skill Level

‚Äç

Beginner (DUPR Rating: 2-3.5)

‚Äç

For those just starting, pickleball can feel challenging enough without worrying about advanced paddle specifications. Beginner players benefit from paddles that prioritize control and forgiveness, helping them make consistent contact and learn the basics.

‚Äç

Recommended Paddles for Beginners:

The Rally: The Rally paddle by Rally Republic is ideal for new players looking for control and consistency on the court. Its lightweight design at 8.0 oz allows beginners to play longer with reduced fatigue, making it great for improving accuracy.
GAMMA Fusion Power: Known for its widest-hitting surfaces, the GAMMA Fusion Power provides a generous sweet spot for better precision. Its mid-weight design supports beginners by offering a blend of versatility and power.
ACE Heart Paddle: The ACE Heart paddle is crafted with new players in mind. It provides more power and precision with each shot. Lightweight and easy to maneuver, it helps build confidence.

‚Äç

Intermediate (DUPR Rating: 3.6-5.5)

‚Äç

Intermediate players usually have a feel for their game style, allowing them to start experimenting with power and spin. They often prefer paddles that deliver a balanced mix of control and power, offering flexibility for both defensive and offensive shots.

‚Äç

Recommended Paddles for Intermediate Players:

JOOLA Ben Johns 3S: Featuring a carbon fiber surface, the JOOLA Ben Johns 3S enhances spin and durability, making it ideal for players looking to add precision and more aggressive shots to their game. Its mid-weight design (about 7.8 oz) provides a blend of power and finesse, perfect for advancing players.
HEAD Boom Team EX Paddle: The HEAD Boom Team EX paddle is designed for intermediate players seeking a balance of control and power. Its lightweight construction makes it easy to handle and maneuver, while the graphite face ensures durability and a responsive feel. The paddle features a forgiving sweet spot, which helps improve consistency on off-center hits, making it ideal for players still refining their technique.
HEAD Boom Tour EX paddle: The HEAD Boom Tour EX paddle is designed to provide excellent spin and control. Its ergonomic grip ensures comfort, making it ideal for players seeking to enhance their game with power, precision, and reliability on the court. This high-performance paddle is perfect for those looking to elevate their play to the next level.

‚Äç

Advanced (DUPR Rating: 5.6-8)

‚Äç

Advanced players have mastered control and technique and may benefit from a high-performance paddle that amplifies power and precision. These paddles often have a smaller sweet spot and require skillful control, making them ideal for experienced players.

‚Äç

Recommended Paddles for Advanced Players:

JOOLA Vision CGS 16: For players who prioritize power, the JOOLA Vision CGS 16 delivers explosive shots. Its lightweight design with an elongated shape enhances reach, perfect for players who have mastered control and are ready to dominate on offense.
GAMMA Airbender 16: The GAMMA Airbender 16 offers unmatched customizability with its adjustable end cap weighting system and Zorbicon Shockbuster gel insert to reduce vibrations. Its design enhances maneuverability, maximizes spin and control, and provides the perfect balance of power, comfort, and precision.‚Äç
ACE Club: The ACE Club Paddle offers a perfect balance of power, control, and comfort. Its 8.1 oz weight design delivers maximum power without the added weight, while the comfortable grip reduces fatigue, ensuring reliable performance during extended play.

‚Äç

Types of Pickleball Paddles: Control vs. Power

‚Äç

Beyond skill level, understanding whether you prioritize control or power in a paddle is essential to selecting the right one. Here‚Äôs a breakdown to help you decide:

‚Äç

Control Paddles

‚Äç

Control paddles, sometimes called ‚Äútouch‚Äù paddles, feature a larger, consistent sweet spot that helps players control placement and accuracy. These paddles generally have a thicker core and are a great fit for players who focus on defense and strategic placement.

‚Äç

Recommended Control Paddles:

JOOLA CGS 14: Ideal for intermediate players, with excellent shot accuracy.‚Äç
GAMMA Fusion React: Great for beginners learning control.

‚Äç

Power Paddles

‚Äç

Power paddles deliver added speed on each hit, making them perfect for players who want to put their opponents on the defensive. They often have a thinner core and a smaller sweet spot, making them a better match for advanced players who have developed their control and need a paddle that enhances their power game.

‚Äç

Recommended Power Paddles:

JOOLA Vision CGS 16: Best for advanced players who want a powerful edge.‚Äç
ACE Diamond: A high-performing option for advanced players.

‚Äç

Final thoughts

‚Äç

Whether you‚Äôre new to pickleball or aiming for the next level in your game, choosing the right pickleball paddle is crucial to maximizing your performance. From beginner-friendly options to high-powered paddles, finding the right paddle can transform your game and help you boost your DUPR to unlock the best player inside you!

title: How St. Louis Shock Leverages DUPR to Build a Thriving Pickleball Community
summary: Learn how St. Louis Shock uses DUPR to grow its pickleball community, engage fans, and enhance brand loyalty with exciting events and future plans.
content:
Your DUPR rating reflects more than just your on-court performance. It represents your progression as a complete pickleball athlete.

‚Äç

Many players focus solely on drills and gameplay, neglecting the crucial physical and mental foundations. This oversight often leads to plateaus, injuries, and competitive frustration. Let's change that.

‚Äç

This guide will show you exactly what to focus on at each stage of your pickleball development, from novice to pro.

‚Äç

Novice (2.000 - 2.999): Master the Fundamentals

‚Äç

Many new players rush straight into gameplay, skipping essential preparation routines.

This eagerness often results in preventable injuries and slower skill development.

Establish a consistent 10-minute dynamic warmup to help you start fast, improve mobility, and prevent injury
Develop a 5-minute post-play cooldown routine to enhance recovery and improve flexibility

Research demonstrates significant injury rate reductions among those who perform structured warm-ups compared to those who don't (1,2,3).

Here's the key: higher compliance with warm-up programs correlates with greater injury prevention. Even warming up once a week is beneficial, with increased frequency providing additional protective effects (4,5).

If you don‚Äôt know where to start, our partners at AIM7 have built a free warmup guide with video instructions. You can download it here.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Intermediate (3.000 - 3.999): Physical Resilience

‚Äç

Intermediate players face a critical transition in their physical and mental demands.

This stage presents the highest injury risk due to increased court time and competitive play.

To mitigate injury and to take the next step in your global development, you should introduce a structured resistance training program into your regiment. Add at least two total-body strength sessions weekly to build robust tissues, foundational balance, strength, and power. In addition, strength training develops resilient muscles, bones, tendons, and ligaments, which is critical for longevity in the sport.

Consistently engaging in structured warmups, cooldowns, and bi-weekly resistance training will create a solid foundation for long-term physical resilience.

‚Äç

‚Äç

Now, let's examine what advanced players need to focus on.

‚Äç

Advanced (4.000 - 4.999): Mental Game and Recovery

‚Äç

Advanced players must integrate basic psychological skills with systematic fueling and recovery protocols.

This dual focus will determine performance consistency in high-stakes competitive environments.

Implement research-backed mental preparation techniques (breathwork, visualization, mindfulness)
Develop comprehensive match-day nutrition and hydration strategies
Create structured recovery routines that enhance sleep quality and tissue repair

At this level, technical mastery alone won't secure victory. The psychological battleground becomes paramount, where strategic decisions under pressure define match outcomes. Your ability to maintain mental clarity while managing physical resources becomes the critical performance differentiator.

The advanced player's success framework integrates three core domains:

Mental Performance Architecture:

Self Regulation: Mastering pre-point breathing patterns and emotional control
Attentional Focus: Developing robust visualization and mindfulness practices
Decision-Making Under Press: Building systematic decision-making frameworks for crucial moments

Fueling & Recovery Fundamentals:

Hydration Protocols: Personalized pre/during/post-match fluid strategies
Nutritional Timing: Strategic fueling for matches and tournament progression
Sleep: Evidence-based routines for restful and fulfilling sleep

Players who invest in this integrated approach will experience more consistent performance.

‚Äç

‚Äç

The professional level demands even more sophisticated performance optimization strategies.

‚Äç

Pro (5.000 - 8.000): High-Performance Systems

‚Äç

Professional players must manage multiple performance variables simultaneously.

Success requires systematic monitoring and adjustment of all training elements.

Track subjective and objective performance metrics daily (e.g., HRV, training load,¬† subjective wellness, etc.)
Work with qualified specialists (e.g., nutrition, mental game, strength, etc.)
Implement science-backed recovery tools and protocols.

Top professionals work with a high performance team to improve the physical, psychological, technical, and tactical elements of the game.¬†

‚Äç

‚Äç

The Path Forward

‚Äç

Your pickleball journey requires a different focus at each stage. Identify where you are now, and simply take the next step.¬†

References: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

content:
At the forefront of pickleball‚Äôs rising popularity in St. Louis, the St. Louis Shock is tapping into the power of DUPR to not only grow their brand but also foster a loyal community of pickleball enthusiasts. The Shock is one of the teams in Major League Pickleball (MLP) dedicated to engaging local players and fans while building a dynamic community around the sport. According to Andrew Haines, Chief Operating Officer of the Shock, these events are pivotal in the team‚Äôs strategy.

‚Äç

"We‚Äôre really trying to build our brand both locally and nationally," Haines said. "Anything we can do to engage players, whether at an amateur or advanced level, funnels into our long-term plans.‚Äù

‚Äç

DUPR events are one of the primary vehicles for building that local fan base, attracting players who want to get rated and improve their game. The events are structured around maximizing playing time, keeping the energy high and the downtime low. The Shock has tried various formats to optimize each session.

‚Äç

"On Friday, we changed it up to two sessions so players could get almost non-stop playtime," Haines explained. "Our goal is to do these weekly and create a community of Shock followers who feel like they're part of the family and team."

‚Äç

Why DUPR?

For teams like the St. Louis Shock, DUPR is more than just a rating system‚Äîit‚Äôs a marketing tool that brings people together and boosts brand recognition. Ryan Maher, Vice President of Partnerships & Programs at DUPR and local to St Louis, noted these events' power:

‚Äç

"These rating sessions are incredible. For a professional team to be promoting DUPR as their partner is all we could ask for,"

‚Äç

Maher said, emphasizing how these sessions benefit both organizations. As more players get rated, DUPR grows its user base, while the Shock builds brand loyalty and draws more local fans into the fold. The events are not only attracting players‚Äîthey‚Äôre selling out quickly. For instance, the first two events filled up in less than 24 hours. As Haines described,

‚Äç

"We charge a small fee that covers registration and a Shock item, like a shirt or hat, and it‚Äôs been incredibly popular. We even had people asking about future events before we‚Äôd wrapped up the current one."

‚Äç

‚Äç

The Future Vision for St. Louis Shock

‚Äç

The St. Louis Shock has ambitious plans, not just locally but nationally. Haines and his team are working on establishing their own venue, aiming to host pickleball events year-round and to become the community hub for pickleball in St. Louis.

‚Äç

"We hope to open our own facility soon, we want it to be the go-to spot for pickleball in St. Louis," Haines said. ‚ÄúAnd this will coincide with some larger goals as well, we want to do everything possible to host MLP at Chaifetz, a 10,000-seat state-of-the-art venue at Saint Louis University‚Äù. Maher was enthusiastic about the venue‚Äôs potential, adding, "There will not be an MLP event that rivals this. Central Park was amazing, but this arena will be unbelievable."

‚Äç

The team is also exploring ways to involve its players more directly with the community. However, with team members spread across the country, flying everyone in is both time-consuming and costly.

‚Äç

"All the teams are in the same boat,‚Äù said Haines. "But by the time we bring players in, we want to make sure it‚Äôs a huge event that really leverages the local fan base we‚Äôve built through these DUPR sessions.‚Äù

‚Äç

Cultivating Connections and Expanding Nationally

‚Äç

As the Shock deepens its local presence, it‚Äôs also looking to set the standard in the MLP. By sharing its success with other teams, Haines hopes the Shock can inspire similar community engagement efforts across the league.

‚Äç

"I‚Äôm getting a lot of calls from other teams wanting to set up their own DUPR events," Haines said. "We share ideas on what we‚Äôre doing in the community, and I‚Äôm a big proponent of these DUPR sessions. It‚Äôs a no-brainer for all the teams."

‚Äç

‚Äç

The collaboration between St. Louis Shock and DUPR is setting a model for what‚Äôs possible when professional sports teams work directly with the communities they represent. The St Louis Shock is the first MLP team to have an Official Club on DUPR. The Shock‚Äôs dedication to building this community isn‚Äôt just about expanding its brand‚Äîit‚Äôs about elevating pickleball as a sport, engaging new players, and creating fans who feel a personal connection to the team.

‚Äç

With DUPR sessions selling out and pickleball fever spreading in St. Louis, the Shock is well on its way to becoming the heartbeat of the city‚Äôs pickleball scene. As Haines put it:

‚Äç

"Our goal is to build a community of Shock followers, and this is just the beginning of something bigger for St. Louis.‚Äù

‚Äç

‚Äç

Check out the St Louis Shock schedule for the upcoming season, and find out more on how to set up your DUPR¬†rating session here!

title: Mastering Pickleball: Training Techniques and Tips for Improvement
summary: Learn expert training techniques, grip styles, essential shots, and spin strategies. Plus, see how improving your skills can boost your pickleball rating and introduce you to RPPK.
content:
In the world of racquet sports, pickleball and tennis are two of the most popular choices. Both offer exciting gameplay, but they have distinct characteristics that make each unique. If you‚Äôre curious about pickleball vs. tennis and wondering how they differ, you‚Äôre in the right place! Let‚Äôs explore the key differences and answer the question: Is pickleball easier than tennis?

‚Äç

How Is Pickleball Different from Tennis?

Understanding the differences between pickleball and tennis can enhance your appreciation for each sport. From the dimensions of the court to the nature of the equipment used, these elements shape the gameplay and experience.

Court Size
Pickleball courts are smaller‚Äî20 feet wide and 44 feet long‚Äîcompared to tennis courts, which are 36 feet wide and 78 feet long. This smaller size makes pickleball more accessible for players of all ages and skill levels, as it requires less physical endurance and allows for quicker reactions.
Equipment
In pickleball, players use a solid paddle and a plastic ball with holes, while tennis players use a strung racquet and a felt-covered ball. The equipment changes how each game feels and plays. The design of pickleball paddles, which can vary in weight and material, influences gameplay, allowing for different styles of play. The lighter, perforated ball used in pickleball travels more slowly, which can create longer rallies and more strategic exchanges.
Scoring
Pickleball has a simpler scoring system. Points can only be scored by the serving team, and games are usually played to 11, 15, or 21 points, with a win by at least 2 points. In contrast, tennis has a more complex system involving games, sets, and tiebreakers, making matches longer and sometimes more strategic.
Serve Style
Pickleball serves are underhand and require the ball to clear the non-volley zone (the kitchen), which encourages a more strategic approach to gameplay. Tennis serves are typically powerful and overhand, allowing for a wider variety of serve types, including spin and speed variations. This difference significantly impacts the pace and rhythm of each game.

‚Äç

Is Pickleball Easier Than Tennis?

While the question of whether pickleball is easier than tennis depends on personal preference, here are a few reasons why some find pickleball more beginner-friendly:

Less Running: The smaller court size means players cover less ground, making it easier on the legs and reducing the risk of injury, especially for older players.
Simple Rules: With straightforward scoring and serving, newcomers can pick it up quickly, making it less intimidating for beginners.
Social Vibe: Pickleball is often played in doubles, creating a fun and friendly atmosphere that encourages interaction and teamwork. This can make it more inviting for those new to racquet sports.

‚Äç

Overall, when comparing pickleball vs. tennis, both sports offer excellent ways to stay active and have fun. Whether you‚Äôre drawn to the strategic rallies of tennis or the friendly vibe of pickleball, there‚Äôs something for everyone. Why not give pickleball a shot? You might just discover your new favorite game!

title: The Ultimate Guide to Pickleball Nets: Finding the Right Fit
summary: Discover the best portable, indoor, and outdoor pickleball nets to fit your space and playing style. Plus, see how choosing the right net can enhance your game and improve your pickleball rating!
content:
Pickleball, a dynamic and engaging sport, has rapidly gained popularity among players of all ages. Whether you‚Äôre a novice eager to learn or an experienced player looking to refine your skills, focusing on training techniques and understanding the fundamentals of the game is essential. In this blog post, we‚Äôll explore key areas of pickleball training, including grip, shots, spin, and strategies to improve your overall game.

‚Äç

Understanding the Pickleball Grip

One of the first steps to enhancing your pickleball game is mastering the pickleball grip. The grip you choose can significantly impact your control and the power of your shots. Here are three popular grips to consider:

Eastern Grip: Similar to the grip used in tennis, the eastern grip allows for versatile shot-making and a good balance of power and control.
Continental Grip: This grip is favored for its adaptability, making it ideal for various shots, including serves and volleys. It‚Äôs particularly effective for players who like to mix their spins and angles.
Western Grip: Primarily used for topspin shots, the western grip can be useful if you want to put more spin on your ball, especially during rallies.

Experiment with different grips to see which one feels most comfortable and effective for you. A proper grip not only improves your shot accuracy but also reduces the risk of injury.

‚Äç

Essential Pickleball Shots

To get better at pickleball, it‚Äôs crucial to master a range of pickleball shots. Here are the foundational shots every player should practice:

Forehand and Backhand Drives: These shots are your primary offensive tools. Focus on footwork and body positioning to ensure powerful and accurate strikes.
Dinks: A gentle shot that lands just over the net, dinks are essential for controlling the pace of the game and forcing your opponent to make a mistake.
Volleys: Mastering volleys allows you to take advantage of opportunities at the net. Focus on quick reactions and maintaining your paddle position.
Serves: Your serve sets the tone for each rally. A strong and varied serve can keep opponents on their toes.

‚Äç

The Art of Pickleball Spin

Incorporating pickleball spin into your shots can give you a competitive edge. Here are a few techniques to develop spin in your game:

Topspin: Achieved by brushing up on the ball, topspin allows for a higher net clearance and a sharper descent. It can be especially effective for both serves and groundstrokes.
Backspin: When you brush down on the ball, backspin causes it to stay low after bouncing, making it difficult for opponents to return.
Side Spin: This spin is created by hitting the ball on its side, causing it to curve in the air. It can be a surprise tactic during serves or rallies.

Experimenting with different spins during your practice sessions will help you discover how to best utilize them in matches.

‚Äç

Improving Your Pickleball Backhand

Many players struggle with their backhand. Here are some tips to enhance your backhand game:

Stance: Ensure your feet are shoulder-width apart, and your knees are slightly bent to maintain balance.
Grip: Use either the eastern or continental grip for more control and power in your backhand shots.
Follow Through: A proper follow-through is essential. Ensure your paddle moves through the ball and finishes high to generate power.
Practice: Set aside dedicated practice time for your backhand. Repetitive drills will help you gain confidence and consistency.

‚Äç

Elevating Your Pickleball Serve

Your pickleball serve is your first opportunity to dictate the point. Here‚Äôs how to improve it:

Practice Different Types of Serves: Work on your underhand, topspin, and slice serves. Varying your serves can make you less predictable to your opponents.
Focus on Accuracy: Aim for specific areas of the service box to improve your serve's effectiveness. Hitting the sidelines or targeting your opponent‚Äôs weak side can give you a strategic advantage.
Develop a Consistent Toss: A consistent toss helps in achieving a reliable serve. Practice your toss to ensure it‚Äôs at the right height and position every time.

‚Äç

RPPK Certification for Coaches

For those looking to take their pickleball skills to the next level and possibly share their knowledge with others, consider pursuing certification through the RPPK (Registered Pickleball Professional Coach) program. This program offers aspiring coaches a structured pathway to become certified and gain valuable experience. If you're interested in becoming a certified coach, visit DUPR's certification page to learn more.

‚Äç

Conclusion

Improving your pickleball skills takes dedication, practice, and a willingness to learn. By focusing on your pickleball grip, mastering essential pickleball shots, incorporating spin, enhancing your backhand, and refining your serve, you‚Äôll find yourself becoming a more well-rounded player. So grab your paddle, hit the courts, and enjoy the journey of becoming a better pickleball player! Happy playing!

title: DUPR: The Game-Changing Rating System Uniting Pickleball Worldwide
summary: DUPR connects players worldwide with accurate pickleball ratings, creating fair competition and fostering growth in the global pickleball community.
content:
Pickleball can be played almost anywhere‚Äîfrom your gym to your driveway. To get the most out of your game, it‚Äôs essential to find a pickleball net that suits your environment. Whether you need an indoor, outdoor, or portable pickleball net, there‚Äôs an option for every setting. Let‚Äôs explore the different types of nets and how to choose the best one for your needs.

‚Äç

Understanding Pickleball Nets

When shopping for a pickleball net, consider where you‚Äôll play and how often you‚Äôll set it up. Standard nets are 36 inches high at the sides and 34 inches in the middle, but designs vary widely.

‚Äç

Portable Pickleball Nets: Play Anywhere

Portable nets offer flexibility for players on the go. They‚Äôre easy to set up and ideal for use in multiple locations like your driveway, a friend‚Äôs house, or a park. Look for lightweight options with sturdy frames and adjustable heights.

‚Äç

Pickleball Nets for Your Driveway

Transform your driveway into a personal court with a pickleball net designed for home use. Choose a weather-resistant net with durable frames to withstand outdoor conditions, ensuring it fits comfortably in your space.

‚Äç

Indoor Pickleball Nets: Bringing the Game Inside

Indoor nets make it easy to play when the weather isn‚Äôt ideal. Look for nets with stable bases and non-marking feet to protect floors and ensure a safe game environment in gyms or basements.

‚Äç

Outdoor Pickleball Nets: Built for Tough Conditions

Outdoor nets are made to handle the elements, with materials that resist UV rays and moisture. Stability is key‚Äîopt for heavy-duty frames with ground stakes to keep your net secure on windy days.

‚Äç

Choosing the Right Pickleball Net

With so many options, choosing the right net can be tough. Here are some quick tips:

Portability: Choose lightweight, foldable options with carrying cases.
Driveway Use: Look for weather-resistant nets that fit your space.
Indoor Use: Find stable nets with non-marking feet.
Outdoor Use: Select rust-resistant materials and sturdy frames.

‚Äç

Elevate Your Game with the Right Net

No matter where you play, the right pickleball net can enhance your game. Explore your options, find the perfect net, and enjoy endless hours of pickleball, whether at home or on the go. Happy playing!

title: 3 Steps to Build Mental Strength to Dominate on the Pickleball Court
summary: Struggling under pressure on the pickleball court? Learn proven mental training techniques to stay composed, make better decisions, and watch your pickleball rating improve.
content:
After 16 Campus Regionals, 9 Super Regionals, and now the Collegiate National Championship, the 2024 collegiate season has been completed! Just two years ago, there hadn‚Äôt been a single collegiate event‚Äîand a year from now, we‚Äôll already be halfway through our fifth season. All the collegiate pickleball growth is due to the players and teams that show up to each tournament, bring their A-game, and continue to expand out their collegiate pickleball club at their school.¬†

‚Äç

By the numbers, here‚Äôs how far we‚Äôve come:

The 2025 season events have been announced, you can read more on the upcoming season here! We will be adding more campus regionals and more dual matches into the calendar to foster localized competition. Our big change in 2025 will be moving the National Championship to be at the end of the spring semester instead of the fall. This means our next Nationals will be April 11th-13th, 2025!

‚Äç

Nationals Numbers¬†

Going into the 2025 season, our defending champions will be the Utah Tech Trailblazers from St. George, Utah! After coming close to winning the first two National Championships, they finally clinched it with their stellar performance at the 2024 Nationals. They are the only champions to not drop a single game in the semifinals and finals, beating UNC 3-0 in the semis and UVA 3-0 in the finals. Those wins were significant too, as those were the two schools that had stopped Utah Tech from becoming the champion in 2022 (UNC) and 2023 (UVA).¬†

‚Äç

This tournament proved once again that you cannot underestimate the power of the fans in collegiate matchups. UNC and UVA brought the most players to the 2024 Nationals, and everyone in the building knew it with the cheering that occurred between each point. Those cheers powered UNC to a nailbiter win over Utah Valley in the quarterfinals, and UVA over Clemson in the semifinals.¬†

‚Äç

With the 2025 Nationals only five months away, there were 24 bids given out at the 2024 Nationals to speed up the process. Here are the recipients of those bids based on their finish in the tournament:

‚Äç

Champion Utah Tech
Runner-Up UVA
Semifinals UNC
Semifinals Clemson
Quarterfinals FAU
Quarterfinals Utah Valley
Quarterfinals Indiana
Quarterfinals NC State
Round of 16 Texas A&M
Round of 16 Miami (FL)
Round of 16 Drury
Round of 16 TCU
Round of 16 Virginia Tech
Round of 16 Purdue
Round of 16 UT Austin
Round of 16 USC
Round of 32 Bowl Winner UT Arlington
Round of 32 Bowl Winner FSU
Round of 32 Bowl Winner Baylor
Round of 32 Bowl Winner Samford
Round of 32 Bowl Winner Mississippi State
Round of 32 Bowl Winner UF
Round of 32 Bowl Winner GCU
Round of 32 Bowl Winner Michigan

‚Äç

All in all, Nationals was a huge success this year! 500 players and 64 teams competing in the single elimination format made it truly electric. Fans and players were hanging onto every point, especially in our FAU vs. Clemson and UNC vs. Utah Valley Dreambreakers in the quarterfinals.

‚Äç

With the 3rd season of collegiate pickleball behind us, it has become clear that they are three collegiate pickleball ‚Äúblue bloods‚Äù. Schools that have been competitively dominant year after year, are very well organized, and are models for other schools to follow in both on-court and off-court success. These three schools are of course UNC, UVA, and Utah Tech. Here are some stats to show how dominant these blue bloods have been compared to the rest of the field:

‚Äç

Blue Bloods

The blue blood teams have only lost to themselves at Nationals, with the exception of TCU beating UVA in group play in 2022. Since each of those schools have been to two finals, it means there are no schools that have been to a single finals, either two or zero for each school. Will these blue blood schools maintain their dominance in the 2025 season, or can any challengers (Utah Valley, FAU, Clemson, Indiana, NC State) make it to the finals?

‚Äç

‚Äç

To see the action from the tournament yourself, check out the recording of the semifinals and finals here on the PPA YouTube channel.

‚Äç

A special thanks goes to our DUPR Collegiate Pickleball partners: JOOLA, HEAD, GAMMA, Rally Republic, Osaka, No Apologies Nutrition, Erne, Pickleball Superstore, and Total Pickleball. Another thanks goes to the UPA World Championship in Dallas, TX for hosting us in this amazing tournament!

Watch now!

‚Äç

If you haven't already, check out our CNC recaps on Instagram and follow us to stay updated!

title: The 2024 Collegiate National Championship: Semi-Finals and Finals Await
summary: Watch the exciting 2024 Collegiate National Championship semi-finals and finals with Utah Tech, UNC, UVA, and Clemson. Who will claim the title?
content:
You're up 9-7 in the third game of a tournament match. Then everything falls apart.

‚Äç

One bad shot leads to another. Your confidence crumbles. Your thoughts race. Before you know it, you've lost the match 11-9. Sound familiar? Most players focus solely on technique and tactics. Yet mental strength often determines who wins close matches. The good news? Mental strength can be trained.

‚Äç

Here's how to transform from a reactive player into a composed competitor who thrives under pressure.

‚Äç

1. Master Self-Regulation: Stop Emotional Spirals Before They Start

We've all watched a player implode after a few bad points.

‚Äç

Their frustration snowballs into a complete meltdown, taking their game down with it.

‚Äç

Start with Awareness

Self-regulation begins with awareness. Many players tank because they aren't in control of their attention. Mindfulness trains attentional awareness and empowers you to understand your mental state. When you notice uncomfortable thoughts and emotions early, you can shift attention to positive action.

‚Äç

Master Your Tools

Once awareness is established, you have several powerful tools you can use to regulate your state:

‚ÄçBreathwork:

Extended exhale breathing calms your nervous system during high-stress moments
Box breathing (4-4-4-4) improves focus between points
Practice these techniques during drills to make them automatic
Release-Reset-Refocus Framework:
Release: Make a conscious physical action to let go of the mistake and to deal with it later.
Clap your hands
Tap your paddle
Use a specific phrase
Choose one consistent signal to release negative energy
Reset: Ground yourself in the present moment using a physical or verbal cue.
Take a deep breath
Count to five
Do a quick body scan
Refocus: Direct your attention to what's important now (WIN). Focus your attention on something actionable, in your control, and present-focused.
Check opponent positioning
Focus on your serve routine
Return to your game plan

When you control your emotional state, you control the match. Your opponents can't rattle you.

‚Äç

2. Build Decision-Making Skills Under Pressure: Make Winning Choices When It Matters

Most players freeze or panic in crucial moments.

‚Äç

Their mind goes blank, and they resort to desperate low-percentage shots.

‚Äç

The CLEAR Framework

Adapted from military decision-making models, CLEAR gives you a structured approach:

‚ÄçCourt position: Where are you on the court?

Kitchen line
Mid-court
Backcourt
Position determines your options

Look: What's the tactical situation?

Opponent positions
Court coverage
Movement patterns
Identify vulnerabilities

Evaluate: What's your highest percentage play?

Available shots
Risk vs reward
Score context
Choose based on position and patterns

Act: Commit fully to your decision

No hesitation
Complete follow-through
Trust your preparation

Reset: Return to the one-point mentality

Use Release-Reset-Refocus
Stay present
Prepare for the next point

Better decisions in crucial moments lead directly to more wins.

‚Äç

3. Develop Resilience: Turn Setbacks into Comebacks

Every player faces setbacks, but few know how to learn from them.

‚Äç

Most either ignore failures or let them destroy their confidence.

‚Äç

The ADAPT Framework

ADAPT transforms setbacks into growth opportunities:

‚ÄçAcknowledge: Face the setback without judgment

Process emotional response
Accept the current reality
Create space for learning

Distill: Extract specific lessons

Break down what happened
Identify patterns
Find actionable insights

Adjust: Modify your approach

Develop tactical solutions
Refine mental game
Create specific practice plans

Practice: Implement changes systematically

Focus on deliberate practice
Progressive challenge levels
Build new patterns

Test: Evaluate in competition

Apply changes under pressure
Gather performance data
Continue refining approach

Each cycle through ADAPT builds both skill and mental toughness. The framework turns frustration into focused improvement.

‚Äç

The Path Forward

Mental strength separates good players from great ones.

‚Äç

This isn't just about bouncing back ‚Äì it's about continuous growth. Start with self-regulation as your foundation. Build your decision-making framework through CLEAR. Use ADAPT to transform challenges into improvements. Practice these skills daily, not just during matches.

‚Äç

Training your mental game requires the same dedication as technical skills. But the payoff is enormous. You'll stay composed under pressure. Make better decisions when it matters. Turn setbacks into comebacks.

‚Äç

Next Step:¬†

Choose one aspect of self-regulation to practice this week. Notice when you get frustrated. Apply breathwork or Release-Reset-Refocus. Track your recovery time from setbacks.

‚Äç

Remember: Your mindset is a muscle. Train it consistently. Watch your game transform.

‚Äç

To learn more, visit https://www.aim7.com/

‚Äç

By Alex Auerbach, PhD & Erik Korem, PhD

content:
Today, the 2024 Collegiate National Championship (CNC) enters into semis and finals, with the University of North Carolina (UNC), Utah Tech University, the University of Virginia (UVA), and Clemson University competing in the semi-finals. Only one #1 seed‚ÄîUtah Tech‚Äîhas made it to this round.

Familiar Ground for Some, New Territory for Clemson

UNC and Utah Tech: A Championship Rematch

The Utah Tech vs. UNC semi-final is a rematch of the 2023 CNC finals, adding extra weight to today's game. Sarah Carpenter from UNC is the only returning player from last year‚Äôs final, bringing some valuable experience to her team. Utah Tech‚Äôs presence as the lone #1 seed in the semi-finals speaks to their consistency and drive to reclaim their 2023 Collegiate National Championship title.

The quarterfinals saw some tight matches, especially Clemson‚Äôs matchup against Florida Atlantic University and UNC‚Äôs matches against Utah Valley. Many matches are decided through the Dreambreaker format, highlighting the intensity of this year‚Äôs competition and how close many of the matches have been.

‚Äç

Championship Sunday

Today, the stakes couldn‚Äôt be higher, with Utah Tech aiming to make good on their #1 seed status, while UNC, UVA, and Clemson each bring their own edge to the competition. With a mix of returning finalists and new contenders, make sure you tune into the live stream to see who will come out on top in this year‚Äôs championship.

title: Inside the 2024 National Junior Pickleball Championship Cup
summary: The 2024 National Junior Pickleball Championship in Houston showcased rising talent, strong sportsmanship, and the influence of pickleball ratings through DUPR.
content:
Pickleball, once a niche sport, has exploded in popularity, growing from casual backyard games into a dynamic community that blends competition with camaraderie. Central to this rise is David Tabb, a pickleball enthusiast and event organizer whose nearly decade-long involvement has shaped the Florida pickleball scene into what it is today. Tabb‚Äôs events combine the spirit of fun with structured competition, fostering a community-driven environment that leaves participants feeling rejuvenated and eager for more.

‚Äç

A Passion for Pickleball: The Beginnings

David Tabb‚Äôs journey with pickleball began almost nine years ago on a roller hockey rink in Holiday Park, Fort Lauderdale. Reflecting on those early days, Tabb says, "I started playing about nine years ago before it was cool, and we played on a roller hockey rink here in Holiday Park, Fort Lauderdale." As the sport gained traction, he started organizing local drill sessions and small-scale events that laid the foundation for his larger endeavors. His early tournaments emphasized community, bringing people together for friendly competition. Over time, these events grew, evolving into more structured competitions while maintaining the lighthearted, fun atmosphere that Tabb is known for. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd always go out to lunch afterward, and we played tournaments. It was double elimination. You‚Äôd wait for a long time. Nobody knew how to tell what anybody was rated,‚Äù Tabb recalls.

‚Äç

The Challenge of Ratings: Enter DUPR

As pickleball's popularity soared, so did the demand for competitive fairness. One major challenge Tabb faced early on was the lack of an accurate rating system for players, which made it difficult to run tournaments that fairly reflected players‚Äô skill levels. "At the club in West Palm Beach, we actually had a competitive team... but we didn‚Äôt actually have ratings," Tabb says, explaining how difficult it was to organize skill-based events. That all changed when he was introduced to DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating), a tool that allowed for more consistent player ratings. This innovation helped take Tabb's tournaments to the next level, offering competitive, yet accessible, events where players of all levels could shine. He recalls, ‚ÄúI got introduced to Lee Whitwell... She introduced me to some guy named Tito, and Tito was like, ‚ÄòHey, we have this thing called DUPR Digital Club... Would you be interested?‚Äô‚Äù

‚Äç

Minor League Pickleball

David Tabb became the first Tournament Director to host a Minor League Pickleball event, a groundbreaking platform for both casual and competitive players to engage in high-energy tournaments that break away from the traditional mold. With locations like GT Bray Park in Bradenton, Florida, these events quickly became a hit, known for their focus on fun and creativity. Instead of adhering to rigid double-elimination formats, Tabb fostered an environment where players felt encouraged to take risks and attempt challenging shots. His catchphrase, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fun to do bad things,‚Äù became a playful rallying cry, inviting players to embrace the joy of the game rather than just focusing on winning.

Reflecting on these events, Tabb explains, ‚ÄúWe threw the first-ever amateur [minor league event] at GT Bray... It was a lot of fun. It was a mess, it was hilarious. There were spreadsheets and people playing on different courts at the same time, but it was a lot of fun.‚Äù Despite the initial chaos, the format was a hit, and requests for similar events began to pour in.

‚Äç

Halloween Event at All State FloridA, 2023
Minor League Pickleball

‚Äç

‚Äç

The Key to Successful Tournaments: Fun and Emotional Engagement

David Tabb‚Äôs success in hosting tournaments goes beyond pickleball skills‚Äîhis events thrive on emotional connection and community spirit. Whether it‚Äôs the rock music playing in the background or the unique, themed events, the goal is always to ensure that participants leave feeling both energized and emotionally connected to the game. His approach includes everything from fun costumes at events like ‚ÄúFright Against Cancer‚Äù to professional photographers capturing players' best moments. Tabb‚Äôs goal? ‚ÄúWe want you to feel refreshed, revived that you had a great experience, and you go and talk to your colleagues or your friends about the event on Monday.‚Äù

Tabb also emphasizes the community aspect: ‚ÄúYou never know what the person across from you is going through. Monday morning, there are people that are going back to their families who just got diagnosed with cancer, who just lost a loved one... but that weekend, they were able to escape and play and have fun.‚Äù

‚Äç

Creativity and Community: Enhancing the Tournament Experience

Tabb‚Äôs events stand out because of his creative touches. His ‚ÄúPimp My Paddle‚Äù station, where players can customize their paddles and outfits, is just one example of how he adds personal flair to every tournament. Additionally, themed tournaments like the holiday-inspired ‚ÄúReindeer Games‚Äù and quirky prizes turn his events into community celebrations that extend beyond the sport itself. ‚ÄúWe did one last year at Picktona... It was the ‚ÄòFright Against Cancer,‚Äô and we had people dressed up in Halloween costumes. I was running around as a bank robber,‚Äù Tabb says, reflecting on one of his fun-themed events. The emphasis is always on creating an inclusive environment where both seasoned players and newcomers feel welcome.

‚Äç

David Tabb‚Äôs Formula for Fun: Bringing Joy, Charity, and Community Together

Beyond the fun, Tabb‚Äôs events often serve a higher purpose by supporting charitable causes. His tournaments frequently feature food drives and fundraisers that benefit local communities, turning a day of competition into something even more meaningful. Players can give back while enjoying the game, and the spirit of giving adds another layer to the experience. From his legendary pre-game speeches to quirky features like pumpkin carving contests during matches, Tabb knows how to make an event stand out.

One of Tabb‚Äôs signature touches is his attention to the emotional side of competition. ‚ÄúWe do long speeches... and we talk about charity, raising close to $100,000 this year. We also remind people that the person across from them might be going through something tough, but this weekend is their escape,‚Äù Tabb explains. He emphasizes that his tournaments are about more than just winning‚Äîthey‚Äôre about rejuvenation and connection.

‚Äç

Conclusion: The Power of Fun and Community

David Tabb‚Äôs journey is a testament to the power of combining passion, creativity, and community in sports. By focusing on emotional engagement and memorable experiences, Tabb has created a pickleball community that goes beyond the court. His tournaments are more than just games‚Äîthey‚Äôre opportunities for people to come together, support great causes, and share in the joy that pickleball brings.

‚Äç

Recommended Spotify Playlist: Upbeat Classic Rock
Next Event: Bardmoor Betterball, November 14th

‚Äç

If you haven‚Äôt yet experienced one of David‚Äôs events, you‚Äôre missing out on a pickleball tournament like no other. As he always says, ‚ÄúIf it‚Äôs fun, we‚Äôre in!‚Äù

‚Äç

title: UVA Adds to Trophy Collection Before Their Title Defense in November
summary: UVA claims their first Super Regional championship by defeating UNC. Read about the Virginia Beach tournament and teams securing bids for the 2024 Nationals.
content:
This year‚Äôs National Junior Pickleball (NJP) Championship Cup in Houston set a new benchmark in junior pickleball, bringing together young players from 18 states, as far as Alaska and Canada, to compete, connect, and celebrate the sport.¬†

The energy was electric, with families, friends, and players filling the venue with their enthusiasm and team spirit. Founder of National Junior Pickleball (NJP), Courtney Loughridge shares her experience with us: "The energy and enthusiasm from players and families, along with the new friendships formed, exceeded every expectation," she shares, ‚ÄúFrom clinics to clinics to championship matches, each day was packed with excitement.‚Äù

The event kicked off with an engaging evening of clinics, which provided juniors with a chance to connect and break the ice before diving into three days of intense competition. The weekend unfolded with Singles, Doubles, and Team events, all set within a positive and competitive atmosphere. It was clear that NJP‚Äôs mission of fostering a community-centered tournament was alive and well.

Standout Performances and Memorable Moments

"Our tournament was filled with incredible moments‚Äîfrom ATPs and hand battles to thrilling rallies, including a singles game that ended with a nail-biting 27-25 score," noted Courtney. The young athletes not only brought competitive spirit but also showcased remarkable sportsmanship and camaraderie‚Äîa hallmark of NJP events.

Among the highlights were the Gold Medal Champions in each Advanced age division. These players proudly hoisted the coveted golden Championship Cup and donned the exclusive Championship Cup jackets‚Äîa unique twist on the usual medal awards. Three players were also honored with Sportsmanship Awards, a tribute to their exceptional spirit, resilience, and kindness on and off the court.

The Rise of Junior Pickleball

This year has marked explosive growth in junior pickleball. NJP witnessed a surge in young beginners joining tournaments and a significant increase in girls' participation across all age divisions. "We were thrilled to see an increase in girls' participation, especially in the 12U age group," shared Courtney. Offering divisions such as Girls Singles Advanced, Intermediate, and Beginner in this age group is a promising sign that young girls are embracing the sport with enthusiasm.

‚Äç

How DUPR Transformed the Tournament Experience

The DUPR rating system has been a game-changer for NJP, helping the organizers place players in appropriate skill divisions based on existing ratings and allowing newcomers to establish theirs. For many, NJP was their first competitive experience, and having their tournament results entered into DUPR has given players a clear sense of their skill level. This transparency and structure have enhanced the tournament experience for both beginner and intermediate players, who now have a tangible way to track their progress.

Looking Ahead: The Future of NJP and Junior Pickleball

NJP has big plans for the coming year, with a focus on expanding to new regions and increasing opportunities for young players to compete and connect.¬†

"Our goal is to reach more young players and give them accessible pathways to competitive play, regardless of their location or skill level," the team shared. NJP‚Äôs vision is to establish junior pickleball as a go-to sport for young athletes, from beginners to those aspiring to compete at elite levels.¬†

As NJP Founder Courtney expressed. "Building a community where juniors and their families feel they truly belong is something I‚Äôm deeply passionate about."

In Houston, the NJP Championship Cup captured the essence of what junior pickleball is all about: community, competition, and joy. This year‚Äôs tournament will be remembered as a milestone, not only for the incredible performances and surprises but for the friendships and memories forged along the way.¬†

The future of junior pickleball looks bright, and we can‚Äôt wait to see what next year holds!

content:
With 180 players, the Virginia Beach Super Regional was the 3rd largest tournament in DUPR Collegiate Pickleball history, only behind the Georgia Super Regional (190) and 2023 Nationals (360). 17 schools contributed to the 180 players, with 13 of the schools in search of a bid to the 2024 Collegiate National Championship. This was the first collaboration event between MLP and DUPR Collegiate Pickleball, in order to showcase collegiate pickleball as a path to pro. The DUPR Collegiate National Championship on November 1st-3rd will also be a collaboration event with MLP.

‚Äç

In front of a lively audience, UVA secured their first Super Regional championship by beating UNC 3-1 in the finals. The last time these two teams met in the finals of a tournament was last year‚Äôs National Championship, when UVA beat UNC 3-2 in a dreambreaker. In 2024, both of these teams are looking to new players to keep themselves as championship-caliber teams. With David Bieger and Lauralei Singsank graduating from UVA, and Hunter Boyd, Collin Shick, and Caitlin Lewis no longer on the UNC pickleball team, both teams have to replace crucial pieces. Along with JMU and UConn, both UVA and UNC already had secured bids to Nationals before this tournament.¬†

‚Äç

Winners of the Virginia Beach Super Regional

‚Äç

NC State, UNCC, Duke, and Liberty all gained a bid through their play at the Virginia Beach Super Regional. NC State advanced to the semifinals, UNCC made it to the quarterfinals, and both Duke and Liberty won their Battle of the Bid showdowns against Randolph-Macon and High Point, respectively. Along with High Point, this was the first tournament appearance for Rutgers. In the challenger bracket, Samuel Pan and Seth Penniston from NC State won Men‚Äôs Doubles Group A, Aryan Mozar and Chase Harmer from JMU won Men‚Äôs Doubles Group B, Joshua Bridges and Caroline Messier from JMU won the Mixed/Women‚Äôs Doubles bracket.¬†

title: Pickleball Rules 101: A Fun and Simple Guide to Playing America‚Äôs Fastest-Growing Sport
summary: New to pickleball? Learn the essential pickleball rules, including singles vs. doubles play, scoring, and kitchen rules. Master the game and boost your DUPR pickleball rating with this fun and simple guide!
content:
Pickleball players know that the right equipment can make a huge difference on the court. The type of pickleball you choose can impact your game, whether you‚Äôre playing indoors or outdoors. These pickleballs are designed for different conditions, and understanding their characteristics can enhance your performance.

‚Äç

Pickleballs are specialized plastic balls with a lightweight construction and perforated design that help control flight and bounce, making them suitable for various play environments. Let‚Äôs explore what sets these two types of pickleballs apart and how they impact your performance.

‚Äç

Pickleballs guidelines

These parameters ensure consistency and quality:

Must be 2.87-2.97 inches in diameter
Must weigh between 0.78 and 0.935 ounces¬†
Must have a bounce of 30-34 inches when dropped from a height of 78 inches
A minimum of 26 and a maximum of 40 holes
Uniform color and untextured surface

Based on these guidelines, pickleball companies have made specific design adjustments for both indoor and outdoor play.

‚Äç

Indoor Pickleballs

The softer material and reduced bounce of indoor pickleballs make them ideal for controlled environments. Players can expect more predictable bounces and slower speeds, which allow for longer rallies and strategic play.

Features:
Material: Made from a softer plastic, providing a different feel during play
Weight: Typically around 0.8 ounces (22.7 grams)
Holes: Usually have 26 holes, allowing for better airflow and reduced wind interference
Bounce: Lower bounce compared to outdoor versions, promoting more controlled gameplay¬†

‚Äç

Outdoor Pickleballs

The durability and speed of outdoor pickleballs make them suitable for use on various surfaces, including concrete and asphalt. Players often experience a faster game, which encourages aggressive play and quick reflexes.

Features:
Material: Made from harder plastic, ensuring durability and resistance to wear from harsh conditions
Weight: Like indoor balls, they weigh around 0.8 ounces (22.7 grams), but their construction affects performance
Holes: Typically, have around 40 holes, minimizing wind impact and allowing for greater speed and trajectory
Bounce: Generally, have a higher bounce, leading to faster-paced games

‚Äç

Foam Pickleballs

Foam pickleballs are a great option for beginners and casual play, offering a softer alternative to standard plastic balls. While they are not typically used in official competitions, they serve as training tools and help introduce new players to the game.

Material: Made from soft, lightweight foam that is less likely to cause injury risk, making them suitable for younger players and recreational use
Weight: Typically, lighter than standard balls, weighing about 0.5 to 0.6 ounces
Holes: Often have fewer or no holes, affecting flight and handling.
Bounce: Foam balls have a lower bounce, making them easier to control for beginners
Noise reduction: Designed to be quieter during play, ideal for indoor environments or residential areas.

‚Äç

Whether you‚Äôre playing on an indoor or outdoor court, choosing the right type of pickleball is crucial for enhancing your experience. Understanding the differences between indoor and outdoor pickleballs can help you select the right ball for your game.

‚Äç

The next time you step onto the court, consider which pickleball suits your environment best, and enjoy the game!

title: Pickleball: The Fastest-Growing Sport in America
summary: Pickleball Explained: Learn the basics, why it‚Äôs growing so fast in the U.S., and how the DUPR pickleball rating system helps players find fair competition.
content:
Pickleball is a fun, fast-paced sport that is easy to learn, but understanding the rules is essential to playing successfully. Knowing the official pickleball rules will help you enjoy the game and compete at your best, whether you're playing singles or doubles, indoors or outdoors. In this post, we'll cover the basic pickleball rules, the differences between singles and doubles play, and highlight important concepts like pickleball scoring rules and pickleball kitchen rules.

‚Äç

Basic Pickleball Rules

Pickleball is played on a 20x44-foot court with a net in the middle. The game begins with a serve, where the server hits the ball underhand and diagonally across the net to the opponent‚Äôs service area. The ball must clear the non-volley zone (commonly called the kitchen) and land in the opponent‚Äôs diagonal service box.

Serving: The serve must be underhand, and the ball must be struck below the waist. The server must be positioned behind the baseline and serve the ball diagonally. Only one serve attempt is allowed.
Double Bounce Rule: After the serve, the ball must bounce once on each side of the net before either team can begin volleying (hitting the ball in the air without letting it bounce). This ensures a more controlled start to each rally.
Faults: A fault occurs when a player fails to return the ball, hits the ball out of bounds, or violates other key rules like stepping into the kitchen while volleying (more on that later).

‚Äç

Official Pickleball Rules for Singles and Doubles

While the pickleball rules singles and pickleball rules doubles share many similarities, there are some key differences:

Singles Play: In singles pickleball, each player is responsible for covering the entire court. The serving player switches sides after every point. For example, if you serve from the right side and win the point, your next serve will come from the left side. Scoring in singles is simpler, as there is no need to alternate service between partners.
Doubles Play: In doubles pickleball, each player has a partner, and only the serving team can score points. After the first serve of the game, both partners have a chance to serve before the serve is turned over to the opponents (this is called "side-out"). The server starts on the right side of the court and alternates between sides after each point.

‚Äç

Pickleball Scoring Rules

Pickleball uses a rally scoring system. In pickleball doubles, only the serving team can score a point, while in pickleball singles, the server scores when they win the rally. A game is typically played to 11 points, and a team must win by two points. Tournaments may sometimes require games to be played to 15 or 21 points, with the same win-by-two rule.

In doubles, each partner gets a chance to serve before the serve goes to the opposing team. The exception is at the start of the game when only one partner on the initial serving team serves before the serve changes sides.

‚Äç

Pickleball Kitchen Rules

The kitchen, also known as the non-volley zone, is a 7-foot area on both sides of the net. Pickleball kitchen rules are crucial to understand, as they prevent players from dominating at the net by volleying (hitting the ball in the air) too close to the net.

Players cannot volley the ball while standing in or making contact with the kitchen.
It‚Äôs also a fault if your momentum carries you into the kitchen after volleying.
However, players are allowed to enter the kitchen to hit a ball that has bounced, provided they exit before the next volley.

These kitchen rules help keep the game fair and balanced, encouraging strategy and finesse over power and domination at the net.

‚Äç

Conclusion

Understanding official pickleball rules is key to playing well and enjoying the game, whether you're a beginner or an experienced player. From pickleball rules singles and doubles to the nuances of the pickleball kitchen rules, knowing the ins and outs of this sport ensures a fair and fun experience for everyone involved. With clear pickleball scoring rules, anyone can quickly pick up the game and compete in no time. So, grab a paddle, head to the court, and start playing pickleball!

title: The Fascinating History of Pickleball: From Backyard Game to Global Sport
summary: Explore the fascinating history of pickleball, from its invention in 1965 to its rise as a global sport. Learn about its origins and the story behind the name.
content:
Pickleball is a dynamic sport that combines elements of tennis, badminton, and table tennis, and it has quickly become one of the most popular activities across the U.S. Played on a court with a low net, players use paddles to hit a perforated plastic ball back and forth. The game can be played as singles or doubles, making it versatile and suitable for all ages and skill levels. It‚Äôs easy to learn, which makes it accessible for newcomers, yet competitive enough for seasoned athletes.

‚Äç

Pickleball Explained

Pickleball‚Äôs simplicity is part of its charm. The smaller court size and slower ball speed make it less physically demanding than tennis, while still providing enough challenge to engage players. Whether you‚Äôre playing indoors or outdoors, the game‚Äôs pace can be adjusted to match the setting, adding to its flexibility. Indoor pickleball is typically played on gym floors, while outdoor pickleball is usually on tennis or pickleball courts, where players contend with weather elements, adding to the fun.

‚Äç

The Role of DUPR

An exciting aspect of the pickleball sport is the DUPR (Dynamic Universal Pickleball Rating) system. DUPR helps players assess their skill levels by analyzing match results and performance, offering an accurate rating that ensures fair competition. Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or an advanced player, DUPR makes it easy to find suitable opponents, fueling the competitive aspect of the game.

‚Äç

Why Is Pickleball Called Pickleball?

A common question many have is, "Why is pickleball called pickleball?" The origin story is fun and fitting for such a playful sport. Legend has it that the game was named after the Pritchards‚Äô dog, Pickles, who used to chase after the ball during games. Another theory suggests the name came from ‚Äúpickle boat,‚Äù a rowing term referring to a crew made up of leftover rowers from different teams, which reflects pickleball‚Äôs mix of various sports.

‚Äç

Celebrity Appeal and Global Expansion

Pickleball‚Äôs reach extends beyond casual backyard games, with celebrities like Shaquille O'Neal and Barack Obama picking up paddles, adding to its widespread appeal. As the sport grows, so does its player base, with millions now playing worldwide. The sport is also gaining traction globally, from Canada to Europe, Asia, and beyond.

‚Äç

A Sport for Everyone

Pickleball‚Äôs blend of fun, fitness, and social engagement makes it appealing to a wide audience. Whether you‚Äôre playing indoors to escape the elements or enjoying outdoor pickleball under the sun, this versatile sport offers something for everyone. Thanks to DUPR and its global rise, pickleball is not just a game‚Äîit‚Äôs a community.

‚Äç

To start your own pickleball journey and track your progress, explore more about DUPR and pickleball events at www.dupr.com.

title: Utah Tech Beats the Heat and Claims 5th Regional Win
summary: Utah Tech claims its 5th regional win at the Nevada Super Regional, securing bids to the 2024 Collegiate National Championship. Watch the action now!
content:
We have big changes coming to the 2025 collegiate pickleball season! Each change has been made with the goal to offer more opportunities to compete across the country and further position pickleball as the next collegiate sport. Read more below to see what‚Äôs in store for next year!

‚Äç‚Äç

Partnership with UPA

DUPR Collegiate Pickleball has partnered with the UPA to bring collegiate pickleball to an even wider audience. We will be working together to have collegiate pickleball at more PPA & MLP tour stops in 2025, as well as establishing a path to pro for top collegiate players.¬†

‚Äç

2025 Collegiate National Championship

We have heard feedback about the mismatch of having the Collegiate National Championship (CNC or Nationals) in the fall semester, while the end of the school comes in the spring semester for most students. That changes in 2025! April 11th-13th, 2025 (location TBD) will be the 4th annual Collegiate National Championship. Going forward, CNC will always fall on the 2nd Saturday in April, so you can start planning ahead now!

‚Äç

With Nationals moving to April, the 2025 spring semester will be one entire collegiate season. The next season after that will be the 2025 fall semester to the 2026 spring semester, which follows the school year. With 2025 being a shorter season, we will be giving out 24 bids at the 2024 Collegiate National Championship this fall: Every school that makes the round of 16, plus the winners of the top 8 bowl games (bowl games are matches played on Sunday by eliminated schools). The 40 other bids will be given out at Super Regionals, PPA/MLP events, and Campus Regionals along with some wildcard bids.¬†

‚Äç

2025 Super Regionals

‚Äç

Georgia Super Regional - February 1st-2nd
Pickle & Social - Buford, GA

‚Äç

Ohio Super Regional - February 8th-9th
Paddle Taps - Worthington, OH

‚Äç

New Jersey Super Regional - March 1st-2nd
Robbinsville Pickle House - Robbinsville Twp, NJ

‚Äç

Arizona Super Regional - March 8th-9th
The Picklr - Scottsdale, AZ

‚Äç

Each Super Regional will be giving out 4 bids to the 2025 Nationals, and $6000 in scholarship money.¬†

‚Äç

2025 Campus Regionals

Many successful Campus Regionals have been run in 2024, and we plan on keeping that going in 2025! Each Campus Regional will continue to give out 1 bid to Nationals, and will still be run by schools and facilities that want to be a part of the collegiate pathway to Nationals. For anyone interested in running a campus regional, here is the link to all of the information.¬†

‚Äç

2025 Dual Matches

Dual matches are foundational in taking collegiate pickleball to new heights, and they will be a focus in 2025. Our dual match format is designed both to mirror our tournament rules, as well as allow for flexibility for teams of all sizes to compete. Here is the link explaining the dual match format.¬†

‚Äç

We‚Äôre excited for 2025, and we look forward to seeing your school represented at an event! For any questions, send us an email at college@mydupr.com.

For more information, please visit https://www.dupr.com/collegiate

‚Äç

title: MLP Australia event drawing record crowds - "hailed as the most electrifying display of pickleball ever witnessed in Australia"
summary: MLP Australia‚Äôs Championship Event drew record crowds and delivered the most electrifying pickleball showcase in the country. See team rankings, pickleball ratings updates, and the latest results from this historic event!
content:
79 players battled it out in triple digit temperatures at the 2nd Nevada Super Regional this past weekend! The heat didn‚Äôt prevent any of the nation‚Äôs top pickleball talent from showing up, as there were seventeen players with a 5.0+ DUPR in attendance - counting for 22% of the players! The four bids given out at this event will get schools into the Team Bracket at the DUPR Collegiate National Championship on November 1st-3rd, more details linked here.¬†

Their only games dropped were to the newcomer USC team, who took a game off them in both group play and in the semifinals. The other semifinal matchup was between Utah State and the Utah Tech 2nd team, which went down to a thrilling dreambreaker. It‚Äôs the first time that the Utah Tech 1st or 2nd team has played a dreambreaker against another school, and they‚Äôre now 0-1 as Utah State pushed past them to the finals.¬†

‚Äç

From this event, USC, ASU, and the University of Utah gained their bids by making it to the quarterfinals thanks to their group stage play. Fresno State earned the last bid by winning the consolation bracket over the GCU 3rd team. We‚Äôll see many of these schools again at the Arizona Super Regional on October 19th-20th, where the last 4 bids to Nationals will be given out.¬†

A special thanks goes to our DUPR Collegiate Pickleball partners: JOOLA, HEAD, GAMMA, Rally Republic, Osaka, No Apologies Hydration, Erne, Pickleball Superstore, and Total Pickleball. Another thanks goes to Life Time Green Valley in Henderson, NV for hosting this tournament!

title: Pickleball World Rankings (PWR) Announces $540K Prize Purse for 2025 Indian League
summary: PWR unveils 2025 pickleball events, including the $540K Indian League in Mumbai led by Andre Agassi. See full global tour dates, prizes & player details.
content:
The Major League format has made its way across continents, all the way to Australia, and it's in full swing this 2024!

‚Äç
The past September 19th, Major¬†League Australia (MLPA) celebrated their Championship Event. This attracted record crowds and has been praised as the most thrilling showcase of pickleball ever seen in the country. Bringing together top teams from across Asia, the team South East Asia Surge made history, claiming victory in Event One of Season Two of the MLP Australia on the Gold Coast.

Team Surge delivered an unforgettable performance, ultimately triumphing over the highly-rated Fast Fours in a nail-biting championship final. The journey to the teams championship title was not without challenges.where the team South East Asia Surge made history, claiming victory in Event One of Season Two of the MLP Australia on the Gold Coast.

‚Äç

In the semifinals, the Surge faced the formidable Western Vipers, a team filled with talent and featuring international star Shelby Bates and Australian rising star Emilia Schmidt. The Vipers, known for their strategic gameplay and relentless energy, put up a fierce resistance. Bates impressed with her powerful attack and precise shots, while Schmidt dazzled with her quick reflexes and court coverage, joined by the strong play of Ryan ‚ÄòRyno‚Äô Henry and Andy Horridge. It was the Vipers' first appearance in the semifinals, but ultimately, the Surge‚Äôs teamwork and resilience prevailed, resulting in a hard-fought 3-1 victory.

‚Äç

The final score stood at 3-1 in favor of the Surge.
Game one: Surge (Hsieh/Kao) 21 def 14 Fours (Wei/Truluck)
Game two: Fours (Wall/Pascoe) 25 def 23 Surge (Chan/Lazaro)
Game three: Surge (Lazaro/Kao) 21 def 14 Fours (Wei/Wall)
Game four: Surge (Chan/Hsieh) 21 def 15 Fours (Pascoe/Truluck)
‚Äç

Kao celebrated her team‚Äôs determination and focus, stating,

‚ÄúWe knew it would be a tough match against Liz and Jamie (Ting Chieh Wei), who had been in great form leading up to the final. But our team believed in each other and played with heart. This win means everything to us.‚Äù

‚Äç

Continue reading the article on MLPA's Official Website.
‚Äç


More about MLP Australia

Major League Pickleball (MLPA), is Australia's official professional pickleball league! With a commitment to showcasing elite talent and promoting the sport, MLPA operates in partnership with the Pickleball Australia Association, the governing body for pickleball in the country. Together, they shine a spotlight on top players, teams, and exhilarating events.

The excitement is ramping up for 2024 as MLPA and PPA Tour Australia (PPAA) announced a thrilling calendar of six events featuring a staggering prize purse of $700,000. This season promises to be a landmark year for professional pickleball across Australia, New Zealand, and Asia.

But that‚Äôs just the beginning! In 2025, Major League Pickleball is set to level up even further. Get ready for a season packed with six major events categorized into three tiers: Premier, Challenger, and Masters. With an impressive total of over $1 million in prize money ‚Äî with MLPA contributing more than $640,000 and the PPA Tour Australia adding another $400,000 ‚Äî the stakes have never been higher!

‚Äç

Check out the current team rankings and standings for MLPA HERE.

Watch MLP Australia on MLPA's official YouTube Channel!

‚Äç
